Body Text: after the event at al-rashid street in gaza , in which more than 100 people were reported killed after a rush on an aid convoy , the international community is under pressure to tackle the growing crisis of hunger in the territory , a fergal keane report from jerusalem . they die in all kind of place and way . broken under the rubble of their home , blasted by explosive , punctured by high velocity bullet , cut open by flying shard of metal . and now - citing concern over security - ha said it is unable to deliver aid to northern gaza . these are fundamental fact to bear in mind when trying to understand the tragedy . from the outset the international community - expressed in public statement - ha regarded israel a having the primary responsibility for ensuring aid can be delivered safely . but , after month of war there is no sign of what the un call `` an enabling environment `` in which large volume of aid can be delivered to those who need it . it is not a if there ha been absence of evidence of a mounting humanitarian crisis . witness the statement made by the un over several month . `` we are already seeing a cascading collapse in water , sewage , and sanitation service , telecom , food shortage , and healthcare , `` the un 's human right office reported on 15 november . on 2 december , the office for the co-ordination of humanitarian affair reported : `` un humanitarian on monday said that aid team had only ' extremely limited ' movement and access to the north wa `` now entirely blocked . `` twelve day later the un security council adopted resolution 2720 calling on `` the party to the conflict to allow , facilitate and enable the immediate , safe and unhindered delivery of humanitarian assistance at scale directly to palestinian civilian throughout that territory . `` on 26 january , the international court of justice ( icj ) required israel `` take immediate and effective measure to enable the provision of urgently needed basic service and humanitarian assistance . `` by 9 february , director of the un relief and welfare agency ( unrwa ) phillipe lazzarini wa accusing israel of blocking food for 1.1 million palestinian in gaza . according to the un , 500 lorry of aid are required each day . the daily average ha been 90 . the aid falling by parachute from the sky in recent day is welcomed on the ground , but it is also a symbol of the failure of the aid effort . there are road leading into gaza from israel and egypt along which lorry carrying huge amount of aid could travel - if those road were safe . the continuing war , and the chaotic condition it ha spawned , mean many lorry driver will not risk their life . civilian looting aid , and criminal gang stealing aid to sell , are part of what one un official termed the `` mogadishu-like `` condition that may be developing - a reference to the chaos that enveloped the somali capital during the civil conflict of the early 1990s . the hamas-run police force in gaza is unwilling to escort aid convoy because it member reportedly fear being shot by the israeli . a for hamas 's leader , having provoked this war they have vanished and are now fighting to survive in the tunnel and ruin of gaza . israel say it is facilitating aid delivery and that , for example , there were three escorted delivery on the night prior to the tragedy at al-rashid street . it ha blamed the un saying aid is stacked up inside the northern border and the un ha n't `` turned up `` to distribute the supply . it is also deeply mistrustful of unrwa - adding he wanted israel to restore water supply to gaza . a month later - on 12 february - he told the uk 's house of lord that israel had to make sure food , water and shelter were available to people in gaza `` because if they do n't do that , that would be a breach of international humanitarian law `` . in the wake of al-rashid street he called for an urgent investigation . `` this must not happen again , `` he said . but the evidence from many civilian in gaza is they live in constant fear of violent death and - Body Text: the division playing out in demonstration on british street are also playing out in all our life - and increasingly in the cultural world too . with antisemitism and islamophobia rising , word and action really matter , but from the pavement to the playground to the playhouse , the israel-gaza conflict is polarising opinion - and protest have spilled into the cultural world , with some inevitable backlash . there have been high-profile example of cultural figure venturing into the political arena and taking a stance on what 's unfolding . charlotte church sang the controversial pro-palestinian chant `` from the river to the sea `` at a concert . ( she denied she wa antisemitic ) . the comedian paul currie pulled out a palestinian flag after his show ended at london 's soho theatre and told jewish audience member who did n't stand up to `` get out `` . ( the theatre apologised and said it would n't be inviting currie back ) . and belfast rapper kneecap recently appeared on the late late show in ireland wearing pro-palestinian outfit . ( they apparently flouted rule set by the broadcaster ) . how is what 's happening in the middle east - and the tension being driven here by war and violence there - impacting the uk 's art and entertainment sphere ? what role doe culture have to heal political divide - or foment them ? they 're question i wanted to explore with figure working in that world , to understand where culture fit at a time that emotion are running understandably high . artist speaking up for cause they believe in is n't new . dame vanessa redgrave is almost a renowned for her political view a her acting talent . it 's hardly surprising there are people who want to protest about what 's happening in gaza . the cultural world contains a lot of left-leaning voice . we 've also seen ( so far resisted ) call for israel to be banned from having a pavilion at the venice biennale and from competing in the eurovision song contest . dame helen mirren and boy george were amongst the artist to sign an open letter in favour of israel taking part in what they called `` unifying event such a singing competition `` . they argued the contest is a crucial way `` to help bridge our cultural divide and unite people of all background `` . talking more broadly , the theatre director iqbal khan , associate director at the birmingham rep , say `` the nuance in these issue is being destroyed `` . he call the polarisation across all form of public life `` really concerning `` , describing `` a constant requirement to attach yourself to metaphorical flag and tribe of opinion which do n't represent the truth of thing . `` david baddiel raised the issue of tribalism on the bbc 's today programme last week . the comedian , writer and broadcaster said `` within the space i come from - culture , showbusiness , artist , whatever - it feel there is a lot of support for palestinian and it may feel that the jewish voice is n't able to be heard and cowers a bit at the moment `` . he added that baroness warsi , the former conservative deputy chairwoman and his co-host on a new podcast , had told him muslim feel similarly excluded and silenced in the world of politics and government . many would point to lee anderson 's comment about `` islamist `` controlling the london mayor a evidence of that . the actress and writer tracy-ann oberman told me that `` for those of u that have lived with israeli and with middle eastern politics for a very long time , who 've worked in advocacy between palestinian and israeli and who really understand the geopolitics of the region , we look at people who seem to have suddenly been educated at the university of tiktok to understand the situation - which is of course far too complex to be broken down in a 60-second video `` . she add that `` we 're in shock because of what they 're allowing themselves to say and to be part of `` . each night , more horror unfolds in gaza , with grim milestone passed and devastating image beamed into our home . the conflict wa sparked by horrific act of murder and rape carried out in israel by hamas on 7 october , and the ongoing trauma of the hostage held in gaza . the actor khalid abdalla , who play dodi fayed in the crown , say `` what is very hard is to find a voice which can speak in a way that honour the fact that there is grief and immense legacy on both side `` . but with no political solution , no ceasefire , and `` this scale of slaughter , what 's left for people other than to protest ? and if they have a platform culturally , to use it `` . it 's `` very charged territory `` but there is `` a moral imperative to take a stand `` . the tension in the middle east can have real world consequence in the uk , not just in racist attack on the street . tracy-ann oberman 's timely reimagining of shakespeare 's the merchant of venice is her attempt to `` reclaim `` a difficult play full of antisemitic trope . she wanted people to `` see on stage what anti-jewish hatred look like `` . she is a vocal antisemitism campaigner - often `` the lone voice in a room with so-called progressive creatives `` she say . she told me she now ha personal security a well a security guard who patrol the theatre a she performs her play the merchant of venice 1936 . `` you 've got a jewish actress who ha to have security in the west end because of speaking out about the rape on 7 october and the industry ha not risen up and said ' that 's wrong ' . `` `` there should be more people who are saying ' this is unacceptable ' . they would find it unacceptable if this wa happening to any other minority `` . `` the country should take this very seriously . a history ha proven , what start with the jew doe n't end with the jew `` . clearly , a line is breached if - in these inflamed time - people feel unsafe . khan say `` the right of an artist to show solidarity with people who are suffering should be absolutely honoured . the minute though somebody 's safety is threatened , that 's different `` . he us what happened at the soho theatre comedy show a an example of that . `` everybody in that cultural space should feel safe . and i 'm not sure in the soho instance that happened `` . ( soho theatre is still investigating what happened but said while it robustly supported the right of artist to express a wide range of view in their show , `` intimidation of audience member , act of antisemitism or any other form of racism will not be tolerated `` . ) khan say while `` vigorous debate `` is useful , people `` need to talk without encroaching on another 's safety or inciting others to violence `` . he belief there is `` enormous support culturally for those who oppose antisemitism `` . there is also `` massive disgust at what is going on in gaza at the moment , with obviously the understanding that the atrocity that began all of this wa the particular set of event on 7 october `` . `` the response feel appalling to a lot of people … that 's the thing that 's motivating those voice . `` i wa horrified at what happened on 7 october . but the continuing response and the amount , i would describe it a a genocide . `` the cultural space being used a a vehicle for activism is n't new . art never operates in a vacuum . think back to 1985 when spitting image broadcast a satirical song , released for sale the following year , called `` i 've never met a nice south african `` . it wa an attack on that country 's apartheid regime and wa comedic and pretty uncontroversial . fast forward to 2022 and the baftas took place soon after russia 's full-scale invasion of ukraine . star of the film world including benedict cumberbatch turned up wearing blue and yellow badge in support , and the ukraine flag wa projected onto the side of the royal albert hall . then , last summer , liverpool hosted eurovision on behalf of ukraine - in a sun-filled , joyful coming together of culture . but these geopolitical issue are viewed a binary , for the vast majority in the uk anyway . apartheid wa wrong and the invasion of ukraine is unjust - that 's the prevailing western narrative , and nobody is taking to the street or our tv screen to say otherwise . those artist picked a side and were lauded for it . the israel-gaza war is also binary for many , with more than 30,000 killed in gaza and about 1,200 killed in israel . but perhaps that leaf no room for nuance or an understanding that jew in britain are n't representative of the israeli state , just a british muslim do n't speak for hamas - and that there is genuine fear in our minority community a tension rise . oberman say `` a lot of people do n't seem to understand you can both be heartbroken at the situation in gaza and be appalled at the rise in antisemitism in the uk - the two are not mutually exclusive `` . so where doe all this leave that hard won right to freedom of expression ? she argues `` it 's sacrosanct but it doe n't seem to be working for the jewish community at the moment `` . abdalla say `` either we believe in freedom of expression or we do n't … artist and worker in culture generally have a responsibility to find way to express whatever is culturally important to their age `` . he belief the cultural arena `` ha to be a safe space for difficult conversation . the failure in public discourse ha fed this crisis and we have a duty to confront that . `` `` we need our artist , our cultural worker to be finding a way through , to find a language that can speak a way through , a part of finding a political solution . ``

's military launched an air and ground campaign in gaza after hamas 's attack on israel on 7 october , in which around 1,200 people were killed and 253 others were taken hostage . more than 30,000 people have been killed in gaza since then , the territory 's hamas-run health ministry say . more than 20 airdrop of aid into gaza have taken place over the past few week in co-ordination with the israeli military , with france , the united arab emirate and egypt conducting them alongside the u and jordan . one gaza resident , ismail mokbel , told bbc arabic 's gaza lifeline radio - an emergency radio service for the territory set up in response to the conflict - that package of aid dropped on friday consisted of some legume and a few woman 's health essential . another man , abu youssef , said he wa not able to get some aid that wa dropped near al-shifa hospital in gaza city . `` suddenly , when we were looking up into the sky , we saw aid parachute . so we remained in the place [ where we were ] until the aid landed about 500 metre away from u . there were many people , but the aid wa little , and so we could not get anything . `` mr mokbel said not enough aid wa dropped to meet the basic need of the large number of people in the area . `` thousand of citizen saw the aid falling on them . . . and when hundred or thousand wait in such area , only around 10 to 20 people get thing , while the others go back with nothing . unfortunately , this method of dropping through air is not the most suitable way to transport aid to the north district of gaza , `` he added . `` gaza need a land and water pathway to deliver the aid instead of [ doing it in ] such a manner , which doe n't meet the need of all citizen . `` initially employed during world war two to supply isolated troop on the ground , airdrop have evolved into a valuable tool for delivering humanitarian aid , with the un first using them in 1973 . however , they are considered a `` last resort `` , only to be used `` when more effective option fail `` , a the wfp said in a 2021 report . south sudan is the last place where the wfp carried out airdrop . `` airdrop are expensive , haphazard and usually lead to the wrong people getting the aid , `` jan egeland , the secretary general of the norwegian refugee council and a former un aid chief , told the bbc after returning from a recent three-day visit to gaza . airdrop are seven time more expensive compared to ground-delivered aid due to cost related to aircraft , fuel and personnel , say the wfp . in addition to that , only relatively small quantity can be delivered with each flight , in comparison to what a convoy of lorry can bring in , and significant ground co-ordination is required within the delivery zone , say the wfp . the international committee of the red cross also stress the importance of controlling distribution to prevent people from risking their life by consuming inappropriate or unsafe item . `` delivering sudden and unsupervised type of food to people who are malnourished or even starving can pose serious risk to life . these risk need to be weighed against delivering nothing by air , or the delay a ground distribution may incur , `` the organisation warned in a 2016 report published when aid wa being airdropped into syria during the country 's civil war . airdrop can be carried out from different altitude , ranging from about 300m to 5,600m ( 985-18,370ft ) in conflict zone , and so ensuring robust packaging is crucial to make sure parcel can endure impact with the ground , the wfp add . according to the agency , drop zone should ideally be large , open area no smaller than a football field , which is why delivery have often been aimed at gaza 's coastline . however , this ha sometimes resulted in aid falling into the sea or being carried by the wind into israel , according to local account . gaza resident samir abo sabha told bbc arabic 's gaza lifeline radio that he believed the u should do more and put pressure on it ally israel for a ceasefire . `` a a citizen of gaza , this stuff is of no use , `` he said . `` what we want [ is ] america to pressure israel israel uphold it duty to provide humanitarian aid , access , and other basic service . `` melanie ward of medical aid for palestinian said the u , uk and others should `` ensure that israel immediately open all crossing into gaza for aid and aid worker to assist those in need `` . but a the crisis deepens , others argued that food must be delivered by any mean necessary . `` we need to bring food into gaza any way we can . we should be bringing it by the sea , `` josé andrés , a chef and founder of world central kitchen , which ha been sending food to gaza , told abc news . `` i do n't think we need to be criticising that jordan , america are doing airdrop . if anything , we should be applauding any initiative that brings food into gaza . `` president biden ha vowed that the u will `` redouble our effort to open a maritime corridor , and expand delivery by land `` - but those effort have not yet translated into reality on the ground . israel defense force spokesman rear admiral daniel hagari said on sunday that they were facilitating aid convoy and airdrop to northern gaza `` because we want humanitarian aid to reach gazan civilian in need `` . `` we will continue expanding our humanitarian effort to the civilian population in gaza while we fulfil our goal of freeing our hostage from hamas and freeing gaza from hamas , `` he added . edited by alexandra fouché

malnutrition and dehydration across the territory since last week , with at least 15 happening at kamal adwan . it ha also expressed fear for six infant who it said were being treated for malnutrition at the hospital . the un 's child 's agency , unicef , ha warned that the number of child starving to death is likely to rapidly increase unless the war between israel and hamas end and obstacle to humanitarian relief are immediately resolved . gaza 's health ministry say child and woman make up 70 % of the more than 30,700 people who have been killed and 72,000 others injured in the territory killed and 253 others were taken hostage . an estimated 300,000 people are currently isolated in northern gaza , where the world food programme say hunger ha reached catastrophic level because only a trickle of aid ha been able to get through . malnutrition screening carried out there by un agency in january found that one in six child under two year of age wa acutely malnourished . of those child , almost 3 % were suffering from severe wasting and requiring urgent treatment . the lack of nutritious food , safe water and medical service - a well a exhaustion and trauma caused by the conflict - is also hindering the ability of mother to breastfeed their baby . without breast milk or formula - the supply of which are reported to be almost non-existent in the north - baby can quickly become severely dehydrated and malnourished , which increase the risk of life-threatening condition like kidney failure . dr samia abdel jalil , who work at kamal adwan 's intensive care unit , said in an for that little girl , `` she recalled . `` she died without getting her small dose of milk . `` salah samara , a four-month-old boy , is one of the seriously ill child who dr abdel jalil and her disease and urinary retention , which is extremely painful and cause abdominal bloating . `` my heart hurt a lot because of what is happening with him . it is a very difficult thing that you see your Body Text: israel 's government ha advanced plan for more than 3,400 new home in settlement in the occupied west bank . about 70 % of the home will be built in maale adumim , east of jerusalem , with the rest in nearby kedar and efrat , south of bethlehem . a minister ha said the construction is a response to a deadly palestinian attack near maale adumim two week ago . the palestinian authority condemned the plan , which are reportedly the first to be approved since june . israel ha built about 160 settlement housing some 700,000 jew since it occupied the west bank and east jerusalem - land the palestinian want a part of a future state - in the 1967 middle east war . the vast majority of the international community considers the settlement illegal under international law , although israel dispute this . israel 's haaretz newspaper said the higher planning committee of the civil administration - the body that implement israeli government policy in the west bank - had advanced plan for the development of 3,476 settler home on wednesday - with 2,452 in maale adumim , 694 in efrat and 330 in kedar . finance minister bezalel smotrich , a far-right politician who oversees the civil administration , said following the meeting that a total of 18,515 home in west bank settlement had now been approved over the past year . `` the enemy try to harm and weaken u but we will continue to build and be built up in this land , `` he wrote on x , formerly twitter . however , the israeli anti-settlement watchdog peace now warned : `` instead of building a future of hope , peace , and security , the israeli government is paving the way for our destruction . `` it said the project would have a negative impact on the possibility of a two-state solution to the israeli-palestinian conflict . the foreign ministry of the west bank-based palestinian authority condemned both the new plan and mr smotrich 's remark . `` settlement is void and illegitimate from it foundation , representing an explicit call for the continuation of the spiral of violence and war , `` a statement said . mr smotrich put forward the plan on 22 february , hour after three palestinian gunman opened fire on car on a road near maale adumim , killing one israeli and wounding several others . he said the attack `` must have a determined security response but also a settlement response `` . u secretary of state antony blinken expressed disappointment with the decision the following day and surprised many observer by declaring that the u viewed settlement a illegal - reverting to a position that had been overturned by former president donald trump 's administration in 2019 . `` it 's been longstanding u policy under republican and democratic administration alike that new settlement are counterproductive to reaching an enduring peace , `` he told reporter in argentina . `` they 're also inconsistent with international law . our administration maintains a firm opposition to settlement expansion . and in our judgement , this only weakens - it doe n't strengthen - israel 's security . `` a peace now report said in january that there had been an `` unprecedented surge in settlement activity `` across the west bank since the start of the war in the gaza strip , triggered by hamas 's deadly attack in israel on 7 october . the west bank ha also experienced a spike in violence over the same period . the un say at least 413 palestinian - member of armed group , attacker and civilian - have been killed in conflict-related incident in the west bank , including east jerusalem , or in israel since october . fifteen israeli , including four security force personnel , have also been killed .

Body Text: a university challenge student ha accepted `` substantial damage `` from a tory peer who falsely accused her of being antisemitic . baroness jacqueline foster made the claim after melika gorgianeh appeared on the programme in november . she ha apologised to m gorgianeh on x , formerly twitter , saying the allegation were `` completely false `` . the university of oxford student said she had received death threat after the post wa published . in a now-deleted tweet in november 2023 , baroness foster criticised m gorgianeh for wearing what she said were the colour of the palestinian flag and for the team 's soft toy octopus mascot , which she described a one of the most `` disgusting antisemitic symbol , `` according to a statement by rahman lowe solicitor - the law firm representing m gorgianeh . jewish people were sometimes depicted a octopus in nazi poster during world war two . in the november post , baroness foster called for m gorgianeh to be `` expelled `` by her university and `` arrested `` by the police , the statement said . rahman lowe said the allegation were made despite m gorgianeh wearing a blue , orange , green and pink jacket , being part of a four-person team and the fact that the programme wa recorded in march 2023 , before the outbreak of the israel-gaza war . the palestinian flag 's colour are red , black , green and white . baroness foster reiterated her apology for the post , saying : `` i wrongly alleged that m gorgianeh chose one of the most disgusting antisemitic symbol , a blue octopus a her team 's mascot which i held her responsible for . `` i accept that these allegation were completely false and unfounded . `` i again deeply apologise to m gorgianeh for these allegation and any distress caused to her . . . i have agreed to pay her substantial damage and cost . `` m gorgianeh said the allegation had had a `` deeply damaging impact `` on her life and she had felt `` unsafe `` to leave her house . `` i wa a student appearing on my favourite tv quiz show . all of a sudden , lie told about me , and only me , led to me receiving death threat and to my mental health deteriorating , `` she said in a statement . `` baroness foster 's post , and the post of others who are yet to be held to account , affected both myself and my family . `` she added : `` word have consequence . and now , through her apology , baroness foster 's word begin to have the consequence of healing the very real damage that had been done to me . `` it come after cabinet minister michelle donelan apologised to an academic after wrongly suggesting she supported hamas , costing the taxpayer £ 15,000 in damage .

israel 's siege and denouncing antisemitism and islamophobia.however , the council stopped short of calling for a ceasefire . `` we understand the anger of some member of our community in relation to large ship carrying food , water , medicine and temporary shelter . initial shipment will arrive via cyprus , where israeli security inspection will take place . `` a temporary pier will enable a massive increase in the amount of humanitarian assistance getting into gaza every day , `` president biden said . he added that israel must `` do it part `` by allowing more aid to enter into the territory and to `` ensure that humanitarian worker are n't caught in the crossfire `` . `` humanitarian assistance can not be a secondary consideration or a bargaining chip . `` on friday , uk to get shipload of aid in urgently , while the administration ha publicly ramped up it pressure and increasingly shown in public it impatience with israel over the desperate situation on the ground . designed for rapid deployment , but the military ship have not yet left the u , the official said . vice adm kevin donegan , who wa formerly commander of the u navy 's fifth fleet - the most senior u naval commander in the middle east - told bbc radio 4 's world tonight programme that the port plan wa `` absolutely executable `` . however , he said delivering aid by land wa still the most effective way , in term of being able to get a many good in a possible . vice adm donegan also cautioned that having `` security and a good distribution network `` would be critical for the safe delivery of aid from the port , referencing the more than 100 people who were killed trying to reach an aid convoy . last week , amid the growing desperation . palestinian said most were shot by israeli troop . the israeli military , which wa overseeing the private aid delivery , said most were killed in a stampede . aid lorry have been entering the south of gaza through the egyptian-controlled rafah crossing and the israeli-controlled kerem shalom . but the north , which wa the focus of the first phase of the israeli ground offensive , ha been largely cut off from assistance in recent month . on 20 february , the un 's world food programme ( wfp ) said it wa suspending food delivery to northern gaza because it first aid convoy in three week had endured `` complete chaos and violence due to the collapse of civil order `` , including violent looting . the u and other nation have resorted to dropping aid in by air - but humanitarian organisation say that method is a last resort and ca n't meet the soaring need . an independent un expert on thursday accused israel of mounting `` a starvation campaign against the palestinian people in gaza `` . `` the image of starvation in gaza are unbearable and you are doing nothing , `` michael fakhri , un special rapporteur on the right to food , said in a speech to the un human right council . yeela cytrin , a legal adviser at the israeli mission to the un , said `` israel utterly reject allegation that it is using starvation a a tool of war `` , before walking out in protest . during his state of the Body Text: the israel defense force ( idf ) ha finished building a new road which run across northern gaza from east to west , according to satellite image verified by the bbc . the idf told the bbc they were attempting to gain an `` operational foothold `` , and facilitate the movement of troop and equipment . but some expert fear it will used a a barrier , preventing palestinian from returning to their home in the north . others said it appeared to be part of an israeli plan to remain in gaza beyond the end of current hostility . in february , prime minister benjamin netanyahu unveiled a post-war vision in which israel would control security in gaza indefinitely . international leader have previously warned israel against permanently displacing palestinian or reducing the size of gaza . it run across north gaza , with central and southern area lying below it . it start at gaza 's border fence with israel near the nahal oz kibbutz and finish near the coast . it also intersects with the salah al-din and al-rashid road , the two major artery running through the territory . although there is a network of road which connect east and west , the new idf route is the only one which run uninterrupted across gaza . satellite imagery analysis by the bbc reveals that the idf ha built over 5km ( 3 mile ) of new road section to join up previously unconnected road . the initial section of the road in eastern gaza near the israeli border wa established between late last october and early november . but most of the new section were built during february and in early march . the new route is wider than a typical road in gaza , excluding salah al-din . imagery analysis also show that building along the route , which appear to be warehouse , were demolished from the end of december until late january . this includes one building several story high . the road span an area which previously had fewer building and wa less densely populated than other part of gaza . it also sits below a makeshift and winding route which the idf had been using to move from east to west . an israeli tv channel reported on the route in february , saying it wa code named `` highway 749 `` . a reporter from channel 14 travelled along part of the route with the israeli military . in the video , road construction vehicle and digger were seen preparing for the construction of new section of the route . analyst at janes , a defence intelligence company , said the type of unpaved road surface seen in the channel 14 footage , wa suitable for tracked armoured vehicle . the idf did not go into this type of detail in it statement . `` a part of the ground operation , the idf us an operational route of passage , `` it said . retired brig gen jacob nagel , former head of israel 's national security council and a former security adviser to mr netanyahu , told bbc arabic that the objective of the new route wa to provide fast access for security force when dealing with fresh threat . `` it will help israel go in and out . . . because israel is going to have total defence , security and responsibility for gaza , `` he told bbc arabic . he described it a `` a road that divide the northern part from the southern part `` . `` we do n't want to wait until a threat is emerging , `` he added . maj gen yaakov amidror , formerly of the idf , had a similar view . the primary purpose of the new road wa to `` facilitate logistical and military control in the region `` , he said . justin crump , a former british army officer who run sibylline , a risk intelligence company , said the new route wa significant . `` it certainly look like it 's part of a longer-term strategy to have at least some form of security intervention and control in the gaza strip , `` said mr crump . `` this area cut off gaza city from the south of the strip , making it an effective control line to monitor or limit movement , and ha relatively open field of fire . `` khaled elgindy , a senior fellow at the us-based middle east institute , also think the road is a long-term project . `` it appears that the israeli military will remain in gaza indefinitely , `` he told the bbc . `` by dividing gaza in half , israel will control not only what go in and out of gaza , but also movement within gaza , `` said the analyst . `` this includes quite possibly preventing the 1.5 million displaced palestinian in the south from returning to their home in the north . `` additional reporting by paul cusiac , alex murray & erwan rivault

the democratic unionist party ( dup ) - in it support for the israeli government . aside from those difficult conversation , the first and deputy first minister will be keen to cash in on the good will generated by stormont 's return . judging by the list of engagement , they will take centre stage in washington this week and are likely to be the go-to couple for selfies . but their focus will be on the £ 5bn ( $ 6.4bn ) in u investment promised by president biden on stormont 's return . that pledge wa made during his visit to belfast in 2023 . the president 's point man in northern ireland , special envoy joe kennedy , will be under pressure to deliver . to that end he is hosting a number of investment gathering this week which will be attended by the first and deputy first minister . economy minister conor murphy will also be in attendance , along with stormont speaker edwin poots . education minister paul givan is joining the delegation in washington , where he will be lobbying to secure extra investment for childcare . dup leader sir jeffrey donaldson is also making the trip . in 2023 , northern ireland secretary chris heaton-harris played a leading role during the festivity a the only political gatekeeper in office . this year he will be happy to drop to the supporting-role category , making way for the locally elected politician to step up . but while it may feel like a lap of honour now stormont is back , there is enough to keep mind focused elsewhere .

security minister itamar ben-gvir hailed the officer who shot ramus a a `` hero and a warrior `` , saying he had done an `` exemplary job `` and would receive the full support of the minister 's office . mr ben-gvir branded ramus al-halhouli a `` terrorist `` . not far from the police station where the minister spoke , on wednesday , rawia al-halhouli wa sitting in her living room surrounded by friend , relative and tearful mourner who came one at a time to pay their respect . outside in the courtyard , ramus 's father ali , 60 , wa sitting with the men of the family and friend , unable since then . the chief spokesman of the israel defense force ( idf ) , rear adm daniel hagari , said in a briefing to journalist on wednesday that they needed to make sure that all 1.4 million people currently living in rafah , or `` at least a significant amount `` , would leave ahead of any offensive . he suggested that they could move to `` humanitarian island that we will create with the international community `` , where temporary housing , food and water would be provided . but there are still plenty of logistical question to answer . moving more than half of gaza 's population from palestinian are hungrier and weaker than they were five month ago , which would also make large-scale movement slow . the central part of the strip where israel proposes to relocate them ha been badly damaged by repeated ground and air attack . the u secretary of state , antony blinken , said he wa yet to receive further detail , but `` needed to see a plan to get civilian out of harm 's way `` of any ground operation in rafah and ensure they had food , shelter and medicine . benny gantz , a member of israel 's war cabinet , had suggested a new military operation would begin in rafah by the start of the islamic holy month ramadan if no new hostage release deal wa agreed . that did not happen , but prime minister benjamin netanyahu continues to reference it when he address the israeli people . `` there is international pressure to prevent u from entering rafah and completing the work . a prime minister of israel , i reject this pressure , `` mr netanyahu told soldier at ofer military base on thursday . `` we will enter rafah . we will complete the elimination of hamas 's battalion . we will restore security and we will bring total victory for the people of israel and state of israel , `` he added . the idf would also need to bolster it number again ahead of any new ground offensive . many of the reservist who were called up in the early day of the war have now been released from duty , and would need to be brought back into operation . rear adm hagari told journalist that the idf wa also `` trying to flood `` gaza with humanitarian aid by opening up multiple route by land , sea and air . he said u military expert were due to arrive in israel this week to discus with the idf a u plan to build a floating dock and temporary pier off gaza 's coast . it would be able to receive containerloads of food , water and medicine . mr blinken emphasised that the floating dock , which will take between one and two month to become fully operational , would be `` a complement to - not a substitute for - other way of getting humanitarian assistance into gaza `` . `` in particular , overland route remain the most critical way to get assistance in and then to people who need it , `` he said . the un ha warned that half a million people are on the brink of famine in gaza . israel , a the occupying power , ha the responsibility to see that food and Body Text: the u ha announced sanction against three more israeli settler and - for the first time - two farming outpost , a part of new measure by washington and london to stop the violent displacement of palestinian in the occupied west bank . fare samamreh may not carry a gun , but he ha a global superpower defending him . he 's still losing the fight . a palestinian sheep farmer on the sun-tinged slope of the south hebron hill in the occupied west bank , his battle with his neighbour , an israeli settler called yinon levy , ha drawn both the u and the uk into the dispute . `` yinon levy came here three year ago and started bothering me , `` fare said , his head wrapped in a piece of white cotton , his eye narrowed in a permanent squint against the sun . `` before the war [ in gaza ] it wa the usual thing ; they would come with drone . but a few day after 7 october , it became serious . they all had gun . they started coming to u day and night . i have little kid - some of them are four and five year old . `` fare said yinon wa one of a group of local israeli settler who would regularly come to harass his sheep with their dog and weapon , and even , he say , to assault his family . `` they destroyed water tank , closed down road , they fire at the sheep , `` he said . `` he told my wife if we did n't leave here , we 'd all be killed . `` he said when his wife then swore at him , yinon levy hit her with the butt of his gun . soon afterwards , fare and his family left their village of zanuta . activist say it 's one of four community around the settler 's farm that have been abandoned by their resident . yinon ha denied acting violently towards palestinian in the area - and said he did n't own a gun until very recently . but he 's the subject of sanction from both the u and the uk . the road to yinon 's farm is straight out of a child 's picture-book ; a narrow path that wind back and forth up a steep hill , slope and valley dropping away to the horizon on either side . at the top , a spacious bungalow stand next to a large shed , full of bleating sheep smothering the strain of pop music from a radio . `` we 're safeguarding these land to ensure they remain under jewish ownership , `` yinon said . `` when there is a jewish presence , then there is no arab presence . we keep a watchful eye on the land , ensuring that no unauthorised construction take place . `` most country deem the settlement , which are built on land captured by israel in 1967 in the middle east war , to be illegal under international law , although israel disagrees . the settler outpost are also illegal under israeli law . the uk said that yinon and another man had `` used physical aggression , threatened family at gunpoint , and destroyed property a part of a targeted and calculated effort to displace palestinian community `` . yinon denied the allegation , and said that the israeli government wa on his side . `` i 'm not worried , `` he told the bbc . `` this is not against me personally - it 's against those who obstruct the creation of a palestinian state . there 's no legal process against me [ in israel ] . here , everything is fine . `` both the uk and the u say there is a threshold of evidence that must be met - but neither have made that evidence public and declined to share it with the bbc . we sent yinon a video appearing to show him on palestinian land , approaching activist with a snarling dog . he said it wa misleading , and that he wa defending his flock . we sent him another video apparently showing him entering another palestinian village with a gun last october . he declined to comment . the sanction came after a surge in violence in the west bank , following the 7 october hamas attack and israel 's war in gaza . the un say violence by israeli settler included physical attack and death threat , and that the number of palestinian displaced from their home last year doubled to 1,539 - with more than 80 % of them leaving after 7 october . the uk ha said israel is failing to act , and ha described `` an environment of near total impunity for settler extremist in the west bank `` . yinon said that he had received support from israeli politician . `` many called and encouraged u , `` he said . `` everyone said that when the bad people are against you , you must be doing something right . `` one of the politician who publicly backed yinon in the wake of the sanction wa zvi sukkot of the ultranationalist religious zionism party - a settler himself . he said that settler violence wa a `` marginal phenomenon `` and that those like levy were the victim of conspiracy . `` when we have a functioning judicial system in israel , we do n't want our ally to say , ' we 'll do the job for you ' , `` he said . `` if there wa evidence against yinon levy , he would be in israeli prison . who is britain to come and say , ' we are smarter than israeli intelligence ' ? `` the israeli police commander responsible for investigating complaint in the west bank told mr sukkot 's parliamentary committee this week that half the complaint filed about settler violence there were false , and that they originated from `` radical left-wing organisation in tel aviv `` . against this backdrop , sanction on a handful of individual settler have not shifted israeli policy in the west bank , but they are having a financial impact . yinon 's israeli bank account wa frozen last month . some of those currently under u and uk sanction have used crowdfunding to finance project for their area - including one for a synagogue and educational centre at another hilltop outpost called moshe 's farm . it owner , moshe sharvit , wa sanctioned along with yinon levy last month . but on thursday the u expanded sanction to cover several new target , including the farm itself - putting this kind of funding at risk . these sanction may be more symbolic than substantial , but they signal american displeasure - both to israel 's leader , and to the part of president biden 's democratic base who have been dismayed by image of the war in gaza , in an election year . the chairman of the local yesha ( settler ) council , shlomo ne'eman , called it `` a disgusting phenomenon `` and said the west bank wa being used a a scapegoat . `` i think more than anything , what drive the response of the uk [ and ] the u is the fear of one settler attack that go ' out of control ' , `` said yehuda shaul , founder of the ofek centre , a think tank which campaign to end israel 's occupation . `` the west bank [ then ] erupts like a volcano . and we have another front , a if gaza is not enough , and the road to regional war is almost unstoppable then . `` two sheep farmer in the occupied west bank - one backed by a superpower , the other by the israeli state . if the lifestyle here is simple , the politics are complicated . from yinon 's hilltop farm , you can clearly see the ruin of zanuta perched on the next hill , with the home fare samamreh left month ago . many of the house are ravaged - roof and furniture taken by their owner into exile ; wall smashed by settler to prevent them returning , activist say . the deserted village is slowly being taken over by vast bank of wild mallow . on a post near the entrance , a large star of david ha been scrawled in blue paint . settler here point to attack by palestinian , and say they are scared . but it 's palestinian who are leaving .

said `` it very much doubt `` the flag cause `` any harm `` . mr rahman said he rejected the idea that the flag were symbol of division , but the council had made the decision to remove them . `` we have been described a a no-go area by a senior conservative mp , and received notice from the government that an immediate inspection of the council would begin that day and continue over the coming month , `` he said . `` numerous article have been published about the borough in the past fortnight , often littered with inaccuracy and islamophobic smear . `` sadly , it is clear the palestinian flag flying in the borough have been the focus of these medium attack , `` mr rahman said . he added that a recent rise in islamophobia in london made `` tower hamlet , with the highest muslim population in the uk , a target `` . however , local conservative councillor peter gold said he felt the decision to remove them should have been taken month ago . `` there are many people who are sympathetic to the palestinian cause but at the same time we do n't want to see lamppost in every street covered with flag , of any kind , `` he said . `` the council commissioned a senior lawyer to write a report on this . they received the report several week ago and it wa quite conclusive that the flag contravened planning law and therefore were unlawful . `` they should have acted week ago . `` the decision come nearly five month after transport for london said it would remove `` unauthorised flag `` from it infrastructure within the borough . a spokesperson for the council said : `` tower hamlet is one of the most diverse place in the country and we have seen palestinian flag put up by resident on private and public land during the recent middle east conflict . `` the council Body Text: since the start of the israel-gaza war , following the hamas attack of 7 october , the overriding fear ha been that the conflict could spill over into something even deadlier . the day after the hamas assault , lebanon 's most powerful armed group hezbollah fired guided rocket and shell into israel in solidarity with hamas , prompting israeli drone and artillery retaliation . could israel , traumatised and vulnerable , with a prime minister fighting for political survival , decide the threat from across it northern border in lebanon need to be neutralised ? the fear ha been that benjamin netanyahu 's government might be tempted into a second front in the war , against hezbollah - which , like hamas , is intent on destroying the jewish state . and if so , would it draw in iran , hezbollah 's key patron in the region and sworn enemy of the u ? this week israel carried out more air strike on the bekaa valley , deep into lebanon , taking the death toll in lebanon since the start of the conflict to more than 240 . in retaliation , hezbollah fired a barrage of 100 katyusha rocket on northern israel , it heaviest attack since the war began , with target including israeli army base in the golan height . at least 17 israeli have been killed in attack from lebanon and syria since october . the rocket this week prompted an angry post by israel 's far-right national security minister itamar ben-gvir , addressed to the defence minister yoav gallant : `` the military is your responsibility . what are you waiting for ? we have to start responding , attacking - war , now ! `` last month , chief of staff of the israel defence force ( idf ) herzi halevi said : `` we are now focusing on being prepared for war in the north . `` for long , it seemed that the clash on the border were carefully calibrated around unspoken red line to avoid escalation into all-out war . hassan nasrallah , the leader of hezbollah , ha not called for it . memory in lebanon are still fresh of the disastrous 2006 war with israel , which left more than 1,000 lebanese dead . and israel know that hezbollah 's military capability is far greater than that of hamas . a poll published in the country 's maariv newspaper last month showed that 71 % of respondent favoured a large-scale military operation to drive hezbollah back . sarit zehavi life close to the lebanese border and head the alma research centre , which specialises on the threat there . she say hezbollah 's aim is `` to drag israel into war without actually initiating it `` . but , she argues , israel is not looking for all-out confrontation . `` israel 's interest is to avoid full scale war - but achieve an improved security situation , while damaging hezbollah 's brigade a much a possible . for israel , it is about choosing the least worst option : we understand the capability of hezbollah here and the cost of war . `` she belief that hezbollah 's use of rocket , which have a longer range than anti-tank missile used previously by the group , is evidence of a shift in the group 's military tactic and capability . `` hezbollah take into consideration the cost of a war , but they do n't look into the near future - they look year ahead . `` `` they have already gained by forcing the evacuation of ten of thousand of israeli , `` she add - about 60,000 israeli living in community close to the border have fled the fighting since october , the largest such displacement in israeli history . around 100,000 lebanese resident have also been moved from the other side of the border . to allow for the evacuee to return , israel want to push hezbollah 's force back beyond the litani river , which mark a buffer zone of sort between beirut and the israeli border . a part of the agreement to end the 2006 war , the area south of the litani wa supposed to be clear of military presence except for that of the lebanese army and un force - which hezbollah ha violated . that 's been part of discussion with amos hochstein , the u special envoy , who ha been repeatedly dispatched to the region to avert an escalation . but a deal on hezbollah 's withdrawal and disarmament remains elusive . so far , both benjamin netanyahu and hezbollah appear to be holding back from the precipice . the israeli army is already stretched in gaza , without opening a new front - and a new wave of international tension . and hezbollah is in reactive mode , opting more for a lower-level war of attrition . but the real risk is miscalculation , and caving into competing pressure . mr netanyahu is battered by the perception that he left his country vulnerable to the worst attack in it history , reviled by family of the hostage who want him to strike a deal to bring them back , and excoriated by the west over the mounting civilian casualty in gaza . the fear is that he may see expanding the fight in lebanon a key to his political survival - and that israel , in the wake of the 7 october attack , would not countenance the continued threat on it northern front without taking military action . professor hilal khashan , from the american university in beirut , belief israel 's relative restraint so far doe n't tell the true story . `` netanyahu clearly want war , `` he say , pointing to israel 's strike on about 4,000 position across lebanon since october . `` he is finished politically and when the war stop , he will have to face his reckoning , `` he say . `` i do n't think he 'll give a damn about what the u or europe will think - he ha made up his mind on hezbollah . `` a further , and potentially more serious , unknown would be the response from iran , which relies on hezbollah , it proxy in lebanon , a a bulwark against israel . since the hamas attack , tehran ha flexed it muscle across the middle east . iran-backed group have hit u military base in iraq and syria , and yemen 's houthi rebel , aligned with iran , have launched countless strike on ship in the red sea . it ha so far stopped short of an unfettered war . but major israeli strike on hezbollah could change tehran 's calculus . in lebanon , there is little appetite for full conflict with israel , particularly among religious group that do n't belong to the shia branch of islam to which hezbollah belongs . `` non-shias are almost unanimously opposed , and want hezbollah to disarm , `` say professor khashan . but shia are unhappy about the fighting too , he say . `` by and large , they do n't want war either . `` hassan nasrallah ha said that he will not agree to a ceasefire with israel before there is a truce in gaza . he is reported to have told an iranian military leader last month that he did not want iran to get sucked into a war with israel or the united state - becoming softer . they are dizzy , they struggle to walk . they are becoming very thin . `` according to the poverty charity care , at least 27 people - 23 of them child - have died from malnutrition or dehydration in northern gaza in recent week . the real number , according to doctor from several northern hospital , is likely to be higher . among those treated for malnutrition by dr eleiwa at al-shifa hospital recently wa a boy aged between 10 and 12 who died last week during ramadan ; a boy aged around four month whose mother wa killed , leaving him short of milk when none wa available to buy ; and an 18-year-old girl who wa already suffering from epilepsy . `` she wa already sick and none of her medicine wa available any longer and her family had no food , `` dr eleiwa said . `` in the end her body wa very meagre , just bone and skin and no fat . `` under his care at al-shifa on friday , 16-year-old rafeeq dughmoush wa lying on his side , bedbound . rafeeq 's bone were showing and one of his leg had been amputated from the knee down . a colostomy bag wa attached to his torso . `` i am emaciated , `` he said , speaking slowly in order to draw breath between word . `` i am so weak i can not move my body from one side to another . my uncle ha to move me . `` rafeeq and his sister rafeef , 15 , were severely injured when an israeli air strike hit their home , killing 11 member of the family , their uncle mahmoud said . among the dead were their mother , four other sibling and their niece and nephew . rafeeq wa already suffering from malnutrition , he said , before the strike that wounded him . `` we could not find any kind of fruit to eat , no apple , no guava , there wa no meat and any food at the market wa all too expensive , `` he said . rafeef , whose leg wa shattered by the strike and pinned together , said she had asked the hospital staff for any kind of fruit or vegetable for him to eat , `` but they can not provide any `` . ramadan used to be a time of pure joy , rafeef said , `` heaven compared to now `` . `` it really wa beautiful , `` she said . `` but these time will not come back . the best people in our life have disappeared . `` the doctor at al-shifa have transferred many child malnutrition patient further north to kamal adwan hospital , because it ha better paediatric facility , but child have died there in high number too . dr hussam abu safiya , the head of paediatrics at kamal adwan , said that 21 child had died at the hospital from malnutrition or dehydration in the past four week , and there were currently 10 child in an acute condition . `` i feel helpless to save these child and it is a hard and shameful feeling , `` dr safiya said . `` i have the same feeling for my staff , who can not find enough food for themselves and some day do not eat . `` israel wa waging a `` war by starvation , `` he said . `` intentionally depriving child of food , killing them with hunger - there is no law in the world that allows occupier to do this . `` the eu 's foreign policy chief josep borrell ha also accused israel of intentionally starving gazans . `` in gaza we are no longer on the brink of famine , we are in a state of famine , `` he said on monday . `` this is unacceptable . starvation is used a a weapon of war . israel is provoking famine . `` israel denies it is intentionally starving gazans . it ha blamed the un , which it say ha created logistical challenge around aid delivery , a well a hamas , which israel say ha commandeered aid . the israeli prime minister , benjamin netanyahu , denied last , `` said abeer etefa , the world food programme 's senior spokesperson for the middle east . `` 1.1 million under the ipc phase 5 - that 's catastrophic hunger . and more than a third of child under coast of gaza , constructed by the charity from the rubble of destroyed building . it is hoped that it will alleviate the severe shortage in north and central gaza , and bring some relief during the remainder of ramadan . but the charitable aid operation ha led to accusation against israel that it ha abandoned it humanitarian responsibility to the civilian population , leaving it up to charity rubble . they had scrounged a small amount of fresh food for the evening meal . on some previous day , there had been none . `` the situation for u now , in the gaza strip , it make me envy the dead , `` near-complete lack of access `` to most of gaza . the international rescue committee ( irc ) said drought and crop failure caused by extreme weather event a a result of climate change were leading to widespread food shortage , particularly in east africa . el niño - a climate pattern that describes the unusual warming of surface water in the pacific ocean - ha already impacted food supply in southeast asia and latin america . the declaration of famine doe not unlock specific funding . however , it often trigger a large international response from other un agency and international government , who can provide food supply and emergency funding . some humanitarian agency like the irc provide malnutrition treatment . oxfam ha worked with partner in gaza to distribute voucher and cash for food and hygiene item . the wfp is working in sudan to restore infrastructure like road and school . it also ha mobile response team that travel to remote area to deliver food and other assistance . many agency typically start to plan and deliver aid before a famine ha been declared in order to avoid the worst effect - usually when a country ha been given a phase three classification or above . the last time famine wa officially declared wa in south sudan in 2017 . nearly 80,000 people faced starvation and another million were on the brink of famine after three year of civil war . at the time , the un blamed the effect of war on agriculture . farmer lost livestock , crop production wa severely curtailed , and inflation soared . previous famine include southern somalia in 2011 , southern sudan in 2008 , gode in the somali region of ethiopia in 2000 , north korea in 1996 , somalia in 1991-1992 and ethiopia in 1984-1985 . between 1845 and 1852 , ireland suffered a period of starvation , disease and emigration that became known a the great famine . about one million people are thought to have died when the country 's potato crop - which fed a third of the population - wa destroyed by disease . food export continued to great britain , which ruled the island of ireland at the time .

strike . earlier , israel 's military said it had killed 90 gunman there since monday . separately , indirect negotiation between israel and hamas are continuing in qatar to bring about a ceasefire and the release of hostage . but there are few sign that a breakthrough is imminent . mr blinken 's sixth trip to the region since the start of the war in gaza saw him land in jeddah on wednesday afternoon to meet the saudi leadership . descending from the plane shortly before sundown he wa greeted by waiting official , including mazin al-himali from the saudi foreign ministry , who embraced mr blinken . he is expected to meet the saudi crown prince , mohammed bin salman , at the royal palace on wednesday night . state department spokesman matthew miller said they would discus effort to reach a ceasefire agreement and increase aid delivery to gaza , amid further dire warning about the scale of the humanitarian crisis there . a un-backed food security assessment this week said 1.1 million people in gaza were struggling with catastrophic hunger and starvation , adding that a man-made famine in the north wa imminent between now and may . also on the agenda would be `` co-ordination on post-conflict planning for gaza , including ensuring hamas can no longer govern or repeat the attack of 7 october , a political path for the palestinian people with security assurance with israel , and an architecture for lasting peace and security in the region `` , mr miller added . mr blinken will travel to cairo on thursday to meet egyptian leader . the american are trying to bring together a major deal that would put the internationally-recognised palestinian authority ( pa ) back into gaza for the first time since it wa driven out by hamas 17 year ago . nothing ha yet been drawn up , but the idea are thought to include possible support on the ground from arab nation , while all the party including israel would commit to pursuing a two-state solution - the long-held international formula for peace . the major arab sponsor saudi arabia would normalise relation with israel in return for access to advanced u weapon and an american-backed civilian nuclear power programme . however , even if such a multi-part plan could be agreed , u official concede it is likely only attainable in the longer term . meanwhile , israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu ha repeatedly rejected the idea of pa control of gaza . the issue is likely to be another sticking point amid an already fractious relationship with president biden . some of those familiar with the plan israeli military 's operation there continued for a third day . witness told the bbc that tank previously positioned around the hospital complex had now moved eastward , along al-wahda street . they also reported a significant increase in the number of air strike in gaza city and other northern area . `` the relentless sound of explosion can be heard from around al-shifa hospital , `` said osama tawfiq , who life 700m ( 2,300ft ) from the complex . `` since monday morning , we feel like a if the war ha just begun . `` according to the witness , the strike targeted home belonging to member of hamas who had been assigned to serve on so-called `` emergency committee `` in place of the armed group 's police force . among them wa amjad hathat , who wa reportedly killed along with 11 other emergency committee member at the kuwait roundabout in gaza city on tuesday evening while securing the distribution of humanitarian aid . mr tawfiq said that the situation had deteriorated in his area between now and may . on wednesday morning , the israeli military said it troop had killed approximately 90 gunman and questioned 300 suspect during what it called the `` precise operation `` in and around al-shifa . they first raided the hospital in november , when the military accused it of being a hamas `` command and control centre `` - an allegation that hamas and hospital official denied . the military said the latest operation wa launched on monday because `` senior hamas terrorist have regrouped inside . . . and are using it to command attack against israel `` . hamas acknowledged a senior commander of it internal security force wa killed there on monday , but said he wa co-ordinating aid delivery . it said the other people killed were patient and displaced civilian sheltering there . the military said it wa taking measure to avoid harm to civilian and keep the hospital functioning , but witness told bbc arabic 's gaza today programme that that the situation there wa the lack of medicine and painkiller , `` one displaced woman , who asked not to be named , said on tuesday . `` the bulldozer are sweeping away the place where we are staying , and shrapnel is flying Body Text: israel 's english-language government spokesman eylon levy ha been suspended , the bbc ha confirmed . the israeli prime minister 's office ha not given a reason . but it is understood that the decision is linked to a recent online row with the uk foreign secretary , lord cameron . mr levy ha so far not commented . on 8 march , he wrote a now-deleted post on x responding to another one from lord cameron that urged israel `` to allow more [ aid ] truck into gaza `` . `` i hope you are also aware there are no limit on the entry of food , water , medicine , or shelter equipment into gaza , and in fact the crossing have excess capacity , `` mr levy replied . `` test u . send another 100 truck a day to kerem shalom and we 'll get them in , `` he added , referring to an israeli-controlled border crossing . two day earlier , he had written another post criticising a statement issued by lord cameron after a meeting with an israeli minister in london . israel 's channel 12 news reported on tuesday that mr levy wa suspended shortly after the uk foreign office wrote to israel 's foreign ministry to express it `` surprise `` and seek clarification on whether mr levy 's post represented the israeli government 's official position . the financial time cited a person familiar with the matter a characterising the british query a : `` is this the way ally speak to each other ? `` on thursday , the bbc confirmed israeli medium report saying that the prime minister 's office had suspended mr levy . there wa no immediate response from mr levy . but he described himself a an israeli government spokesman in several post on x on tuesday . mr levy , who is in his 30 , wa born in the uk and emigrated to israel in 2014 . he served in cogat , the israeli defence ministry body that oversees policy for the palestinian territory , worked a a tv news anchor and wa most recently international medium adviser to president isaac herzog . he rose to international prominence after becoming a government spokesperson following hamas 's 7 october attack on israel and the start of the war in gaza , and frequently being interviewed by english-language broadcaster , including the bbc . on tuesday , israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu reportedly made critical remark about israel 's english-language public diplomacy during a closed-door meeting with two parliamentary committee . channel 12 quoted him a saying : `` there simply are no people . you are surrounded by people who ca n't put two word together [ in english ] . `` in response to that report , his office said he `` deeply value the work of his team and of the public diplomacy directorate that operates under him `` .

palestinian-led governing authority `` . israeli medium have suggested the operation at shifa hospital could last for several day . it is not being linked to the military operation in rafah which of gaza are now displaced there . `` it 's going to happen . and it will happen even if israel is forced to fight alone , `` the israeli strategic affair minister , ron dermer , told the call me back with dan senor podcast . while the idf ha formulated operational plan for rafah and handed these to israel 's government , no order ha yet been given to execute them . it is seen a unlikely that such trying to work out schedule `` . the news come a the relationship between israeli leader and leading u democrat ha grown tense . top senate democrat chuck schumer ha called for israeli voter to replace mr netanyahu , who he ha deemed a barrier to peace talk in gaza . `` i would love to have him come in and address a joint session of congress , `` mr johnson told the network on thursday . `` we 'll certainly extend that invitation . `` he added that he had personally been invited to address israeli lawmaker in the knesset , calling it a `` great honour `` . mr schumer , who is jewish and a supporter of israel , delivered a 40-minute speech on the senate floor last week calling for israel to hold new election to replace mr netanyahu . he criticised mr netanyahu and his conservative government for his handling of the war in gaza , saying he `` ha lost his way `` and argued that he stand in the way of peace between israeli and palestinian . mr johnson on thursday criticised him for those remark . `` to suggest to our strongest ally in the middle east , the only stable democracy , that he know better how to run their democracy is just patently absurd , `` he said . in response to mr johnson , mr schumer 's office released a statement saying he did not object to an address by mr netanyahu . `` israel ha no stronger ally than the united state and our relationship transcends any one president or any one prime minister , `` mr schumer said . `` i will always welcome the opportunity for the prime minister of israel to speak to congress in a bipartisan way . `` mr johnson 's comment on the invitation come a day after mr netanyahu delivered remark behind closed door to republican in the senate . mr schumer turned down a request from mr netanyahu to speak to senate democrat , saying any address should be done in a bipartisan fashion . mr netanyahu last spoke to the u congress in 2015 , when both chamber were controlled by republican . he used the opportunity to criticise then president barack obama , a democrat , for pursuing a deal with u ally and iran to curtail that country 's nuclear programme . mr netanyahu 's possible address also come a an aid bill for israel appears to have stalled in congress and a israel prepares for an operation in rafah , a city in southern gaza that palestinian refugee have fled to . an israeli delegation is due to visit washington to discus the planned assault next week , according to u official . they were invited by president joe biden , who ha attempted to discourage israel from going through with the operation , in a recent call with mr netanyahu . mr biden , who is running for re-election in november , ha come under political pressure from his party 's left wing to do more to convince israel to limit it war in gaza , which began when hamas gunman stormed into southern israel on 7 october , killing about 1,200 people and taking more than 250 others hostage . more than 31,000 palestinian have an aid bill for israel appears to have stalled in congress and a israel prepares for an operation in rafah , a city in southern gaza that palestinian refugee have fled to . an israeli delegation is Body Text: russia and china have blocked a u draft resolution put to the un which for the first time called for a ceasefire and hostage release in gaza . while there have been previous attempt by other country to call for a ceasefire , the u text marked a hardening of it stance towards israel . but russia and china used their veto . moscow called the text `` hypocritical `` . the move by the u , israel 's key ally , come at a time of growing tension between them . washington ha made clear that it expects israel to lessen the intensity of it offensive in gaza , where the hamas-run health ministry say at least 31,988 people - mainly woman and child - have been killed since the war began on 7 october . it ha also said it would not support an israeli attack on the city of rafah without a plan to protect civilian there , and ha urged israel to allow more humanitarian aid into gaza . israel 's prime minister , benjamin netanyahu , ha said that israel will go ahead with a planned ground assault on rafah , even without the support of it key ally . the u secretary of state , antony blinken , in tel aviv for talk , said such an operation wa not the answer . `` it risk killing more civilian , it risk wreaking greater havoc with the provision of humanitarian assistance , it risk further isolating israel around the world and jeopardising this long-term security and standing , `` he said . the u - one of five permanent member of the security council with the power of veto - ha previously blocked resolution calling for a ceasefire , saying such a move would be wrong while delicate negotiation for a truce and hostage release were continuing between israel and hamas . but on friday it publicly changed it position , in a carefully-worded draft . `` the security council , `` the text read , `` determines the imperative of an immediate and sustained ceasefire `` , adding `` and towards that end unequivocally support ongoing international diplomatic effort to secure such a ceasefire in connection with the release of all remaining hostage `` . in doing so , the u linked it support for a ceasefire to the release of the israeli hostage - 253 - held by hamas . although russia and china vetoed the draft , 11 country on the 15-member council voted in favour of it . algeria voted against it and guyana abstained . early on saturday , a vote on a new text calling for a ceasefire wa postponed until monday , diplomat told the afp and reuters news agency . before friday 's vote , russia 's ambassador to the un , vassily nebenzia , criticised the text a `` exceedingly politicised `` , accusing it of doing nothing to avert israel 's planned assault on rafah . more than half of gaza 's 2.3 million palestinian are sheltering in the southern city , where israel say hamas leader are hiding and hamas battalion still operate . the u ambassador to the un , linda thomas-greenfield , called russia and china 's action `` deeply , deeply cynical `` . `` russia and china simply did not want to vote for a resolution that wa penned by the united state , because it would rather see u fail than see this council succeed , `` she said . speaking after talk with mr netanyahu , mr blinken said the u wa trying to show the international community `` a sense of urgency `` . a ceasefire tied to the release of hostage , he said , wa `` something that everyone , including the country that veto the resolution should have been able to get behind `` . french president emmanuel macron said his country would now work on an alternative resolution . `` what 's important to note is that the united state ha changed it position , and shown it will to defend , very clearly now , a ceasefire , `` mr macron said . `` for a long time , the american were reticent . that reticence is now gone . ``
