Body Text: the israeli military 's intelligence chief ha resigned , saying he took responsibility for the failure before hamas 's attack on israel on 7 october . the israel defense force ( idf ) said major general aharon haliva would retire once his successor wa selected . he acknowledged in a letter that his intelligence directorate `` did not live up to the task we were entrusted with `` . he is the first senior figure to step down over the attack , which wa the deadliest in israel 's history . israeli military and intelligence official missed or ignored multiple warning before hundred of hamas gunman breached the gaza border fence that day and attacked nearby israeli community , military base and a music festival . about 1,200 israeli and foreigner - mostly civilian - were killed and 253 others were taken back to gaza a hostage , according to israeli tally . israel responded by launching it most intense ever war in gaza with the aim of destroying hamas and freeing the hostage . more than 34,000 palestinian in gaza - most of them child and woman - have been killed in the conflict , the territory 's hamas-run health ministry say . a statement put out by the idf on monday said maj gen haliva had `` requested to end his position , following his leadership responsibility a the head of the intelligence directorate for the event of 7 october `` . in his resignation letter , the general wrote : `` i carry that black day with me ever since , day after day , night after night . i will carry the horrible pain of the war with me forever . `` he also called for the establishment of a state commission of inquiry `` that can investigate and find out in a thorough , in-depth , comprehensive and precise manner all the factor and circumstance that led to the difficult event `` . `` everything i did during my service in the idf wa for the sake of the people of israel and the state of israel , `` he added . maj gen haliva 's resignation had been anticipated , given that he had stated 10 day after the attack that he bore full responsibility for the intelligence failure of his directorate . however , his departure is expected to be followed by further resignation among israel 's senior military and intelligence commander , with other official having admitted error and oversight in the run-up to 7 october . the idf 's chief of staff , lt gen herzi halevi , and the director of the shin bet security service , ronen bar , have both taken responsibility for failing to protect israeli but decided to stay on for the war in gaza . monday 's news may also add to the pressure on the veteran israeli prime minister , benjamin netanyahu . up to now , mr netanyahu ha said only that he will answer tough question about his own role , without acknowledging any responsibility , and ha sought to deflect blame onto his security chief . he ha said that a full inquiry should wait until the war in gaza is over . opposition leader yair lapid said on x ( formerly twitter ) that maj gen haliva 's decision to resign wa `` justified and honourable `` , but added that mr netanyahu `` should have done the same `` . in a video statement on sunday , the prime minister lamented that the 133 people still held in gaza would not be around the seder table with their loved one for the jewish festival of passover . `` their suffering and the suffering of their family rends our heart and only strengthens our resolve to bring them back , `` he said . he claimed that hamas had `` hardened it condition `` for a hostage release deal and threatened to `` strike it with additional painful blow `` in response . `` in the coming day , we will increase the military and diplomatic pressure on hamas because this is the only way to free our hostage and achieve our victory , `` he added . mr netanyahu did not specify the next step , but he ha repeatedly said that israeli force intend to launch an operation in the southern city of rafah . the u and un have warned an all-out assault on rafah , where 1.5 million displaced palestinian are sheltering , could have catastrophic consequence .

Body Text: a un report into the palestinian refugee agency unrwa ha concluded it must do more to improve it neutrality , staff vetting and transparency . but the independent review also said that israel had failed to back up a claim that many of the agency 's staff belonged to terror group . some of unrwa 's staff were accused by israel of involvement in the 7 october attack and of being hamas member . this led several country to halt funding to the humanitarian agency . the new report say israel ha not yet provided `` supporting evidence `` for it allegation . however it add that the agency 's monitoring process need to improve , and that neutrality-related issue persist despite the fact that the organisation ha a `` robust framework `` . the israeli authority have rejected the finding , claiming the report ignores the severity of the problem . they say the problem with the agency is not `` that of a few bad apple : it is a rotten and poisonous tree whose root are hamas `` . israel initially alleged that 12 unrwa staff took part in the hamas attack on southern israel , which saw 1,200 people killed and about 250 taken hostage . unrwa fired the 10 of those employee who were still alive and a separate investigation by the un 's office of internal oversight into those allegation is ongoing . monday 's report look at the other israeli claim that large number of unrwa staff are member of terror group or have family member who are . israel ha said more than 2,135 employee of the agency - of a total of 13,000 in gaza - are member of hamas or palestinian islamic jihad , proscribed a terrorist organisation by israel , the uk , u and others . it ha also suggested a fifth of unrwa school administrator are hamas member . unrwa insists it carry out detailed reference check on all staff , and share staff list with all host state including israel . this new report say israel is yet to provide supporting evidence for it claim . but it is not a glowing endorsement of the agency . led by former french foreign minister catherine colonna , and supported by three european research institute , it find that unrwa could do better upholding the obligatory humanitarian principle of neutrality and impartiality . it point to staff vetting system that could be improved - but add that for this to happen , there need to be better cooperation with and from israeli and palestinian authority . israel already receives list of unrwa staff for it own vetting purpose on a regular basis . the report also highlight how challenging - even dangerous - unrwa 's working environment is . violence is common , opinion are polarised , and although unrwa 's system are described a more rigorous than many other agency , the report suggests they are often hampered by low staffing and security concern . the un chief and head of unrwa have accepted the report 's finding in full , and pledged to implement all it recommendation . although several donor including japan , sweden , finland , canada and the eu have resumed funding to unrwa , the u and uk have not . the un will be hoping this report will encourage them to restore their financial support . but some donor may want to wait for the other un investigation that specifically look at allegation that 12 unrwa staff actually took part in the 7 october attack , before restoring cash to an organisation today 's report described , despite it need for improvement , a `` irreplaceable and indispensable to palestinian ' human and economic development `` .

Body Text: a few day after hamas attacked israel and war erupted in gaza , umm mohamed in the occupied west bank received a telephone call from her son in an israeli prison . `` pray for me mum , `` abdulrahman mari said . `` thing are getting harder here . they might not let me speak to you again `` . it would be the last time she heard his voice . condition deteriorated for palestinian prisoner in israel after 7 october last year , when hamas mounted it deadly assault on israeli community near the gaza strip , according to the west bank-based palestinian authority 's ( pa ) commission of detainee affair . thirteen palestinian prisoner have since died in israeli prison , `` the majority of them a a result of beating or denial of medication `` , the commission 's head , qadoura fare , told the bbc . abdulrahman wa one of the first to die . a carpenter in the village of qarawat ban hassan , he had been on his way back home from work in ramallah in february last year when he wa arrested at a mobile checkpoint . he wa taken into administrative detention - under which israel can hold people indefinitely without charge - in megiddo prison . his brother ibrahim said the charge against him were minor , such a taking part in protest and possessing a firearm , but said he wa also accused of belonging to hamas although there were no specific charge about any activity within the group . ibrahim is still trying to piece together how exactly his brother died . he ha to rely on testimony from abdulrahman 's former cellmates , a well a report from court hearing . one former cellmate , who spoke to the bbc on condition of anonymity , said : `` after 7 october , it wa total torture . they beat u for no reason , they searched u for no reason . even if you look at someone the wrong way . `` he described having seen abdulrahman heavily beaten in front of him and others . `` at 9am , they came into our cell , and began to beat u . one of the guard began to insult abdulrahman 's parent , which he did n't stand for , and he began to fight back . `` they beat him badly , and took him away to another cell upstairs for a week . during that time you could hear him cry out in pain . `` he said he had only found out about abdulrahman 's death after he left prison a week later . the israeli prison service did not directly address the bbc 's question about abdulrahman 's death or those of the 12 other named palestinian that the commission of detainee affair say have died , saying only : `` we are not familiar with the claim described and a far a we know they are not true . `` professor danny rosin , a doctor from the group physician for human right , attended the examination of abdulrahman mari 's body . his remark corroborate what abdulrahman 's cellmate and brother told the bbc . prof rosin 's report mentioned that bruise had been seen over abdulrahman 's left chest , and that he had several broken rib . external bruise were also seen on the back , buttock , left arm and thigh , a well a the right side of the head and neck with no fracture underneath . it also quoted an additional police report which had mentioned `` forceful restraint `` being used on mr mari six day before his death . professor rosin said in the report that while no specific cause of death had been found , `` one may assume that the violence he suffered manifested by the multiple bruise and multiple severe rib fracture contributed to his death `` . he also added that `` irregular pulse `` or a `` heart attack `` could result from these injury without leaving any physical evidence . israel currently hold more than 9,300 security prisoner , the vast majority of whom are palestinian according to the israeli right group hamoked , including more than 3,600 people in administrative detention . these figure do not include detainee from the gaza strip being held in separate facility by the israeli military . mr qadoura say the change after 7 october `` affected every aspect of the prisoner ' life `` , alleging that prisoner have been subjected to starvation and thirst and some of those with chronic illness were denied their medication . beating became more regular and more brutal . `` i met a detainee who 'd lost 20kg in the last three month , `` he said . `` it 's a if the war on gaza wa also a war on palestinian prisoner . it wa all a form of revenge . `` the bbc ha previously heard from palestinian prisoner who described being hit with stick , having muzzled dog set on them and having their clothes , food and blanket taken away in the week after 7 october . the israeli prison service ha denied any mistreatment , saying that `` all prisoner are held in accordance with the law while respecting their basic right and under the supervision of a professional and skilled prison staff `` . it said prison had gone into `` emergency mode `` after war broke out and it had been `` decided to reduce the living condition of the security prisoner `` . example it gave included removing electrical equipment and cutting electricity to cell and reducing prisoner ' activity in the wing . in the west bank village of beit sira , arafat hamdan 's father showed where israeli police officer had kicked the door of his family home and stormed in at 04:00 on 22 october looking for his son . police covered his son 's face with a thick black cloth and closed it around his neck with a rope . the mask smelled strongly , he said , and arafat clearly had a hard time breathing with it on . `` i kept trying to comfort him . `` yasser hamdan told the bbc . `` it 's ok . they have nothing against you . they have nothing against u . i kept telling him that a they tied him up outside the house . then they took him . `` two day later a phone call came . arafat had been found dead in his cell in ofer prison in the west bank . israeli authority have not explained how he died . arafat had type 1 diabetes and would suffer from low blood sugar level from time to time . his father said one of the police officer arresting arafat had told him to bring medicine with him , but it wa unclear if he had been able to . the bbc obtained a report by dr daniel solomon , a surgeon who wa present at the post mortem of arafat hamdan at the request of physician for human right . dr solomon said it had been carried out in israel on 31 october but added that the condition of the body , due to prolonged refrigeration , had made it harder to determine the cause of death . he also noted the absence of any record showing if arafat 's diabetes medication had been administered and at what dosing . the report also mentioned the need for other test beyond the post mortem to determine the cause of death . `` until now we do n't know how he died . nothing is clear . `` yasser hamdan said . neither arafat 's nor abdulrahman 's body have yet been returned . their family want to arrange their own post mortems , hold funeral , and say a final goodbye . `` he wa my flesh and blood . then he wa gone in a moment , `` yasser hamdan said . photo of his son were everywhere you looked in his apartment . umm mohamed showed photo of abdulrahman on her phone , pointing to one and saying : `` look at him . he wa so cheerful . `` over time he had become a leader in his group of prisoner , she said . `` he 'd call me when he wa making breakfast for them when they were all still asleep . he wa always the most active . he would never sit still , that boy . `` she broke down . `` bring him back to me . i want to see him one last time . one last look . ``

Body Text: a man accused of wearing a headband in support of hamas told police it wa a `` statement of faith `` , a court heard . khaled hajsaad , 24 , wore the clothing at a pro-palestine rally in central london where he wa arrested by police , the prosecution said . city of london magistrate ' court ha previously been told the headband had the `` shahada `` written on it , the basic statement of the islamic faith . mr hajsaad denies a charge of appearing to support a terrorist group . a transcript of a police interview with mr hajsaad , conducted the day after he wa arrested , wa read out in court . the defendant told officer he wa wearing a headband with a saudi arabian flag . `` i wa supporting palestine and i wa wearing an item of saudi arabia , `` the court heard . `` this is a shahada , which is a statement of faith . `` i wa wearing it because i am a muslim and this is my statement of faith . `` mr hajsaad , described a an asylum seeker who arrived in the uk a year ago , said : `` i do n't care about ( hamas ) . i do n't support ( the group ) and i have never supported ( them ) . `` i came here to live in safety . `` he is accused of wearing the clothing at trafalgar square on 25 november `` in such a way or in such circumstance a to arouse reasonable suspicion `` he wa supporting hamas - an illegal act in the uk where it is designated a terrorist group . expert called to attend the court were split on the headband 's likeness to either the flag of hamas or saudi arabia . the trial continues . listen to the best of bbc radio london on sound and follow bbc london on facebook , x and instagram . send your story idea to hello.bbclondon @ bbc.co.uk

family said they would keep fighting for the men 's return . they also urged the israeli government to secure a new hostage release deal . the new video come a hamas said it wa studying israel 's latest proposal for a truce . medium report said mediator egypt had sent a delegation to israel to give fresh impetus to stalled negotiation . such a deal that included an agreement to free the remaining hostage could stop israel 's planned ground assault in the southern city of rafah , israel 's foreign minister said on saturday . mr siegel , a u citizen , wa kidnapped with his wife aviva , how the couple had at one point been left in a tunnel by their captor a they were moved from place to place . at the time of the interview , she said she did not know if keith wa still alive . his daughter ilan said : `` seeing my father today only emphasis to all of u how much we must reach a deal a soon a possible and bring everyone home . i demand that the leader of this country watch this he wa visibly emotional a he delivered a powerful speech , describing his excitement seeing the video of his son , knowing that `` he wa hopefully alive `` . but his speech also had a political element . he talked directly to the government and specifically by name mentioned it far-right member - national security minister , itamar ben gvir and finance minister , bezalel smotrich , calling on them to secure a hostage deal . he urged israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu to `` approve any viable deal `` . `` take one small and bloodless step for both people , `` he said , adding : `` all the people of israel and the nation of the world want to see an end to the bloodshed and especially an end to the suffering of your people . `` what wa also notable wa that before omri 's father made his speech , the hostage video wa shown in full on big screen around hostage square . this is highly unusual , a such video are not generally played on tv . the hostage family forum headquarters said the latest video wa `` the clearest evidence that the israeli government must do everything to approve a deal for the return of all the hostage `` . it follows another proof-of-life video the insisted that any deal should include a permanent end to the war , full israeli military withdrawal from gaza and unrestricted return of displaced people to their home . israel insists it must destroy Body Text: news in the middle east move fast . one moment it is all about unprecedented missile and drone attack between iran and israel . the next the headline return to the fighting and suffering in gaza . but policymakers , analyst and military leader are still absorbing the extraordinary exchange of fire just day ago between two old adversary , one that arguably came a small technological failure away from triggering a devastating international conflict . it is worth considering how close they came to the edge and how deep the abyss that lay before them . this wa the first time iran and israel had attacked each other directly . some analyst say the iranian attack wa the largest combined missile and drone assault ever - bigger than anything russia ha levelled against ukraine . it wa certainly the first external bombardment of israel since saddam hussein 's scud missile in 1991 . most of the 300-plus iranian drone and missile were shot down or failed en route . but i watched from our office in jerusalem a the night sky wa lit up by israeli air defence trying to bring down the ballistic missile flying overhead . all it would have taken is for one gps guidance system to fail for a missile to land in an urban area at huge civilian cost . `` i do n't think people realise how close we were that weekend , `` one senior western security official told me . `` it could have been a very different story . `` yet some in the west think positive can be drawn from the attack on 13 april and israel 's limited retaliation last week . they argue it wa a huge intelligence success to predict the iranian strike , that the defence of israel wa an outstanding example of allied military cooperation , and that both iran and israel learned how to climb down the escalatory ladder . let 's take the intelligence operation first . i am told the u learned about iran 's plan on the wednesday morning before the attack on saturday evening . and crucially , they discovered the scale of iran 's ambition . `` we got wind that iran 's response would be at the top end of expectation , `` said one high-level western source . `` and that wa a bit of a shock . but it helped galvanise the international response . `` crucially , it helped the u persuade some country in the gulf to join in israel 's defence , including jordan and saudi arabia . their fear - once they were aware of the scale of iran 's plan - wa the risk of an escalatory regional war if israel had no choice but to retaliate hard . so a mixture of good intelligence gathering and private iranian signalling ( which the u denies took place ) gave israel and it ally time to prepare . the role played by jordan and saudi arabia are still not fully clear . jordan ha admitted shooting down iranian drone in self-defence to protect it sovereignty . it is understood jordan also allowed israeli warplane some access to it airspace . the saudi are thought to have provided information to the u and kept an eye on any threat from iranian-backed armed group in yemen . the key point is it worked . the u , british , french , jordanian and saudi military showed they could operate together on collective air defence . `` it wa an extraordinarily successful tactical operation , `` said the security source . `` the intelligence cued it up , we had sight of the whole area and we worked together . no other group of nation can do that in the world . `` some have also argued this could be the start of a new regional alliance against iran . to others , though , that is a typical security and military perspective , one that celebrates technological success while missing the bigger political picture . the more pessimistic analyst argue that if iran wanted to inflict significant damage on israel , it could have refrained from giving advance warning , broadened it target , launched a second wave of attack - or even ordered hezbollah to mount a large attack from lebanon . emile hokayem from the international institute for strategic study think tank said the operation revealed how much israel had to rely on ally for it defence . he also wondered whether israel would have enough air defence missile needed for a higher intensity conflict . `` a we 've seen in the war between ukraine and russia , it matter how much of the good stuff you have in stock , `` he said . mr hokayem also dismissed the idea this crisis marked the beginning of a new regional military alliance . `` we 're not at the cusp of a new era , `` he said . `` arab state have cooperated because primarily they want to avoid a regional confrontation . and they want to demonstrate they 're good partner to their western ally . it 's also simply a matter of national sovereignty . they do n't want stuff flying and exploding in their sky . `` the second claim by optimist is that iran and israel have learned from this experience . they say both country - for once - communicated their intention accurately ; they realised they could de-escalate without losing face ; and they both had a scare that will re-establish mutual deterrence . iran may have attacked israel but it warned ally of it intent and signalled early it wa a one-off . israel showed it could retaliate modestly , targeting air defence in central iran and using a small attack to signal a bigger capability , namely that it could hit iran where and when it wanted . i am told iran may even have been tipped off about israel 's retaliation . certainly iran signalled from a very early stage it did not intend to respond to israel 's counter-attack . both side certainly will have learned military lesson . `` the attack probably helped iran identify the relative strength and the weakness of the israeli air defence system , `` said the institute for the study of war . israel and the u will also have a greater understanding of iran 's tactical strategy . the counter-argument is that both iran and israel broke a taboo , that direct attack is now an easier option . in an essay for foreign affair , afshon ostovar from the foreign policy research institute say the scale of iran 's attack show it is no longer convinced by a policy of restraint . `` the notion that iran intentionally launched a weak attack doe not stand up to scrutiny , `` he writes . `` iran hoped to land an impressive blow against israel . `` mr hokayem challenge the idea iran and israel have learned to understand each other . he cite israel 's failure to realise the consequence of it decision to kill several elite iranian revolutionary guard corp ( irgc ) commander in iran 's consulate in damascus . `` these two country do n't talk to each other . instead , they just signal through military posturing and third party . these thing can go badly quite quickly . wrongly reading the other side 's intention - or risk appetite - is a feature rather than a bug in the relationship . `` there is also scepticism either side have re-established deterrence . amos harel , defence analyst for the israeli newspaper haaretz , said : `` the two country breached the previous rule of the game , with limited costsâ_x0080_ ¦ the balance of deterrence between the two country ( is ) unsettled . `` perhaps the key lesson learned by many in this crisis wa just how close the region had come to full scale war . `` it wa just a huge relief , `` one western diplomat told me . `` it could have gone so differently . ``

for once - communicated their intention accurately ; they realised they could de-escalate without losing face ; and they both had a scare that will re-establish mutual deterrence . iran may have attacked israel but it warned ally of it intent and signalled early it wa a one-off . israel showed it could retaliate modestly , targeting air defence in central iran and using a small attack to signal a bigger capability , namely that it could hit iran where and when it wanted . i am told iran may even have been tipped off about israel 's retaliation . certainly iran signalled from a very early stage it did not intend to respond to israel 's counter-attack . both side certainly will have learned military lesson . `` the attack probably helped iran identify the relative strength and the weakness of the israeli air defence system , `` said the institute for the study of war . israel and the u will also have a greater understanding of iran 's tactical strategy . the counter-argument is that both iran and israel broke a taboo , that direct attack is now an easier option . in an essay for foreign affair , afshon ostovar from the foreign policy research institute say the scale of iran 's attack show it is no longer convinced by a policy of restraint . `` the notion that iran intentionally launched a weak attack doe not stand up to scrutiny , `` he writes . `` iran hoped to land an impressive blow against israel . `` mr hokayem challenge the idea iran and israel have learned to understand each other . he cite israel 's failure to realise the consequence of it decision to kill several elite iranian revolutionary guard corp ( irgc ) commander in iran 's consulate in damascus . `` these two country do n't talk to each other . instead , they just signal through military posturing and third party . these thing can go badly quite quickly . wrongly reading the other side 's intention - or risk appetite - is a feature rather than a bug in the relationship . `` there is also scepticism either side have re-established deterrence . amos harel , defence analyst for the israeli newspaper haaretz , said : `` the two country breached the previous rule of the game , with limited costsâ_x0080_ ¦ the balance of deterrence between the two country ( is ) unsettled . `` perhaps the key lesson learned by many in this crisis wa just how close the region had come to full scale war . `` it wa just a huge relief , `` one western diplomat told me . `` it could have gone so differently . ``

Body Text: iraq 's parliament ha passed a bill criminalising same-sex relationship with jail term of between 10 and 15 year . transgender people could also be sent to prison for between one and three year under the new law . supporter of the change say they will help to uphold religious value in the country . right group say they are a further black mark on iraq 's record of violation against lgbt people . those who promote homosexuality or prostitution , doctor who perform gender reassignment surgery , men who `` intentionally `` act like woman and those who engage in `` wife swapping `` will also face prison term under the new legislation . a previous draft of the bill - an amendment to an anti-prostitution law that wa passed in the late 1980s - had proposed capital punishment for same-sex relationship . however , this wa amended after facing opposition from the u and other western country . mp amir al-maamouri told shafaq news on saturday that the new law wa `` a significant step in combating sexual deviancy given the infiltration of unique case contradicting islamic and societal value `` . passing the bill had been postponed until after prime minister mohamed shia al-sudani 's visit to the u earlier this month , according to lawmaker raed al-maliki , who advanced the amendment . `` we did n't want to impact the visit , `` mr al-maliki told the afp news agency , adding that it wa `` an internal matter and we do not accept any interference in iraqi affair `` . lgbt people have long been targeted by the authority in iraq , with other morality law previously being used to punish them . human right watch and other human right organisation have also detailed several case of abduction , torture , rape and murder . major iraqi political party have in recent year stepped up criticism of lgbt right , with rainbow flag being burned at protest . the u state department said in a statement that the passing of the law reform were a threat to human right and freedom . `` the legislation also weakens iraq 's ability to diversify it economy and attract foreign investment , `` it added . `` international business coalition have already indicated that such discrimination in iraq will harm business and economic growth in the country . `` uk secretary of state lord david cameron , meanwhile , described the amendment a `` dangerous and worrying `` . `` no one should be targeted for who they are , `` he wrote on x , formerly twitter . `` we encourage the government of iraq to uphold human right and freedom of all people without distinction . ``

Body Text: palestinian president mahmoud abbas say the u is the only country that can stop israel from attacking rafah , the southern gaza city where more than a million people are taking refuge . mr abbas , who run part of the occupied west bank , said any attack could see palestinian flee gaza . israel ha consistently vowed to carry out an offensive in rafah . u president joe biden `` reiterated his clear position `` on rafah to israel pm benjamin netanyahu in a call on sunday . the u ha repeatedly said it can not support a large-scale israeli military operation in rafah without seeing a credible plan to keep civilian out of harm 's way . speaking at the world economic forum ( wef ) in the saudi capital riyadh earlier , mr abbas - whose palestinian authority is not present in gaza , which ha been under hamas rule since 2007 - urged the u to intervene . `` we appeal to the united state of america to ask israel to stop the rafah operation because america is the only country capable of preventing israel from committing this crime , `` he said , adding that only a `` small strike `` on rafah would force the palestinian population to flee the gaza strip . `` the biggest catastrophe in the palestinian people 's history would then happen . `` more than half of gaza 's population is in rafah and condition in the overcrowded southern city are already dire , with displaced people there telling the bbc there wa a lack of food , water and medication . while the white house did not elaborate on what specifically mr biden 's latest comment to mr netanyahu were regarding the planning offensive in rafah , national security spokesman john kirby told the abc network that israel had agreed to listen to u concern and thought before going in . u secretary of state antony blinken ha arrived in riyadh where he will hold talk with mr abbas at the start of a new middle east tour . meanwhile , the indirect negotiation between israel and hamas over a potential ceasefire and the release of remaining hostage in gaza , which have gained new momentum recently , have been further exposing division in israel 's governing coalition . war cabinet member and opposition figure benny gantz on sunday said that the current government `` would not have the right to continue to exist `` if a reasonable deal to return the hostage wa not accepted . `` entering rafah is important in the long struggle against hamas . the return of our abductees , is urgent and of far greater importance , `` mr gantz wrote on x , formerly twitter . the far-right finance minister bezalel smotrich , however , said the government should resign if it accepted a deal in which the planned offensive in rafah wa cancelled . their comment come after israel 's foreign minister said that the country could suspend the incursion , which mr netanyahu ha said is the next step in it battle against hamas , if there wa a hostage deal . the israeli military said it chief herzi halevi had approved plan to continue the war , with israeli medium saying this referred to the rafah operation . long-running talk mediated by egypt and qatar have largely stalled because of the gap between the israeli and hamas position , but on sunday hamas said it would send representative to cairo to give a response to the latest proposal . u medium have quoted unnamed egyptian official a saying the latest ceasefire proposal given to hamas involved a several-week period of calm intended to lead to the end of the war , in return for the release of 20 hostage . hamas want a permanent end to the war and withdrawal of all israeli troop from gaza , while israel insists hamas must be destroyed in gaza and all hostage freed . egypt and other arab state have previously said an influx of palestinian refugee fleeing the war would be unacceptable because it would amount to the expulsion of palestinian from their land . satellite picture have shown new tent encampment being built near the gaza coast , to the west of rafah and the city of khan younis slightly further north , which ha been left largely in ruin . medium report say the tent are to accommodate people displaced from rafah . the current war began when hamas attacked israeli community near gaza , killing about 1,200 people , mainly civilian , and taking about 250 hostage . some 133 hostage are believed still to be in gaza , of whom about 30 are thought to be dead , after a brief truce in november saw some hostage released . this week hamas 's armed wing released two video showing the first proof of life of three hostage since they were abducted last october . israel 's campaign of aerial bombardment and ground operation in gaza since 7 october ha killed 34,454 people , mostly civilian , according to the hamas-run health ministry there . over the six month of war , the israel defense force ( idf ) have entered and taken control of all of northern gaza including gaza city and most of central and southern gaza including khan younis . they have since withdrawn from almost all of those area but troop remain stationed on a road israel ha built that separate northern and southern gaza . however , palestinian displaced to southern gaza - where the israeli military told them to go for their own safety earlier in the war - have been unable to return to home further north , a key demand hamas is making in ceasefire talk , and israel ha given no indication when they will be allowed to . meanwhile , deadly israeli bombardment ha continued across gaza , including in rafah , with the israeli military saying it ha been striking launch site for projectile .

Body Text: sam attar reckons he left part of his soul in gaza . it wa the part of him that saw suffering and could not turn away . the part which now can not forget . you can be on the shore of lake michigan on an overcast spring day , the wind whipping up wave on the green water . and at the very same time you can be back there , in the heat and the dying . it 's been three week since he came home to chicago but it might a well have been yesterday . the face of that other world are with him : jenna , the traumatised little girl wasting away , spectral pale on a hospital bed , while her mother show sam a phone video of the child 's last birthday . happy day before the disaster . warning : this article contains detail and image some reader may find disturbing . another mother whose 10-year-old son had just died . `` the mom just told me with just a blank numb stare on her face that he had just died five minute prior . the staff had been trying to cover up his body with blanket but she just refused to let them . she wanted to spend more time with him . she wa grieving , she wa sobbing , and stayed that way for about a good 20 minute , she just did n't want to leave his side . `` then there wa the man in his 50 , forgotten in a room , having had both leg amputated . `` he had lost his kid , his grandkids , his home , `` sam recall , `` and he 's alone in the corner of this dark hospital , maggot going out of his wound and he wa screaming : ' the worm are eating me alive please help me . ' that wa just one just one out ofâ_x0080_ ¦ i do n't know , i just i stopped counting . but those are the people i still think of because they 're still there . `` sam is a sensitive , thoughtful man in his 40 , the son of two doctor , who wa born and raised in chicago and who work a a surgeon at northwestern hospital in the city . while in gaza he kept video diary and filmed his experience . for two week in march and april - on behalf of the ngo palestinian american bridge - he worked in gaza hospital that were desperately short of everything except badly-wounded patient . on the day he entered gaza this time around he wa immediately confronted with the hunger crisis . `` we were just swarmed by people banging on the car , some people trying to jump on the car . the driversâ_x0080_ ¦ they just got it . they do n't stop because if they stopped then people jump on the car . they 're not trying to harm u . they 're just begging for food . they 're starving . `` sam recount his experience calmly , a you might expect of a man trained to put patient at ease . every day there wa the relentless pressure of carrying out triage , deciding who could be saved , who wa beyond hope . patient lying on hospital floor surrounded by blood and discarded bandage , the air filled with the cry of pain and of grieving relative . there is no erasing such horror . even if you are a highly trained doctor with past experience of war zone like ukraine , syria and iraq . `` i still think of all the patient i took care of , `` he say , `` all the doctor that are still there . there 's a little bit of guilt and shame at leaving because there 's so much that need to be done . the need are overwhelming . and you walk away from people that are still there and still suffering . `` the last trip - his third into gaza since the war began - saw him join the first team of international medic to be embedded in a hospital in northern gaza where malnutrition is at it most acute . the mission wa organised by the world health organisation ( who ) which ha warned of looming famine . some 30 % of child below the age of two are reported to be acutely malnourished , and 70 % of the population in northern gaza is facing what the un call `` catastrophic hunger . `` last month the un human right chief , volker turk , accused israel of a potential war crime because of the food crisis in gaza . `` the extent of israel 's continued restriction on entry of aid into gaza , together with the manner in which it continues to conduct hostility , may amount to the use of starvation a a method of war , `` he said . israel denies this and ha blamed the un and aid agency for any slow or inadequate delivery of aid . the israeli government said un calculation on hunger were based on `` multiple factual and methodological flaw , some of them serious . `` the government ha said that it had tracked medium report that food market in gaza , including the north , had plentiful supply . `` we outright reject any allegation according to which israel is purposefully starving the civilian population in gaza , `` said a statement from cogat - coordinator of government activity in the territory . sam attar remembers the 32-year-old woman admitted suffering from severe malnutrition , with her son , and her mother and father in the room with her . she underwent cpr - attempt to resuscitate the heart - but could not be saved . `` i had to call it , `` sam say . the young mother lay on a bench , her left arm dangling towards the floor , eye gazing upward in the moment of death . across the room a nurse comforted her cry mother . there wa the little girl , jenna ayyad , aged seven , `` just skeleton and bone `` whose mother hoped to get to the south where better medical facility were available . jenna wa traumatised by the war and looked to be extremely malnourished . she suffers from cystic fibrosis , which make digestion more difficult . her condition ha been exacerbated by the condition of the war and she is also suffering from trauma . in footage taken by a bbc cameraman jenna seems lost and now only speaks to her mother . `` what can i do ? she ca n't be treated , `` said nisma ayyad . `` her mental state is very difficult . she doe n't talk at all whenever anyone talk to her . her situation is bad , and a a mom , i ca n't do anything . `` dr attar said that a his team packed up to return to southern gaza , jenna 's mother approached him . `` jenna 's mom came to me and wa saying , ' i thought we were coming with youâ_x0080_ ¦ what 's happening ? why are you going and we 're staying ? `` sam had to explain that the convoy south wa only approved for the delivery of fuel and food and not for carrying patient . but before leaving sam and his colleague filled in the necessary paper to have jenna transferred . it would take day but they would make sure the paperwork reached the right office . when sam went to speak with jenna 's mother , other mum noticed . `` the problem is it 's open , shared room , [ with ] maybe 10 patient in one room . so when all the other mom saw me talking to her , they all swarmed me . `` jenna wa transferred and is now being treated at the international medical corp hospital near rafah . according to un estimate last month the majority of those killed in the war have been woman and child : 13,000 child , functioning hospital that are left . the who say that only 10 of gaza 's 36 hospital are still functioning . traveling in gaza can be very dangerous for aid worker . witness the death of seven aid worker , including three briton , when the israeli military attacked their convoy with missile strike on 1 april . sam describes queuing for hour at israeli checkpoint . `` we often wait one to four hour depending on how long it take for the israeli to approve the passage because they are conducting military operation . `` the u doctor want to see a concerted push to get more aid into the north . `` the north just need more access , it need more food , more fuel , more water , the road need to be openedâ_x0080_ ¦ and there are so many patient that need to be evacuated from the north to the south and the problem is the south is also busy . i mean , the hospital here are exploding . `` he will go back . soon he hope . there are bond of friendship which call out to him . the paramedic nabil who sam saw every day , bringing in the wounded for treatment , until he himself became a victim who had to be pulled from the rubble by his colleague . he is alive but will not be able to leave gaza . the doctor whose daughter wa killed but who found the generosity to comfort a mother whose toddler son wa suffering from a brain injury caused by bomb shrapnel . and there are the patient and their family who see in the doctor , nurse and paramedic not just the possibility of practical help but the steady light of human decency in a place of terror and degradation . these are sam attar 's people . all of them . with additional reporting by alice doyard , annie duncanson , haneen abdeen , nik millard

need more food , more fuel , more water , the road need to be opened … and there are so many patient that need to be evacuated from the north to the south and the problem is the south is also busy . i mean , the hospital here are exploding . `` he will go back . soon he hope . there are bond of friendship which call out to him . the paramedic nabil who sam saw every day , bringing in the wounded for treatment , until he himself became a victim who had to be pulled from the rubble by his colleague . he is alive but will not be able to leave gaza . the doctor whose daughter wa killed but who found the generosity to comfort a mother whose toddler son wa suffering from a brain injury caused by bomb shrapnel . and there are the patient and their family who see in the doctor , nurse and paramedic not just the possibility of practical help but the steady light of human decency in a place of terror and degradation . these are sam attar 's people . all of them . with additional well a build a third high production kitchen in gaza . speaking on the fatal airstrike , the charity said it wa continuing to call for an impartial and international investigation into the death of the aid worker , which included three briton , a palestinian , australian , pole and us-canadian citizen . `` while we have no concrete assurance , we continue to seek answer and advocate for change with the goal of better protecting wck and all ngo worker serving selflessly in the worst humanitarian condition , `` m gore said . wck is one of the main supplier of desperately-needed aid into gaza Body Text: a green party candidate who shared anti-semitic material relating to the gaza conflict on social medium ha apologised , the party ha said.the party wa contacted by the government 's anti-semitism adviser , lord mann , over post by bristol candidate mohamed makawi and abdul malik from october 2023.one of the post showed part of a hamas press conference , while the other made false claim about the killing of israeli citizens.the green party said mr makawi had ha since apologised and undertaken social medium training , while mr malik wa `` unwittingly `` implicated by being tagged in the post . the post followed the hamas attack on 7 october , when wave of gunman stormed across gaza 's border into israel , killing about 1,200 people.mr malik told the bbc he did not put up the post showing hamas spokesman and said he completely condemns the attack on israel.mr makawi ha also been approached for comment.meanwhile lord mann , who wrote to the party 's co-leaders about the allegation , ha criticised the green party for taking so long to respond.he said he wa `` disappointed `` the green only responded to his letter , which wa sent on 5 april , three week later , after the bbc contacted the party . `` i 'm a little puzzled , `` he said . `` the green party ha created a bigger problem for itself by not responding immediately . `` a green party spokesperson said it ha responded to lord mann with `` evidence of the action we have taken to remove these ill-judged and offensive communication `` and offered to meet him to continue discussion . `` in one case , it appears the candidate wa unwittingly tagged into an offensive post that he assures u he did not himself publish , `` they said . `` he deleted this post from his timeline a soon a we made him aware of it . `` in the other case , the candidate gave credence to some egregious misinformation by sharing it online . he ha since apologised and undertaken social medium training . `` in our response to lord mann we also reiterated that the green party ha repeatedly condemned the appalling hamas attack of 7th october , and called for the unconditional release of israeli hostage , a well a calling for Body Text: for about three month , adnan el-bursh reported on the war in gaza while living in a tent , eating one meal a day , and struggling to keep his wife and five child safe . the bbc arabic correspondent share the harrowing moment he faced covering a war that pushed him to his limit . warning : this report contains description and image some reader may find distressing one of the worst moment of the past six month wa the night we all slept on the street . i looked at the face of my wife and child , huddled in the bitter cold in khan younis in southern gaza , and felt helpless . my 19-year-old twin , zakia and batoul , lay on the pavement alongside my daughter , yumna , who is 14 , my son mohamed , who is eight and my youngest girl , razan , aged five , with their mother , zaynab . a we tried to rest outside the palestinian red crescent society 's headquarters , the sound of shelling echoed through the night and drone buzzed overhead . we had managed to find an apartment to rent , but the landlord had called earlier that day , saying the israeli military had warned him the building would be bombed . i wa working at the time , but my family grabbed their bag and fled . we met up at the red crescent headquarters , which wa already overflowing with displaced people . my brother and i sat on cardboard box all night , discussing what we should do . we had fled our home in the town of jabalia a few day earlier , on 13 october , leaving most of our possession behind , after the israeli military told everyone in northern gaza to move south for safety . and now we had just escaped being bombed in the area we had been told to move to . it wa hard to think straight . i felt angry , humiliated and terrible that i could not provide any protection for my family . eventually , my family moved to an apartment in nuseirat in central gaza , while i stayed with the bbc team in a tent at nasser hospital in khan younis . i visited every few day . communication wa difficult , with internet and phone signal sometimes cut . once i did not hear from my family for four or five day . in khan younis , the bbc team - about seven of u - lived on one meal a day . even when there wa food , sometimes we did not eat it because there wa hardly anywhere to go to the toilet . during this time my friend , al jazeera bureau chief wael al-dahdouh , suffered a terrible loss . the house his family had been staying in wa hit in an israeli air strike . his wife , teenage son , seven-year-old daughter and one-year-old grandson were killed . the israeli military say it take `` feasible precaution `` to reduce civilian casualty , and in this case had `` targeted hamas terrorist infrastructure in the area `` . reporting gaza : my war in gaza , palestinian journalist document the war a they live it on a daily basis . in this bbc world service film , we hear the story of bbc arabic 's reporter in gaza , adnan el-bursh who found himself reporting the news , a he wa living through it . watch now on bbc iplayer ( uk only ) or on the bbc world service youtube channel ( outside uk ) i watched the footage of my friend , who i have known for 20 year , embracing his child 's shroud-wrapped body in central gaza . i wished i wa there with him . the news came amid a string of report about the death of other friend , relative and neighbour . my heart ached . i have now lost about 200 people in the war . that day i wept live on air , a i wa reporting . in the night , i woke up with tear covering my cheek . wael 's image never left my mind . i have covered conflict in gaza for 15 year , but this war stand apart , from the unprecedented attack that triggered it , to the scale of the loss . at 06:15 on 7 october i wa woken by loud explosion and my child screaming . i went up to the rooftop and saw rocket being launched towards israel from gaza . when we realised hamas had breached the fence into israel - in it assault that saw about 1,200 people killed and 250 taken hostage - we knew the response from israel would be like nothing we had seen before . more than 34,000 people have now been killed in gaza , according to the hamas-run health ministry . the risk of injury and death ha been ever-present . two day into the war , i hurried to our local market in jabalia , to stock up with food . it wa busy with others doing the same . but the area wa bombed heavily just 10 minute after i left . the entire place wa destroyed , including the large grocery store where i had shopped moment earlier . i knew the face of the shop owner . many of them were among the dead . amnesty international say at least 69 people were killed in the attack and that it should be investigated a a war crime . the israeli military ha not responded to the bbc 's question about this incident . throughout the war it ha said it operation is targeting hamas , which it say operates from civilian location . it also say `` strike on military target are subject to relevant provision of international law `` . before the war , jabalia wa a beautiful , tranquil town . i wa born there and had been living a simple , contented life with my family , filled with love and plan for the future . i had a farm east of the town , where i had planted olive , lemon , and orange tree with my own hand . it wa peaceful and i loved to drink tea there after work . the day we decided to flee northern gaza for khan younis - leaving our home and the bbc office in gaza city behind - wa a pivotal moment in my life . with more than 10 people crammed into one car , my family and i crawled our way south , along a single road , with ten of thousand of other people , on foot and in vehicle , all loaded with belonging . the journey wa punctuated by air strike on nearby area on both side of the road . confusion , grief and uncertainty marked the face of my family and the crowd . the child kept asking me : `` where are we going ? will we be back tomorrow ? `` i really wish i had taken our photo album , full of picture of me a a young child , my parent , and my wife and i when we got engaged . my dad wa an arabic teacher and i also wish i had taken some of his book that i kept after he died . later , i learned from a neighbour that my house had been completely destroyed , and my farm burned . after that terrifying and surreal journey south , and our night outside the red crescent headquarters , i continued working from khan younis for several week . my family were still in nuseirat and being separated from them took a toll emotionally . then , in early december , israel began telling gazans to leave part of khan younis and move to other area , including rafah , further south . the israeli military also closed the main road leading north , which connected me and my family . i did not know how i would get to them or where we should go if i did . rafah wa already overcrowded with hundred of thousand of people , and there wa barely anywhere to stay . for day , i grappled with swirling emotion . news circulated about israeli force advancing towards the main road , apparently aiming to divide the south from the central and northern region . i wa terrified that i - or my family - would be killed and we would never see each other again . for the first time i felt like i had lost it . i did not even know what day it wa . i considered stopping work and returning to my family . if we died , we would die together . in the end , on 11 december , i drove with a colleague along a back road to nuseirat . when i arrived , my youngest child rushed up to hug me , with razan reaching round my neck and holding on tight . we managed to move the family to rafah . the bbc team had also relocated there , continuing to report . there were some awful moment . in late december , i reported a the israel defense force ( idf ) handed about 80 body to the authority in gaza . the idf said it had taken them from gaza to israel so they could be checked to see if there were any hostage among them . a large lorry drove into the cemetery in the rafah area . the stench wa overwhelming when the container wa opened . men in apron and mask placed the remains , wrapped in blue plastic , in a mass grave dug by an excavator in the sandy ground . i had never seen a scene like that before . it is hard to describe how horrible it wa . then , in january , i wa reporting from a hospital in rafah when several body were brought in , including another of wael al-dahdouh 's son , hamza , his eldest , who wa also a journalist working for al jazeera . who would tell wael ? it just seemed impossible , after the tragedy he had already faced . i could not even listen a one of my colleague called someone close to wael to pas on the news . hamza and his colleague , freelance videographer mustafa thuraya , were killed in an israeli air strike on their car , after they had reported on the aftermath of another strike in the area . the israeli military alleges they were `` member of gaza-based terrorist organisation `` . the family and al jazeera reject the claim a false . the idf say the two were operating drone `` posing an imminent threat to idf troop `` , but a washington post investigation `` found no indication that either man wa operating a anything other than a journalist that day `` . more than 100 journalist have been killed in gaza since 7 october , according to reporter without border - the vast majority are known to be palestinian . the idf say it `` ha never , and will never , deliberately target journalist `` . it say it `` take all operationally feasible measure to mitigate harm to civilian including journalist `` , but `` remaining in an active combat zone ha inherent risk `` . eventually , the news came that the bbc team 's family had permission to leave gaza . four week later , we too finally left through the rafah crossing , facilitated by the egyptian authority . i am writing this in qatar . but i know that in jabalia , they have been pulling up grass and grinding animal feed to eat , while i 'm here having meal in a clean hotel . i find it hard to eat - it 's like eating poison . the future is a blur . gaza is my life . i want to return one day , but for now , that seems impossible .

Body Text: the u secretary of state hope hamas will accept what he ha called israel 's `` extraordinarily generous `` offer for a gaza truce and hostage release deal . antony blinken wa speaking a a hamas delegation discussed the new proposal with mediator from egypt and qatar . a source close to the talk told the bbc they were cautiously optimistic . the proposal includes a 40-day truce in return for the release of hostage and the prospect of displaced family being allowed back to northern gaza . it reportedly also involves new wording on restoring calm meant to satisfy hamas 's demand for a permanent ceasefire . the hamas delegation ha now left cairo and will return with a written response to the proposal , egypt 's state-affiliated al qahera tv said . the israeli government is coming under growing pressure from it global ally and the family of the hostage to agree a deal . israel launched a military campaign to destroy hamas in response to the group 's cross-border attack on southern israel on 7 october , during which about 1,200 people were killed and 253 others were taken hostage . more than 34,480 people have been killed in gaza since then , according to the territory 's hamas-run health ministry . a deal agreed in november saw hamas release 105 of the hostage in return for a week-long ceasefire and some 240 palestinian prisoner in israeli jail . mediator from egypt , qatar and the u have been attempting for week to broker a new agreement that would secure another pause in the fighting and the release of the 133 hostage who israel say are still being held , at least 30 of whom are presumed dead . earlier this month , hamas rejected an israeli proposal for a six-week truce and the release of 40 woman , child and elderly or sick hostage in exchange for hundred of palestinian prisoner . hamas said it wa sticking to it demand for a permanent ceasefire that would lead to a full withdrawal of israeli troop from gaza and the return of displaced palestinian to their home . the source close to the talk in cairo told the bbc that the new proposal from israel wa significantly different from previous offer . on saturday , the axios news website cited israeli official a saying the proposal included a willingness for the return of people to northern gaza and the withdrawal of israeli troop from the east-west corridor that divide the territory and prevents freedom of movement . it also included a willingness to `` discus the establishment of a sustainable ceasefire a part of the implementation of the second phase of the deal `` , the official said . israeli official and a diplomat meanwhile told the new york time and financial time on monday that israel wa also prepared to reduce the number of hostage released during the first phase to 33 , down from 40 . hamas ha only said publicly that it is studying the new israeli proposal , but an unnamed senior official told afp news agency on sunday that `` the atmosphere is positive Body Text: dozen of pro-palestinian demonstrator at columbia university have escalated their protest over the war in gaza by occupying an academic building . activist at the university in new york city seized hamilton hall early on tuesday , barricading themselves inside . one student said the campus wa `` lawless `` , a official grapple with the long-running demo which ha prompted a wave of rally elsewhere . columbia ha urged student and staff to stay away from campus on tuesday . it earlier began suspending student who defied monday 's deadline of 14:00 est ( 18:00 gmt ) to leave their two-week encampment nearby . but a the deadline passed , dozen of student rallied at the site . columbia student for justice in palestine ( sjp ) , one of the main protest group , vowed to defy the order in a post on x , and called on activist to `` protect the encampment `` . the group later announced the takeover of hamilton hall , highlighting that the venue wa also the focus of student protest in 1968 . another group , columbia university apartheid divest ( cuad ) , said it had `` reclaimed `` the building in honour of hind rajab , a six-year-old girl found dead in gaza earlier this year . one student described the campus a `` lawless , utter anarchy `` , with demonstrator breaking the building 's window to enter , before blocking the door with furniture . speaking to the bbc 's u partner cbs news , jessica schwalb said the group had entered with `` bag full of stuff `` , adding : `` i 'm guessing they 're going to be living in there indefinitely . `` demonstration have rocked campus across the u in recent week , sparked by new york police clearing an earlier encampment at columbia . hundred of people have been arrested across the country - among them dozen of protester at the university of texas at austin on monday . official there said protester had ignored direction to take down their tent and that `` baseball-size rock `` had been found in the encampment . the un human right chief volker turk ha voiced his concern that some law enforcement action witnessed on american campus have been `` disproportionate in their impact `` . `` freedom of expression and the right to peaceful assembly are fundamental to society , `` he added in a statement . at virginia commonwealth university ( vcu ) in richmond , student said police used tear gas and pepper spray against their gathering on monday . the university said the group had been `` repeatedly `` asked to leave , and echoed other institution by saying many of those involved in the demonstration were not student . elsewhere , there ha been a rare agreement reached in evanston , illinois , between northwestern university and protester who have camped out for day in solidarity with the palestinian . under the deal , the university said it would permit `` peaceful demonstration `` , provided the encampment wa limited to a single tent . activist across the u are demanding that their university , many with massive endowment , financially divest from israel . divestment mean to sell or otherwise drop financial tie . pressure ha been building on the leadership of columbia - an elite ivy league university in upper manhattan - to act , or step aside . posting on x before the occupation of hamilton hall , u house speaker mike johnson labelled the scene at columbia an `` utter disgrace `` and called on the university 's president to step down . columbia 's campus ha become the focal point of the country 's debate over the war in gaza and u support for israel , a well a fear that antisemitism is putting jewish student in danger . earlier on monday , a group of house democrat urged it board of trustee to resign if it could not `` act decisively , disband the encampment , and ensure the safety and security of all of it student `` . annual tuition and fee for columbia add up to around $ 90,000 ( £ 72,000 ) for undergraduate , making it one of the most expensive university in the u . more than 100 people were arrested when police raided the earlier encampment on 18 april . but activist redoubled their effort , regrouping in another encampment and prompting university leadership to move to hybrid learning . a statement on monday from columbia 's president , dr minouche shafik , reiterated that the university `` will not divest from israel `` , and that talk between academic leader and student organiser had failed to result in an agreement . several hour after the deadline passed for student to take down their camp - on monday that plan to attack rafah would be shelved in favour of a `` sustained period of calm `` if a ceasefire agreement between hamas and israeli wa reached . day earlier , israel 's foreign minister israel katz told israeli channel 12 television that `` if there will be a deal , we will suspend the [ rafah ] operation `` . but on tuesday mr netanyahu insisted that the war would continue until israel had achieved all of it objective in rafah . `` the idea that we will halt the war before achieving all of it goal is out of the question , `` he said . `` we will enter rafah and we will eliminate the hamas battalion there with or without a deal , in order to achieve the total victory , `` according to a statement issued by mr netanyahu 's office . it said the family urged the prime minister and his national security adviser , tzachi hanegbi , to continue the war and ignore mounting international pressure . many hostage family however have publicly demonstrated for the government 34 of them are presumed dead . the rest have been released or rescued . indirect talk have been at an impasse for week , although the u secretary of state , antony blinken , said on monday that he hoped hamas would accept what he ha called israel 's `` extraordinarily generous offer `` for a truce . meanwhile the head of the un 's refugee organisation ha warned that the looming invasion wa causing people in rafah to live in a state of `` constant traumatic stress disorder `` . `` people have not yet been asked to evacuate from rafah , but there is a sense that if there is no deal this week that could happen , `` philippe lazzarini told reporter . `` my colleague on the ground are describing constant state of trauma among the people . `` mr netanyahu also denounced a `` a scandal on a historical scale `` recent report , citing israeli official , that the international criminal court ( icc ) at the hague could be preparing to issue arrest warrant for israeli government leader and military commander on charge related to the war . `` i want to make one thing clear : no decision , neither in the hague nor anywhere else , will harm our determination to achieve all the goal of the war , `` the prime minister said . `` israel expects the leader of the free world to come out strongly against this scandalous step , a step that will harm the self-defence capacity not only of the state of israel , but of all democracy in the world . `` there ha been no announcement from icc prosecutor karim kahn kc . however , his office ha been formally investigating alleged war crime in the israeli-occupied west bank , east jerusalem and gaza strip since june 2014 , and mr khan ha confirmed that the investigation will cover the 7 october attack and the ensuing war . israel ha never ratified the rome statute , the icc 's founding treaty , and mr netanyahu insisted that the icc had `` no authority `` over the country . however , the icc ruled in 2015 that it had jurisdiction because the palestinian had ratified the treaty . white house press secretary karine jean-pierre said on monday that the u - which ha also not ratified the rome statute - did not believe the court ha jurisdiction and did not support the investigation .

Body Text: the u military ha published photo showing a floating pier being built in the mediterranean sea to help increase humanitarian aid delivery to gaza . logistics vessel and personnel can be seen assembling the pier from steel segment , next to a u navy ship . costing about $ 320m ( £ 255m ) , the pier and a causeway attached to the shore should be operational in a week . the goal is to deliver aid equivalent to a many a two million meal a day to gaza to help avert a famine there . a un-backed assessment said last month that 1.1 million people were facing catastrophic hunger and that famine wa imminent in northern gaza by may . `` right now , you 're seeing construction of that floating , temporary pier , and then , you 'll start to see construction of the causeway , `` u defence department spokeswoman sabrina singh told reporter in washington on monday . `` eventually , that causeway will be . . . pushed into the coastline and secured by the [ israel defense force ] , `` she added . the pier will be ready a week from now , u secretary of state antony blinken said on tuesday . the un ha said a maritime corridor can never be a substitute for delivery by land , and land route are the only way to bring in the bulk of supply needed . satellite image published by planet lab meanwhile appeared to show the pier wa being built next to the usn benavidez , a military sealift command roll-on/roll-off ship , 11km ( 7 mile ) north-west of the coast of northern gaza . a senior u military official said last week that the israeli military 's security role meant `` no u boot will be on the ground `` a part of the mission to construct and operate what is known officially a the joint logistics over-the-shore , or jlots . an unnamed `` third party `` would also be driving aid lorry down the causeway , the official added . hundred of sailor and soldier involved in the operation will live and sleep aboard a british navy logistical support ship , rfa cardigan bay , which ha been deployed to the area . on saturday , the idf confirmed that the israeli navy would `` secure the force `` operating the pier and said it wa `` committed to increasing the amount of humanitarian aid transferred daily into gaza `` . a senior hamas official told the associated press last week that the group - which is proscribed a a terrorist organisation by israel and the u - rejected `` any non-palestinian presence in gaza , whether at sea or on land `` and would `` deal with any military force present in these place … a an occupying power `` . he spoke a day after israel said `` terrorist `` had fired mortar at the site during a visit by un personnel . no injury were reported . the idf also released photo and video of what it described a the `` extensive preparation `` being carried out by it force at a 67 acre ( 0.27 sq km ) holding area where aid from the floating pier will be brought . the site is just inland from the makeshift jetty built by the u charity world central kitchen in march for a maritime corridor that wa suspended after seven of it aid worker were killed in an israeli air strike . the u military official said the floating pier should be able to handle about 90 lorry load of aid per day initially , and then quickly scale up to about 150 lorry load . a lorry can typically carry about 20 tonne of supply . the un ha blamed the severe food shortage on israeli restriction on delivery , the ongoing hostility and the breakdown of order . on friday , the un said a daily average of 192 aid lorry entered gaza during april via the egyptian-controlled rafah and israeli-controlled kerem shalom crossing , which are in southern gaza . the figure did not cover two recently-opened israeli-controlled entry point in central and northern gaza . israeli defence ministry body cogat said an average of 350 lorry entered gaza daily through all crossing in the week beginning 7 april . it ha insisted that israel is not limiting aid delivery and ha blamed the un for failing to distribute it to those in need inside gaza . israel launched a military campaign in gaza to destroy hamas in response to the group 's cross-border attack on southern israel on 7 october , during which about 1,200 people were killed and 253 others were taken hostage . more than 34,500 people have been killed in gaza since then , according to the
