Body Text: spiralling tension and cross-border strike which have killed more than 70 civilian in lebanon have turned part of the south into ghost town . resident have fled , leaving their home at risk of destruction . the bbc went on patrol with the un 's peacekeeping force there to see what ha happened . the huge crater containing a mangled mattress buried under a pile of dust and stone is all that 's left of the building that stood on this spot just day ago . `` we call it ' the pool ' , `` said a lebanese army officer at yarine - a border town on the front line of the one of the region 's most dangerous conflict zone . yarine is just 1km ( 0.6 mile ) from the un-designated blue line - the highly volatile , unofficial boundary between israel and lebanon . in every town near the line , there are similar sight : building levelled or vanished into crater ; next to them , building which have been damaged , then row of house intact - followed by more crater . in alma el shaab , about 4km west of yarine , stand the remains of what appears to have been a gated villa with parked car - destroyed , apart from a fence now surrounding a pile of rubble . the window of house nearby were all smashed from the force of the explosion . `` we are paying the price of all of this , `` lamented the 75-year-old owner of the villa , nadim sayyah . mr sayyah said he used to keep the light on all the time in the hope that might spare the family home from being hit . `` everything is lost , the house , the belonging , and the car . but i will return a soon a i can , even if i were to live in a tent there . `` a soldier there pointed out that `` one missile did all of this `` . israel ha been carrying out strike on southern lebanon almost daily since hezbollah - the powerful lebanese shia islamist group - fired rocket at israel on 8 october in support of hamas in gaza , triggering an escalating series of attack and counter-attacks . because of the danger - three reporter ( one from reuters and two from al mayadeen ) have been killed in strike in south lebanon which their news organisation and lebanon have blamed on israel - the bbc team visited the border area with the un peacekeeping force , unifil . israel ha said it doe not target journalist . unifil ha been in south lebanon since israel 's pullback and eventual withdrawal following it invasion of 1978 . in a not-too-distant past , unifil proudly emphasised that it had overseen the longest period of calm between lebanon and israel - stretching to 16 year since the last war between hezbollah and israel in 2006 . a the bbc team wa filming , what seemed to be israeli drone could be heard in the sky . moment later , plume of thick black smoke appeared in the distance , an apparent israeli strike . it wa not possible to know what had been hit . the israeli army say it target hezbollah fighter and infrastructure and retaliates to attack on israeli army base in northern israel . but some lebanese official , including the caretaker prime minster and speaker of parliament , have accused it of implementing scorched earth tactic to make the whole area uninhabitable . right now , there is no sign of life in many southern village . people have fled , leaving town deserted . about 90,000 lebanese have become displaced , according to the international organization for migration ( iom ) . on the israeli side , about 80,000 people have been evacuated . israel 's defence minister ha said israeli from northern community can not expect to return home until hezbollah ha been driven back from the border . the lebanese town of aita el shaab - just 700m ( 2,300ft ) from israel - ha suffered the heaviest damage so far . on the day of our visit , israel said it launched 40 strike on the town . `` we know that our house ha been badly damaged , but it is still standing - a far a we know , `` said hussein jawad , who come from aita el shaab . hussein , a construction worker , left his house with his seven child and his wife in october . they are now staying in an apartment on the outskirt of beirut . `` we did n't expect it all to last that long . we thought it would just be a couple of day , `` his wife maryam said . `` we know it will still take a while . `` we showed hussein a video of his town that we filmed just month ago . `` this house is now destroyed , that one doe n't exist any more , this row of shop here is now totally flattened , `` he pointed out . he ha ventured back to his town once - week ago when he attended a funeral . he get update about his house every once in a while , from the civil defence staff there or from the mayor who ha not left the town . according to the us-based monitoring group armed conflict location & event data project ( acled ) , there have been more than 5,400 cross-border attack between israel and hezbollah since october . it say 80 % of those were carried out by israel . the israel defense force ( idf ) said last month that it had hit over 4,300 `` hezbollah target `` . it ha also said that a of 2 april , approximately 3,100 rocket had been fired at israel from lebanese territory . israel say nine civilian have been killed by rocket-fire from lebanon . hussein doe not expect to be able to move back home any time soon . `` it could be that what we are witnessing is just the beginning of it , `` he say . back on the road with the italian contingent on unifil , it commander , colonel alberto salvador , insists that the peacekeeping force ' role is still very important , despite the continuing violence . `` we see many people are tired of the situation on this side of the border and on the other side a well . i think it 's time for peace , `` he say . `` the next challenge for the unifil is to help and support the local population in returning to their home . `` but a fighting between israel and hezbollah intensifies , the prospect of that happening remains dim .

injury , `` mr goldberg-polin told me . `` we 've had several surgeon who have seen the video that say he need another surgery immediately . if he wa treated , it wa an emergency treatment . he need a second surgery at least . `` `` he is considered in a fragile and compromised medical state , and so we 're concerned about that . `` a a 23-year-old man , hersh would not be expected to be included in the next batch of hostage whose release is being discussed , which includes woman and the elderly . but those with medical condition also fall into the category to be freed , and so the family hope that he will be included - although they have not had any confirmation . mr goldberg-polin say she is scheduled to meet the u secretary of state , antony blinken , on his latest visit to israel , Body Text: israeli official are increasingly concerned that the international criminal court ( icc ) is planning to seek arrest warrant for their military and political leader on suspicion of war crime . report suggest prime minister benjamin netanyahu could be among them . the icc , based in the hague , ha been investigating israel 's action in the occupied territory for the past three year - and more recently the action of hamas a well . it ha the power to charge and try individual for the most serious crime under international law . it ha previously issued arrest warrant for leader including russia 's vladimir putin , muammar gaddafi of libya , and ugandan warlord joseph kony . mr netanyahu ha called the prospect of senior israel figure joining the wanted list `` an outrage of historic proportion `` , accusing the icc of attempting to paralyse israel 's ability to defend itself . but the fact that he 's chosen to make such strident public comment suggests that , behind the scene , such a scenario is being actively discussed . while the icc ha not confirmed the israeli claim , when chief prosecutor karim khan kc visited israel and the occupied west bank last december his message wa a clear one . the british barrister toured the site of hamas ' attack in israeli village close to the gaza fence , which hamas-led gunman burst through on 7 october . he also met political leader , and travelled to ramallah to speak to the family of palestinian victim about their experience in gaza and the west bank . he condemned the violence suffered by civilian on both side , and promised to investigate . `` all actor must comply with international humanitarian law , `` he clarified in a statement at the time . `` if you do not do so , do not complain when my office is required to act . `` mr khan said the 7 october attack - in which hamas-led gunman killed about 1,200 people , mostly civilian , and seized 253 hostage , according to israeli tally - represented `` some of the most serious international crime that shock the conscience of humanity , crime which the icc wa established to address `` . in israel 's case , his concern were twofold . he stressed the obligation to conduct it military operation in gaza according to `` clear legal parameter that govern armed conflict `` . israel ha been accused of failing to sufficiently protect civilian during it months-long bombardment , although it insists it take all necessary measure to avoid casualty . the hamas-run health ministry in the territory say more than 34,500 people have been killed there since the war began , and that many of that number are child . mr khan also underlined the need for humanitarian aid to get into gaza , with access to food , water and medical supply a basic right for civilian `` without further delay , and at pace and at scale `` . he also urged hamas not to divert or misuse the supply when they did arrive , after accusation by israel that it member were looting truck and stealing aid , stopping it from reaching the wider population . israel is n't a member of the icc and it say the court ha no jurisdiction over it . but the court ha ruled that since 2015 it doe in fact have jurisdiction over the west bank , east jerusalem and gaza after the palestinian ratified it founding treaty , the rome statute , a the state of palestine . no western-style democracy ha had an icc arrest warrant issued for it leader before . if it happens to mr netanyahu , he 'll be the first . israeli have particular concern about the stigma and potential isolation that would come with it . michael oren wa israel 's ambassador to the united state between 2009 and 2013 . he point to the recent case brought by south africa at the international court of justice ( icj ) , which accused israel of genocide against the palestinian population in gaza - an accusation israel vehemently reject . in january , the court issued an interim ruling that ordered israel to take step to prevent genocidal act in gaza , but stopped short of telling it to stop it military offensive . `` israel emerged from those proceeding relatively unscathed , but the fact that the proceeding were held at all meant that israel had lost the battle , `` he told the bbc . `` they should not have been held at all , and certainly it 's a blow to our international standing and our security . because a country whose leader are accused of presiding over war crime , that country is more vulnerable than a country that is n't . `` sir geoffrey nice kc , another british barrister , led the prosecution of the former serbian president slobodan milosevic for war crime at the international criminal tribunal for the former yugoslavia ( icty ) . he point out that the action of both side in this conflict are within the icc 's focus . `` any investigation will not just be the israeli defense force and political and military leadership but also hamas , `` he told the bbc . `` it 's to be hoped that alleged hamas fighter and leader are not all shot on sight , that they are detained and made available for trial by an international tribunal . `` he also addressed suggestion that the icc could come under political pressure to reconsider it decision-making . `` government around the world , particularly large and powerful government , are there to protect their country 's interest . `` so if they see a trial coming along , or an investigation . . . that would cause them a a country great reputational damage , and if they reckon they can interfere with the trial or the investigative or trial process to save them from that reputational damage , then they 'll do that , because they are acting in the interest of their country . `` the timeframe for issuing warrant can vary , with week and even month sometimes elapsing between the point at which the icc prosecutor request it , and judge grant it . sometimes the detail can be kept confidential if it 's deemed that making them public would lessen the prospect of an arrest . such a move against mr netanyahu , his political colleague or israeli military commander would have practical implication too . it would affect their ability to travel widely , a rome statute nation are obligated to hand over visiting individual with outstanding warrant against them . however , some of those nation have ignored icc warrant in recent year . former israeli ambassador michael oren belief the eventual impact would be far wider , changing the narrative of israeli society `` generally , it responds to love . it doe n't respond to aggression . if you want to get concession out of israeli do not hit them over the head , embrace them , `` he said . `` all of these measure tend to move the political needle in this country rightward and not the other way . it would have a boomerang effect , and rather than opening pathway to possible diplomatic process it will likely constrict it . ``

Body Text: turkey ha suspended all trade with israel over it offensive in gaza , citing the `` worsening humanitarian tragedy `` in the strip . the turkish trade ministry said the measure would be in place until israel allowed an `` uninterrupted and sufficient flow `` of aid into gaza . trade between the two country wa worth almost $ 7bn ( â£5.6bn ) last year . israel 's foreign minister accused turkish president recep tayyip erdogan of acting like a `` dictator `` . israel katz said on x that mr erdogan wa `` disregarding the interest of the turkish people and businessmen and ignoring international trade agreement `` . he added that he had instructed the foreign ministry to find alternative for trade with turkey , with a focus on local production and import from other country . the ministry also say it will also take action to reduce economic connection between turkey and the palestinian authority and gaza , the bbc understands . turkish trade minister omer bolat criticised israel 's `` uncompromising attitude `` towards a ceasefire , a well a the humanitarian situation in the southern gaza city of rafah : `` turkey ha suspended all export and import with israel until a permanent ceasefire is established and the aid into the gaza is allowed without any interruption . `` in 1949 , turkey wa the first muslim-majority country to recognise israel . but relation have worsened in recent decade . in 2010 , turkey broke off diplomatic tie with israel after 10 pro-palestinian turkish activist were killed in clash with israeli commando who boarded a turkish-owned ship trying to break israel 's maritime blockade of the gaza strip . relation were restored in 2016 , but both country expelled each other 's top diplomat two year later in a dispute over israel 's killing of palestinian amid protest on the gaza-israel border . mr erdogan ha become increasingly strident in his criticism of israel since the deadly hamas attack on israel on 7 october last year . he ha repeatedly criticised israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu , comparing him to adolf hitler , benito mussolini and joseph stalin and dubbing him `` the butcher of gaza `` . mr netanyahu ha said turkey 's leader is the last person who can preach morality to israel . in march he said president erdogan `` support the mass murderer and rapist of hamas , denies the armenian genocide [ and ] massacre kurd in his own country `` . the turkish leader ha for month come under domestic political pressure to announce measure against israel , from both opponent and ally . his ruling ak party suffered it worst defeat in two decade in local election at the end of march , and many religious voter supported the islamist new welfare party , which had called for hardline measure against israel . not long after the vote , turkey imposed restriction on 54 product being exported to israel , from iron and steel to jet fuel , pesticide and construction equipment . the trade ministry in ankara said on thursday that the action wa now being extended to all export and import . israel wa turkey 's 13th biggest export market in 2023 , receiving 2.1 % of turkish export last year . turkey wa a narrow strip of agricultural land that ha long been an idf-designated “ humanitarian zone ” - to the city of khan younis and the central town of deir al-balah.the idf did not provide any detail about the location of the tent for the people being evacuated , but in recent week satellite image have shown several encampment constructed north of rafah and west of khan younis . mohammed daoud said the 35 member of his family living had “ no choice but to leave ” after finding out that their house in the oraiba area wa inside the evacuation zone . “ we do not know where to go and how we will manage , ” he told the bbc.rasha sheikh khalil , a displaced woman living in a tent in rafah with her husband and four child , said : “ i had started preparing my bag and getting ready to return to my neighbourhood in gaza city , but the bad news [ on monday ] surprised u . ” “ no-one care about our fate . for seven month we have not tasted comfort and tranquillity . ” ghada el-kurd , a mother-of-two who ha been displaced six time over the last four month , told the bbc that she wa living only 15 minute away from one of the evacuated area but wa staying put for now . “ i ’ m so confused . . . i have no place to go . this wa the last place i know , ” she said . “ if i want to come back to khan younis there is no place - it is all destroyed . [ a for ] area of al-mawasi , they are crowded and i can not any more live inside a tent - it ’ s so hot and my health doe not allow me to be in such a situation . regarding deir al-balah . . . there are a lot of air strike there . . . and it is a very dangerous area . ” the un said it wa “ not taking part in involuntary evacuation or in the setting up of any displacement zone ” . but james elder , a spokesman for the un child ’ s agency , unicef , who wa in gaza last month , said ghada el-kurd ’ s assessment of the idf ’ s humanitarian area wa “ absolutely spot on ” . `` there 's nowhere to go . khan younis , let 's be clear , is rubble , ” he told the bbc . “ i 've walked around those street of khan younis . it 's not a little bit destroyed , it 's utterly devastated . ” “ deir al-balah . . . ha now got raw sewage running through the street because sanitation ha just been devastated , and al-mawasi is a beach , a sandy area , and we 're starting to hit summer . ” “ we 've already had report of child dying of dehydration . so when we 're told that people should move to humanitarian zone , that 's a terrifying irony when humanitarian are n't working in these zone . `` but , he added : “ of course , family will move . they will move because they will move or be bombed . ” mr elder said the aid operation in gaza wa already very fragile because it wa “ continually undermined by bombing , by insecurity , by denial of access ” , but that an israeli offensive in rafah could push it to breaking point.un official are particularly concerned that the rafah and kerem shalom crossing - the key entry point for aid into gaza - could be closed during the current israeli operation in eastern gaza.kerem shalom wa shut on sunday after four israeli soldier there were killed by 10 rocket launched by hamas fighter from an area near the rafah crossing , according to the idf . but israel ’ s prime minister told the u president on monday that he would ensure kerem shalom reopened for humanitarian assistance.kerem shalom wa still closed on tuesday morning , when the idf announced that it troop had `` obtained operational control `` of the gazan side of the rafah crossing . the un agency for palestinian refugee , unrwa - which run the largest humanitarian operation in gaza - ha said it will maintain a presence in rafah a long a possible and would continue providing lifesaving aid.but it ha also warned that the continued interruption of the entry of aid and fuel supply at the rafah crossing would `` halt the critical humanitarian response `` across gaza . `` the catastrophic hunger faced by people especially in northern gaza will get much worse if these supply route are interrupted , `` the agency said in a post on x , formerly twitter , on tuesday.the idf ha said it is committed to facilitating humanitarian aid into and within gaza and that it ha established alternative crossing , including two in the north .

Body Text: president joe biden warned against what he called a `` ferocious surge `` of antisemitism in the u and around the world during a holocaust remembrance event on tuesday . he said too many people had been `` denying , downplaying , rationalising the horror of the holocaust `` . mr biden , 81 , also condemned those who he said had forgotten the 7 october hamas attack on israel . it wa some of his most pointed criticism of hamas since the attack . `` it wa hamas that brutalised israeli , `` mr biden said . `` it wa hamas that took and continues to hold hostage . i have not forgotten . `` the president also criticised what he characterised a lawless behaviour and hateful rhetoric directed at jewish people by some pro-palestinian protester on u university campus in recent week . he said that `` scapegoating and demonising a minority `` threatens all minority . the speech followed police intervention to dismantle several protest camp at college around the country . the demonstrator have faced complaint of intimidation and hate speech , which organiser have denied . at the same time they say they have been subject to islamophobic and racist remark by counter-demonstrators . ahead of the speech , the white house announced new measure aimed at countering antisemitism , expanding on a national strategy first published in june . they include the creation of online resource `` to ensure that college and university do a better job of protecting both jewish student and all of their student `` , a well a new guidance for school . since the 7 october attack on israel by hamas militant and the subsequent israeli invasion of the gaza strip , jewish student in the u have reported an increase in antisemitic incident . according to the anti-defamation league , a leading jewish advocacy group , incident spiked nationally in the final three month of 2023 , and rose 321 % on university campus . one jewish student at columbia university - where a protest encampment sparked a wave of pro-palestinian demonstration - previously told the bbc that she had been called a `` murderer `` and told to `` go back to poland `` . while the protester have said they were demonstrating peacefully for a ceasefire in gaza , several encampment in university building have been shut down by police over concern about escalating violence . others have been allowed to continue on the proviso they remain peaceful . in the six month since the israel-hamas conflict began , the biden administration ha attempted to balance support for israel with addressing growing domestic dissent over the deteriorating humanitarian situation in gaza . but while some have accused mr biden of not doing enough to end the fighting , he ha faced criticism from republican for publicly seeking to limit israel 's action and not speaking about the protest sooner .

Body Text: after month of stalemate , the search for peace in gaza ha reached a critical stage . un chief antonio guterres say it is a `` decisive moment for the palestinian and israeli people and for the fate of the entire region `` . there seems to be common ground between most side about the principle : a ceasefire should take place alongside the release of israeli hostage and palestinian prisoner . various draft agreement have been drawn up , setting out a complex process of how it would all work . there is some disagreement over the detail of what should happen to whom and when and in what order . israeli official say , for example , that it female soldier should be released earlier than envisaged . they also say the text should be clearer that the first 33 hostage to be released must be alive and are worried about not having a veto over which palestinian prisoner would be released . these are issue that could potentially be surmounted through negotiation . but there is a more fundamental sticking point about a core principle that may be harder to get past and that is when the war should end . the opening word of the draft agreement - supported by hamas - declares that there should be a `` temporary cessation of military operation between the two party `` . this is largely unproblematic . six week would pas while people are released , israeli force withdraw from some area , displaced gazans would be able to return to what if anything is left of their home . but then stage two would begin . the draft agreement then talk about a `` return to sustainable calm `` , which it defines a `` a permanent cessation of military and hostile operation `` . it is this that seems to be unacceptable to israel 's government . in a statement , the prime minister benjamin netanyahu said : `` israel will not allow hamas to restore it evil rule in the gaza strip , israel will not allow it to restore it military capability to continue striving for our destruction . israel can not accept a proposal that endangers the security of our citizen and the future of our country . `` in other word , israel 's government want the right to continue taking the fight to hamas in the long run . by contrast , hamas want a permanent ceasefire . what is not clear is whether there is a way for qatari , egyptian and american negotiator to find a middle path through this . it may be that all of this is part of the negotiation . public statement are frequently used in negotiation to put pressure on the other side . the announcement by hamas that it support a particular draft could be an attempt to push israel into making concession and divide it from it ally . israel 's warning about an imminent military operation in rafah could be an attempt to extract better term from hamas . but the question of whether any ceasefire is permanent or not look hard to square with clever diplomatic language . israel ha agreed to send a delegation to cairo but with modest ambition - not to hammer out a deal but `` to exhaust the possibility of reaching an agreement under condition acceptable to israel `` . much will depend on what the u government decides . so far , u spokespeople have fallen over themselves to avoid making any comment on the deal hamas ha signed up to . they have limited themselves to asserting that an agreement is still `` achievable `` and to warning firmly against a military operation in rafah . that is because if the u were to throw it weight behind the current text , then mr netanyahu might be forced to choose between his main ally and the ultra-nationalist hardliner propping up his government who oppose any compromise . mr netanyahu ha survived many crisis in his political career by postponing difficult decision . but president biden ha it in his gift to force israel 's leader to make a choice that he might rather avoid .

Body Text: complaint about doctor subjecting jewish colleague to antisemitic abuse have surged in the month following the 7 october attack and the subsequent israel-gaza war , according to general medical council records.one doctor , a senior jewish physician in london , told the bbc he had been subjected to a vicious antisemitic outburst by a colleague a few day after the deadly attacks.the rise in antisemitic complaint , a well a islamophobic complaint , mirror a broader trend of increased religious hate crime in the uk since the recent conflict , according to figure obtained by the bbc.the gmc , which regulates doctor in the uk , said it wa investigating serious concern and would take action where necessary . the doctor at the london hospital , who requested to remain anonymous , described the `` appalling `` verbal attack from a co-worker . `` this doctor knew i wa jewish , and just day after october 7th he started expressing support for hamas , repeatedly shouting , ' you 're a baby-killer ' , in my face . `` the doctor said he wa left `` extremely upset , horrified and shaken `` by the harassment at work . `` i 've never before had it in such a blatant way inside a hospital - a place which is supposed to be the ultimate safe space . `` the bbc understands that the hospital concerned is investigating all aspect of the case , including the antisemitism allegation . from the start of 2023 , the gmc received eight complaint about antisemitism by doctors.however , in the four month after the hamas attack , 60 medical professional were reported for alleged antisemitic conduct or remark against their colleague across the uk . of these 60 complaint , 22 are currently undergoing `` triage `` , a process where the gmc determines whether a complaint should proceed to a full investigation . according to the gmc , 1,903 doctor identified a jewish in 2023 , the most recent data available . this is roughly 1 % of licensed doctor in the uk . the gmc figure , obtained via a freedom of information request by the bbc , also show an uptick in complaint about islamophobia by doctor since 7 october , with 16 case from october through to january compared to three in the preceding nine month . there are 53,359 doctor in the uk who identify a muslim - 17 % of doctor - according to the latest figure from the regulator.of the 16 complaint made after 7 october , 12 are in triage and four have been closed . dr salman waqar , of the british islamic medical association , said while the figure showed an increase in islamophobic incident , it wa difficult to give an accurate representation of the problem within the nh . `` people tend not to report it because of fear . in the medical profession , most muslim colleague are n't senior yet . we are n't hearing about the worst case a much a we should , `` dr waqar said.he said there were many who worried if they were to complain , they would lose their visas.he described example of muslim doctor facing exclusion , such a being left out of important email chain or meeting and other case , where muslim doctor reported feeling abandoned by colleague who failed to speak up when patient made islamophobic remark . `` these figure are creating a system of ' u and them ' and should n't come across like we 're in the ' racism olympics ' , `` dr waqar said.he also criticised the gmc for following a `` common sense `` definition of antisemitism and islamophobia , rather than working with group to establish a clearer , more precise definition . for the jewish community , the rise in antisemitism complaint against medical professional ha been particularly disturbing , mirroring an overall trend in the uk since 7 october.dr dave rich from the community security trust , a charity that monitor antisemitism , said : `` it is shocking to see this happening within the medical profession - the one part of society where we expect everybody to behave with complete professionalism and neutrality . `` dr rich said his organisation had received `` quite unusual `` report from jewish medic about `` thing either said to them , or posted online , or other kind of antisemitic behaviour from colleague `` in recent month . he called it `` really disappointing to see this playing out `` in the wake of an overseas conflict.dr rich said jewish medical professional were being singled out by their colleague simply due to their identity . `` the vast majority of incident that we record involve visibly jewish people or jewish organisation being singled out simply because they are jewish , and either harassed or threatened , or treated a if they are somehow to blame or responsible for anything israel ha done , simply because they are jewish , `` dr rich said . the jewish medical association 's prof david katz accused the gmc of being `` sluggish `` and `` unclear `` over it criterion for determining and resolving case of alleged antisemitism.he belief the reported incident are `` just the tip of the iceberg `` , with some jewish doctor hesitant to come forward . `` there 's a question that the wish to avoid identifying yourself too publicly a jewish remains a strong one , which reflects maybe a little on the nature of the underlying host society , `` prof katz said . the professional standard authority , which oversees the gmc , ha previously been warned by health secretary victoria atkins that it is `` vital for public confidence `` that `` any instance of extremism , discrimination or hate speech are dealt with in a thorough and timely manner `` . a gmc spokesperson told the bbc : `` we recognise the significant impact the ongoing conflict ha on member of the profession , patient , and all those affected . `` since october 2023 we have received a high volume of complaint about doctor ’ comment on social medium related to ongoing conflict in gaza . `` doctor are entitled to personal belief , and there is nothing preventing doctor from exercising their right to speak about or campaign on issue , but this must not affect their relationship with patient or the treatment they provide or arrange . `` our guidance is clear that discrimination is not compatible with the responsibility and duty of a doctor . `` get in touch : do you have a story you 'd like bbc london 's investigation team to look into ? get in touch , in we are escalating the situation . ” police said no arrest had been made at the protest.the cambridge palestine solidarity campaign ha urged people to write to the university to express support for the encampment and `` their demand `` . a cambridge university spokesman said the university and king 's college , on whose lawn the tent were set up , were operating normally . `` the university is fully committed to academic freedom and freedom of speech within the law and we acknowledge the right to protest , `` it said in a statement . `` we ask everyone in our community to treat each other with understanding and empathy . our priority is the safety of all staff and student . `` we will not tolerate antisemitism , islamophobia and any other form of racial or religious hatred . `` the university ha issued `` protest guidance `` which said : `` all member of our community should feel safe and we will never tolerate any form of discrimination , intimidation , incitement , bullying or harassment . `` follow cambridgeshire news on facebook , instagram and x . got a story ? email eastofenglandnews @ bbc.co.uk or whatsapp u on 0800 169 1830

and surrounding street , `` the statement added . gw said it remains open and operating a normal , but additional security personnel have been deployed to university yard and the surrounding area . in gaza . since the 7 october attack by hamas and israel 's retaliatory assault , student have launched rally , sit-in , fast and , most recently , encampment against the war . according to a bbc tally , there have been pro-palestine protest at 45 state and washington dc since the demonstration started at columbia university in new york on 17 april . they are demanding that their school , many with massive endowment , financially divest from israel . many also want their university to end academic relationship with israeli institution . previously , president joe biden said people had the right to protest but not the right to cause chaos . but , mr biden warned on tuesday the threat of antisemitism is growing in the u , including on college campus , joining a heated american debate about jewish security , zionism , free speech and support for israel , in the country with the largest jewish population after israel . addressing a bipartisan audience at the u holocaust memorial museum 's annual commemoration , mr biden said : `` this hatred ( of jew ) continues to lie deep in the heart of too many people in the world and requires our continued vigilance and outspokenness , `` biden said . `` now here we are , not 75 year later , but just seven and a half month later , and people are already forgetting . . . that hamas unleashed this terror , `` he added . `` i have not Body Text: twelve malawian have been deported from israel after leaving the farm where they were working , to get higher salary elsewhere . the 12 malawian were among more than 40 foreign worker who were arrested while working at a bakery in tel aviv last week.the worker , who were part of a labour agreement between israel and malawi , were unhappy with working condition in the agricultural sector and found work in a bakery instead.israel 's ambassador to malawi michael lotem told the bbc : `` anybody who violates his visa term will be deported – a easy a this , a in any country . `` i hope it will be a sign for others that it is better to stick to the job . nobody forced them to come , they came to do a job , they should do the job that is all . `` last week , benzani , a malawian working in israel , told the bbc that some of his compatriot working on other farm were being paid less than the minimum wage in israel . `` the minimum wage in israel is 32 shekel ( $ 8.60 ; £ 6.85 ) an hour , but some of u are being paid 18 to 20 shekel an hour . `` benzani said many of them had signed contract which said they would receive $ 1,500 a month.benzani is not one of those who were deported . mr lotem said that rather than leaving the farm and breaking the condition of their visa , they should have lodged a complaint . “ if someone think that he is not getting what he deserves , there is a hotline and a phone number they can call `` violating the law is not the answer . `` the israeli police show zero tolerance to illegal activity especially these day when we have so many other trouble , ” mr lotem said . those deported were part of a labour drive by the israeli government last year to fill a shortage of agricultural worker following october 's deadly attack on israel by hamas.this led israel to stop giving permit to palestinian to work on it farm , while 10,000 migrant farm worker - mostly thai national - left israel after war broke out.more than 200 malawian went to israel , while kenya agreed to send 1,500 workers.the announcement of the deal sparked mixed reaction in kenya , with some concerned about their safety.the two government said it would help reduce unemployment in their countries.mr lotem also said that a new agreement had been signed for another 3,000 malawian to go and work in israel . classmate pay tribute to tanzanian killed in israeljoy and relief a 17 thai hostage return homeafrican brain drain : ' 90 % of my friend want to leave ' go to bbcafrica.com for more news from the african continent.follow u on twitter @ bbcafrica , on facebook at bbc africa or on instagram at bbcafrica

Body Text: hundred of gaza 's water and sanitation facility have been damaged or destroyed since israel began military action against hamas , satellite analysis by bbc verify ha found . damage to a major supply depot ha also severely disrupted repair . the lack of clean water and flow of untreated sewage pose a serious threat to health , say aid agency . the israel defense force told the bbc that hamas cynically exploit civilian infrastructure for terror purpose . the destruction come despite israel 's duty to protect critical infrastructure under the rule of war , unless there is evidence site are being used for military reason , say human right lawyer . clean water ha always been a limited resource in gaza and the territory ha largely relied on a system of boreholes and desalination plant for it supply . our analysis found that more than half of these vital facility have been damaged or destroyed since israel launched it retaliation in gaza after hamas attacked on 7 october . we also found that four of the six wastewater treatment plant - crucial to preventing the build-up of sewage and the spread of disease - have been damaged or destroyed . the two others have shut down because lack of fuel or other supply , according to one aid agency . the plant were among more than 600 water and sanitation facility that we analysed , using a list of location provided by gaza 's coastal municipality water utility ( cmwu ) . in one satellite image , of khan younis in the south of gaza , two damaged large water storage tank can be seen . the destruction of water and sanitation facility ha led to `` disastrous health consequence for the population `` , said dr natalie robert , executive director of medecins sans frontieres uk . `` the rate of diarrhoeal disease have gone catastrophically high , `` she said . in very severe case , such disease can kill young child and the vulnerable . rate of hepatitis a - found in contaminated water and particularly dangerous for pregnant woman - are also high , according to the charity . `` this is killing people , `` dr robert said . there is a particular spike in disease in rafah in the south where many gazans have fled to , dr robert said , and a risk of cholera . there ha been widespread damage to building across gaza since hamas attacked israel on 7 october . according to the un , about 69,000 housing unit have been destroyed and a further 290,000 damaged . home are now `` very unlikely `` to have running water , according to aid worker we spoke to . to carry out this analysis we sought advice from expert at the un and human right watch on the best approach . for each site , we sourced the most recent high resolution satellite imagery and compared each shot with an image taken prior to 7 october . we then marked a facility a destroyed or damaged if the closest structure to the given co-ordinate appeared to be reduced to rubble , partially collapsed , or showed other sign of damage . bbc verify ha not distinguished between `` destroyed `` and `` damaged `` facility . this is because without knowing the precise outline of each facility , we can not say whether it ha been partly damaged or completely destroyed . water well usually consist of an underground borehole and electric pump , together with a small control room above ground . however , a the control room is not always visible or easily identifiable we had to rely on analysing the nearest visible building when assessing damage . of the 603 water facility we analysed , 53 % appeared to have been damaged or destroyed since 7 october . a further 43 facility were in area that showed some damage or where solar panel had been removed , but we were unable to determine whether the water facility itself had been damaged so these were not included in our analysis . the latest available satellite image were acquired in march and april , and our analysis ha been ongoing since april . the majority of site identified a destroyed or damaged are in northern gaza or in the area around the southern city of khan younis . at one wastewater facility in bureij , in the centre of the strip , solar panel that power the plant had been obliterated and sewage treatment tank appeared to have algae growing on the surface . not all damage is visible from satellite image , so our analysis may have missed some affected facility . some site also may not be fully operational due to a lack of fuel . for example , the unicef desalination plant in deir al-balah - one of three large seawater facility in gaza - can only work at 30 % capacity because of lack of fuel , unicef told the bbc . with most gazans now displaced from their home , and living in tented camp , the build-up of sewage in the street is even more of a threat . `` the pump for sewage are not operating and the street are flooded [ with it ] , `` said muhammad atallah , who work for the palestinian centre for human right . the conflict ha already made water facility repair difficult for gaza 's water authority , but a strike on a key maintenance warehouse ha made it harder still . the building , in the neighbourhood of al-mawasi , wa severely damaged in a missile strike on 21 january . four people died and 20 others were injured , according to the cmwu . monther shoblaq , the director general of cmwu , told the bbc this warehouse , which acted a a depot for both the cmwu and unicef , contained more than 2,000 item used for maintenance , and wa the heart of the water and sanitation service in gaza . it destruction ha severely limited cmwu 's ability to repair and maintain vital facility such a water pipeline , he said . the idf said the warehouse wa not targeted , but that hamas terrorist operating nearby were struck and `` it is possible that part of the warehouse suffered damage a a result of the strike `` . we gave the idf a sample of five other damaged or destroyed water site from our analysis . in one case , the idf denied there had been an air strike , in the four other case it said hamas fighter or site were the actual target . `` hamas store it weapon and ammunition within these civilian structure , construct terror infrastructure beneath them , and from them , launch it attack … the idf is locating and destroying these terror infrastructure , which have been discovered , among other place , in and near the water facility in question . `` leila sadat , a former special adviser on crime against humanity at the international criminal court , told the bbc that facility critical to the survival of civilian should be protected unless a military body ha some concrete evidence to suggest otherwise . to assess war action in term of legality , you need to consider `` the pattern `` of those action , she said . `` you ca n't just look strike by strike … [ t ] hey [ the idf ] have hit water pipe , tank , reservoir , and infrastructure , `` she said . `` to take out over half of water and sanitation would be very difficult without intentionally doing so . so the pattern is evidence of either a reckless approach to civilian object or the intentional destruction of them ; these were not all mistake , `` she added . in response to our finding , sara elizabeth dill , an international criminal and human right lawyer , said : `` what we are seeing is essentially siege warfare and the total destruction of gaza , without regard for human life or human decency , or any attempt to comply with international law . `` additional reporting by erwan rivault , joshua cheetham , benedict garman and deena easa Body Text: president joe biden ha warned israel that the u will stop supplying some weapon if it launch a major ground operation in the gaza city of rafah . `` if they go into rafah , i 'm not supplying the weapon that have been used historically to deal with rafah , `` he said during an interview with cnn . he added that he would `` continue to make sure israel is secure `` . despite firm and vocal u opposition , israel appears poised to mount a large-scale invasion of rafah . the congested part of southern gaza is hamas 's last major stronghold in the territory . u official have warned that an operation in the city - where the population ha swelled with refugee from other part of gaza - could lead to extensive civilian casualty . `` we 're not going to supply the weapon and artillery shell , `` mr biden said in the interview , which aired on wednesday . israel 's ambassador to the un said the country wa `` very disappointed `` by mr biden 's intervention . `` if israel is restricted from entering an area a important and central a rafah where there are thousand of terrorist , hostage and leader of hamas , how exactly are we supposed to achieve our goal ? `` he said on public radio . mr biden told cnn that the u did not define the current situation in rafah a a ground operation . `` they have n't gone into the population centre . what they did is right on the border , `` he said . `` but i 've made it clear to [ israeli prime minister netanyahu ] and the war cabinet , they 're not going to get our support , if in fact they go in these population centre . `` mr biden acknowledged that u weapon had been used by israel to kill civilian in gaza . when asked if israel had crossed a `` red line `` , the u president replied `` not yet `` . the comment amount to the president 's strongest warning yet over a potential ground invasion of rafah , and mark the first time he ha said the u could stop shipment of american weapon to israel . the u ha already delayed a shipment of thousand of bomb to israel , and ha said it is reviewing future delivery . on wednesday , defence secretary lloyd austin confirmed the delay of the bomb shipment - some of the most destructive munition in western military arsenal - while testifying in front of the senate . the weapon being held back by the u are related to a future delivery , so the move is unlikely to have an immediate impact . but given the rate at which israel is bombing it will probably affect future strike fairly soon . the israeli military , meanwhile , ha said that the two country will resolve disagreement `` behind closed door `` . president biden face mounting domestic pressure - from some democrat and part of the u public - to rein in israeli operation in gaza amid rising civilian death and a worsening humanitarian situation . with november 's presidential election looming , opinion poll indicate many young voter and arab-americans in key state such a michigan are critical of what they see a the president 's support for the israeli war effort . u official confirmed that no new aid supply had been delivered in gaza via two gate in the south since israeli tank rolled into southern rafah and took control of the palestinian side of the crossing with egypt this week . rafah ha been a key entry point for aid , and the only exit for people able to flee , since the start of the war between israel and hamas last october . the crossing remained closed on wednesday morning , but the israeli military said it wa reopening the nearby kerem shalom crossing , which had been closed for four day because of hamas rocket fire . on monday , the israeli military ordered ten of thousand of civilian to begin evacuating eastern part of rafah city , ahead of what it called a `` limited `` operation to eliminate hamas fighter and dismantle infrastructure . meanwhile , effort continue to reach a ceasefire , alongside the release of israeli hostage and palestinian prisoner . in cairo , delegation from israel and hamas have resumed negotiation through mediator . a u official said that talk with israel were `` ongoing and have not fully addressed our concern `` and the u had been reviewing it weapon transfer to israel since april . israel launched a campaign to destroy hamas in response to the group 's attack on southern israel on 7 october , during which about 1,200 people were killed and 252 others were taken hostage , according to israeli tally . more than 34,780 people have been killed in gaza since then , according to the territory 's hamas-run health ministry . a deal agreed in november saw hamas release 105 hostage in return for a week-long ceasefire and some 240 palestinian prisoner in israeli jail . israel say 128 hostage are unaccounted for , 36 of whom are presumed dead . additional reporting by raffi berg

Body Text: benjamin netanyahu ha vowed israel can `` stand alone `` , after the u warned arm shipment could be stopped if he order a full-scale invasion of rafah in gaza . thousand of people have would cross a `` red line `` . but mr netanyahu dismissed the u warning , saying israel would fight on . `` if we need to . . . we will stand alone . i have said that if necessary we will fight with our fingernail , `` the prime minister said . mr netanyahu also invoked the war of 1948 - where the newly formed state of israel wa attacked by a coalition of arab state - to dismiss the u warning . `` in the war of independence 76 year ago , we were the few against the many , `` he said . `` we did not have weapon . there wa an arm embargo on israel , but with great strength of spirit , heroism and unity among u - we were victorious . `` despite mr netanyahu 's comment , his government ha come under pressure after the u suspended the delivery of 1,800 2,000lb ( 907kg ) bomb and 1,700 500lb bomb over fear that they could cause civilian death in rafah . mr biden went further still in an interview with cnn on wednesday , saying that if the attack went ahead he would further suspend supply of artillery shell and other weapon . yoav gallant , mr netanyahu 's defence minister , dismissed the u warning , saying israel 's `` enemy a well a . . . best of friend `` should understand that his country `` can not be subdued `` . `` we will stand strong , we will achieve our goal , `` he added . the comment came hour after the un said more than 80,000 people had fled rafah since monday amid constant bombardment and a israeli tank massed close to built-up area . the un also warned that food and fuel were running out for the more than one million still sheltering in the city , because it wa not receiving aid through nearby crossing . israeli troop took control and closed the rafah crossing with egypt at the start of their operation , while the un said it wa too dangerous for it staff and lorry to reach the reopened kerem shalom crossing with israel . israeli force said they were conducting `` targeted raid `` against hamas element remaining in the city . however , the israeli government ha refused to rule out a full scale invasion , leading to mr biden 's warning he would not supply it with the munition to do so . white house national security spokesman john kirby said mr biden did not believe `` smashing into rafah `` would advance israel 's objective of defeating hamas . `` an enduring defeat of hamas certainly remains the israeli goal , and we share that goal with them , `` mr kirby said . `` the argument that somehow we 're walking away from israel , or we 're not willing to help them defeat hamas just doe n't comport with the fact , `` he said . palestinian medium said two people were killed on thursday afternoon in an israeli air strike in the al-jneineh neighbourhood of rafah - one of the eastern area which the israel defense force ( idf ) ordered resident to evacuate before beginning it ground operation began on monday night . another three people were reportedly killed in an air strike in the nearby brazil area , which is not in the evacuation zone but is next to the egyptian border . hamas and palestinian islamic jihad ( pij ) - which are proscribed a terrorist organisation by israel , the u and other country - said they were targeting israeli force on the eastern outskirt with mortar bomb and anti-tank missile . hamas also said it had blown up a booby-trapped tunnel east of rafah underneath three israeli military vehicle . the idf said three of it soldier were moderately wounded a a result of the explosion . overnight , at least five people were reportedly killed when a family 's home in the western tal al-sultan neighbourhood wa hit in an israeli strike . they included three child , one of them a one-year-old infant , medic said . meanwhile hope of a peace deal - which seemed close earlier in the week before israel said it did not past muster - appeared to be fading . both israeli and hamas delegation left indirect talk in cairo on thursday . after seven month of war in gaza , israel insists victory is impossible without taking the city of rafah and eliminating the last remaining hamas battalion . israel launched a military campaign in gaza to destroy hamas in response to the group 's attack on southern israel on 7 october , during which about 1,200 people were killed and 252 others were taken hostage , according to israeli authority . more than 34,900 people have been killed in gaza since Body Text: even without a full-scale israeli ground invasion , rafah 's medical facility have been overwhelmed . medic say more than a million people sheltering in the southern gaza city are at risk of being deprived of healthcare after the israeli military began a `` limited `` operation against hamas on it eastern outskirt on monday . the largest of the city 's three partially functioning hospital , abu youssef al-najjar , had to be hastily abandoned the following day after staff received an evacuation order and there wa fighting nearby . the hospital 's dialysis department had been the only surviving one in gaza , a lifeline for patient suffering kidney failure . the israeli advance ha also cut off access to the nearby european gaza hospital in khan younis , where critical patient were being referred for surgery , a well a the nearby rafah and kerem shalom border crossing . with the emirati maternity hospital in rafah busy delivering dozen of baby each day , the kuwaiti specialist hospital is struggling to cope with a surge of emergency case despite a lack of capacity , staff and equipment . one doctor at the hospital , which before the war had only four intensive care bed , said the situation there wa `` catastrophic in every sense of the word `` . `` unfortunately , the kuwaiti hospital is a small hospital that doe not have diagnostic capability , `` dr jamal al-hams , it director , told bbc arabic 's gaza lifeline programme . `` even the x-ray machine is disabled due to the israeli shelling and there are no spare part for it , a the crossing are closed . `` `` and the cbc analysis device ha stopped due to being overloaded , `` he added , referring to the complete blood count test used to diagnose and monitor numerous disease . dr ham said he and his colleague were nevertheless having to treat people with complex trauma wound , burn , fracture and crushed limb . `` we have received some case of torn abdomen and intestine , and case of skull fracture with part of the brain outside the skull , `` he recalled . `` some case have lost major part of the buttock , in addition to case of amputation of the lower limb at the foot area . `` these are unusual injury caused by unusual weapon . i lived through all previous war [ in gaza ] . . . where injury were always in a certain area and dealt with by one specialist . but now each case need several specialist . `` he also expressed anger at how doctor at al-najjar hospital had been forced to evacuate both the facility and their family home at such short notice . the israeli military told all resident of a number of eastern area of rafah to leave for their own safety on monday and head towards an `` expanded humanitarian area `` stretching from nearby al-mawasi to the central town of deir al-balah , where it said there would be field hospital , tent and aid . `` where should they go ? tent and other supply were supposed to be provided in other safe area . this ha not been done , `` dr ham said . dr youssef abu al-rish , undersecretary of the hamas-run health ministry in gaza , told gaza lifeline that rafah 's remaining medical facility would no longer able to save the life of many seriously wounded or ill patient . `` rafah governorate doe not have real medical service after the abu youssef al-najjar hospital went out of service and people were unable to reach the european gaza hospital , `` he said . `` there are many field hospital , but they can not provide all these service a they do not have the necessary infrastructure or capability . . . for instance , they do not have dialysis service , oxygen-generating station , intensive care department or blood bank . `` he added : `` the kuwaiti hospital is a small non-governmental hospital that can not provide emergency service . but we are trying to enhance it capability . `` medical aid group project hope said on thursday that all of it clinic and mobile medical point in rafah were closed , and that almost all of it staff had been evacuated , with many fleeing to khan younis and deir al-balah . `` most aid service were based in rafah . now that people are further north , there is nearly no help . a long a the violence continues and the rafah border crossing remains closed , more and more people will die from preventable cause , `` said moses kondowe , it gaza team lead in rafah . mr kondowe say , `` syria `` - wa a no-go . that wa fair and mostly allowed me a way around it . it had no objection , for instance , to `` syrian territory `` or the `` syrian region `` . having to find fresh phrase can be an asset for a reporter . so it wa perfectly liveable-with and to be honest - after a lifetime of listening to that little voice - quite companionable . but high up on the windswept bureau balcony in jerusalem , the voice wa silent . there have been time like this before , and it ha always returned . but who know - this time it might be for good . and it make me feel a little bereft . when i look back , i ca n't really remember how it started but i do know that it wa - to me at least - a relatively unobtrusive part of my childhood . i wa lucky to have a relatively sheltered , privileged upbringing where if it wa noted at all , it wa seen a a vaguely charming mark of distinction . a musty old classic teacher would tell me about the great athenian rhetorician demosthenes standing on the beach with stone in his mouth to cure his stutter . it did n't really appeal . any time there wa some distance that needed to be bridged - like speaking on a phone or asking for a bus ticket - it could be a problem . anything too formal , too . and i found early on that it wa really a stammer , not a stutter . word did n't fracture and become staccato . they simply sat in the path like great unblinking toad , slyly preventing anything from getting past . but a stutter always sounded classier to me , so i 've stuck with that . it 's been everywhere with me - at school , university , work . it 's been quite remarkably even-handed in showing up in formal or casual situation . and utterly capricious , suddenly coming up with an entirely new syllable or consonant to place out of bound . people would ask : is it nerve ? are you very anxious ? which would of course give me anxiety - so i never mentioned it . this meant that if suddenly , halfway through a sentence , i wa struck dumb , people would react a if it were some biblical curse . once in jordan after a 12-hour bus journey through the endless scrubland from riyadh , i wa suddenly unable to sound out a single word , a great imaginary boulder having materialised on my tongue through the night . across the middle east , beyond the endless strife and complication , certain thing were at least clear to me - `` lebanon `` wa no problem , `` iraq `` and `` iran `` were easy - `` israel `` too - `` egypt `` a doddle - but `` tunisia `` , `` tel aviv `` and `` turkey `` were temperamental , withdrawing access at a moment 's notice . i would try to avoid listening to a fellow correspondent on the same story before going on air , in case my inner voice should triumphantly extricate the key word from their report and place it in quarantine . that voice ha however become ever more forgiving and forbearing down the year ; now it is mostly a whisper of itself . but it 's never gone away - or so i thought . maybe i wa just holding onto it a a precious fragment of a long-lost self - a sense that there wa always something latent and untapped that lay beyond the surface . a connection - semi secret - to entire world of people that were gone . a she sank ever deeper into alzheimer 's , my mother , who had helped make it so that i never felt it a burden or a hindrance , simply denied outright that my stutter had ever existed - a last link broken with the past . perhaps it 's her gentleness and elegant humour that the trace of sudden silence on my tongue still keep alive . or did . so , the next time i am lost for word , it may simply be because there are none left to convey what is happening in gaza , israel and beyond .

in the most dangerous place , at a time of unimaginable crisis . this speaks volume about his character , `` he said . kale had spent 22 year in the indian army before he opted for an early retirement ; he later worked in a private firm , his family told bbc marathi . but unhappy with a desk job , he joined the undss in april . `` waibhav kale , an indian , had nothing to do with hamas or israel or this war . but he ha sacrificed his life for peace . now , peace must be restored in gaza , `` his cousin chinmay kale told local medium . india 's mission to the un in new york said it `` deepest condolence are with the family `` of col kale . un secretary-general antónio guterres said on monday that he wa `` deeply saddened `` to learn of the worker 's death and sent his condolence to their family , mr farhan haq said in a statement . in a separate statement , mr guterres said more than 190 un staff had been killed in gaza since the war began . apart from col kale , six international aid worker and a palestinian colleague from the international food charity world central kitchen were killed in an israeli strike at the start of april . their death sparked an international outcry and the idf sacked two senior officer over the incident which it described a a `` grave accident `` . israel launched a military campaign in gaza with the stated aim of destroying hamas - which control gaza - in response to the group 's cross-border attack on southern israel on 7 october , during which about 1,200 people were killed and 252 others were taken hostage . more than 35,090 people have been killed in gaza since then , according to the territory 's hamas-run health ministry . additional reporting by malu cursino in london

's likely to be filled by chaos , `` mr blinken said.mr netanyahu ha previously insisted that discussion on the future governance of gaza are just “ empty talk ” a long a hamas remains in the regrouped there . ten of thousand of palestinian have fled the fighting and bombardment . both the israeli military and hamas 's military wing said on wednesday that battle in jabalia camp and the more than a million displaced people had been taking refuge there . the israel defense force ( idf ) said five soldier serving in the 202nd battalion of the paratrooper brigade were killed in jabalia camp on wednesday evening `` a a result of fire by our force `` . two tank in the area fired two shell at a building being used by the battalion 's deputy commander , according to a statement . `` from the initial investigation . . . it appears that the tank fighter , from the ultra-orthodox paratrooper company hetz , identified a gun barrel coming out of one of the window in the building , and directed each other to shoot at the building , `` it said . seven other soldier were wounded by the tank fire , three of them seriously . the death increased to 278 the number of israeli soldier killed since the start of the ground offensive in gaza on 27 october . another 348 troop were among the 1,200 people killed in hamas 's unprecedented cross-border attack on southern israel on 7 october , which triggered the war . some were also taken back to gaza a hostage . more than 35,270 people have been killed in gaza since then , according to the territory 's hamas-run health ministry . according to the idf 's website , 44 of the soldier killed in gaza a of wednesday - 15 % of the total - died a a result of what it describes a `` operational accident `` . twenty-two of them were killed by `` friendly fire `` , five died because of `` firing irregularity `` , and 17 a a result of `` accident `` , including incident involving weaponry and trampling . on thursday afternoon , official palestinian news agency wafa reported that four people , including a pregnant woman , had been killed in an israeli air strike on a house in the al-faluja area of jabalia camp . earlier , it said there had been intense strike in the al-hoja street area , causing it `` complete destruction `` . hamas 's military wing claimed on thursday that it had fired an anti-tank missile at an israeli nearby gaza city . palestine post photojournalist mahmoud jahjouh and several member of his family were reportedly among the dead . the idf scaled down operation in jabalia , gaza city and the rest of the north in january after declaring that it had `` dismantled `` hamas 's battalion there . but that left a power vacuum in which the group ha been able to rebuild . an estimated 300,000 people trapped in the devastated region are also experiencing a `` full-blown famine `` due to a lack of aid delivery , according to the head of the world food programme . the u announced on thursday that it come `` to a complete halt `` . these comment were echoed by the un 's aid chief , who told the reuters news agency that the humanitarian operation wa `` stuck `` . `` stock of food which were in place already in southern gaza are running out . i think we 're talking about almost none left , `` said martin griffith . meanwhile , in the south of gaza on thursday , fresh israeli air strike killed at least five people in southern and central rafah , wafa reported . the idf ha ordered the evacuation of a number of neighbourhood since 6 may , when it began what it called `` precise operation `` against hamas in `` specific area of eastern rafah and the gazan side of the rafah crossing `` . israel say it need to send troop into the city because hamas 's last remaining battalion reported death in gaza - which currently stand at more than 35,000 - ha not changed , but the un now say incomplete information ha led to the revision . the un say it is now relying on figure from the for woman and child `` the miraculous resurrection of the dead in gaza `` and accusing the un of relying on `` fake data from a terrorist organisation `` . the figure have been released in different health ministry figure , but are not broken down demographically . the number of woman and child killed is deeply contested because it is often interpreted a an indication of the number of civilian death . in a recent interview , israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu said about 30,000 people had been killed in gaza , with 14,000 of them being `` terrorist `` and 16,000 civilian . he did not provide any evidence for those figure . keeping precise record of casualty during wartime is challenging , so it is therefore not unusual for the number reported to vary , according to prof erica charter who specialises in the study of war . the initial figure for how many people were killed in hamas 's 7 october attack wa originally put at 1,400 by israeli authority , but wa later revised down to about 1,200 . at the time , the israeli authority said the misidentification of some of the burnt body wa the reason for the discrepancy . the gmo ha consistently given a higher figure for the proportion of woman and child in all fatality than ha the health ministry . on 6 may , the un reported 34,735 death - of which there were 9,500 woman and 14,500 child , citing the gmo a it source . , the number of registered death of woman ( 4.959 ) and child ( 7,797 ) had both fallen significantly . this difference wa because those individual with incomplete information were not included in the demographic breakdown . the gmo say the proportion of woman and child killed in the conflict is around 70 % . the un 's latest report , citing health ministry data , say out of 24,686 fully identified fatality , 52 % were woman and child , 40 % were men , and 8 % were `` elderly `` , without specifying whether they were male or female . it is n't clear what age the report considers to be `` elderly `` and how it categorises child . we have done our own analysis of detailed data released by the health ministry , and also found that 52 % of the fatality were listed a woman and child ( anyone under 18 ) . in addition , 43 % were men and another 5 % were `` unknown `` ( missing information such a an age or gender ) . for the gmo 's figure to be compatible with the health ministry 's data , almost all of the 10,000 death not fully identified by the ministry would have to have been woman and child . `` it 's not logically impossible . . . but it really strain credibility , `` say prof michael spagat , who specialises in examining death toll in conflict around the world . we asked the gmo why the proportion of woman and child they have recorded a killed is so much higher than in the health staggeringly high `` given the war ha only been going on for six month , noting that the verified hospital death still represent about 1 % of gaza 's pre-war population of 2.4 million . asked by bbc verify why it made the change , the un said it used the gmo data for woman and child killed because the health ministry had not been publishing these figure . `` once the ministry of health in gaza published breakdown that were more comprehensive , backed up by a list of name , the un report reflected that data instead , `` a un spokesman said . he added that in both case , the figure were attributed to their source and a `` clear note `` wa added making clear the un 's `` inability to presently provide an independent confirmation of the data `` . the un ha previously said that it ha a Body Text: south africa is asking the un 's top court to order israel to stop it military offensive in rafah in southern gaza.it is presenting it case at a two-day hearing at the international court of justice ( icj ) in the hague . israel is to deliver it response at the court on friday.south africa is also seeking to force israel to allow `` unimpeded access `` to gaza for aid worker , journalist and investigators.the court is already considering a case brought by south africa in january accusing israel of committing genocide against the palestinian in gaza . israel rejected the claim a false and `` grossly distorted `` . israel began it attack on hamas in rafah 10 day ago , amid warning from the un and others of a grave risk to civilian . more than a million displaced people had been taking refuge in rafah and nearly 600,000 have fled from there since the start of the operation.south africa 's application to the court accuses israel of carrying out `` genocidal `` operation in rafah and elsewhere in gaza , and say that it `` must be ordered to stop `` . addressing the court at the start of the hearing , south african barrister vaughan lowe kc said that `` evidence of appalling crime and atrocity is literally being destroyed and bulldozed , in effect wiping the slate clean for those who 've committed these crime and making a mockery of justice `` . held there.in january , in a highly charged case which wa closely watched around the world , the icj ordered israel to take measure to prevent potentially genocidal act in gaza . it also ordered israel to do more to enable the provision of aid to the people there . the then president of the court , joan donoghue , told the bbc last month that the icj did not decide that there wa a plausible case for genocide , but rather that the palestinian had a right to be protected from genocide , a claimed by south africa.the icj is not expected to deliver a ruling on the genocide case for several year . it ruling are legally binding , but in practice unenforceable by the court.the latest application is the fourth which south africa , whose governing party ha a long history of solidarity with the palestinian cause , ha filed with the icj against israel 's action in gaza.israel began it offensive in gaza after gunman from the ruling palestinian group hamas launched an unprecedented attack
