Body Text: the un 's top court , the international court of justice ( icj ) , ha issued a dramatic ruling , ordering israel to `` immediately halt it military offensive in rafah `` . it acted in support of a south african application last week which sought a number of measure against israel , accusing it of stepping up what it say is a genocide . presiding judge nawaf salam said the situation in gaza had deteriorated since the court last ordered israel to take step to improve it.israel ha vehemently denied the allegation and signalled it would ignore any order to halt it operation . reading the court 's ruling on friday , nawaf salam said `` israel must immediately halt it military offensive , and any other action in the rafah governorate `` which could bring about `` the physical destruction `` of the palestinian - alluding to what constitutes genocide under international law.israel , he added , must also allow unimpeded access to gaza to any un body investigating allegation of genocide.the ruling also reiterated a requirement for israel to enable `` unhindered provision at scale `` of basic service and humanitarian aid for gaza . `` the humanitarian situation [ in gaza ] is now to be characterised a disastrous , `` the ruling said.israel rejected the court 's ruling and said it military offensive in gaza wa in line with international law . `` israel ha not and will not carry out military operation in the rafah area that create living condition that could cause the destruction of the palestinian civilian population , in whole or in part , `` national security adviser tzachi hanegbi said in a joint statement with the foreign ministry.war cabinet minister benny gantz said israel would continue it offensive `` wherever and whenever necessary - including in rafah `` . meanwhile , the palestinian ambassador to the un , riyad mansour , hailed the ruling and called for israel to abide by it . `` we expect that resolution of the icj be implemented without hesitation , `` he said . `` that 's mandatory . and israel is party to the convention . `` following news of the icj ruling , the european union 's top diplomat , josep borrell , said the bloc 's commitment to the rule of law and it support for israel `` are going to be quite difficult to make compatible `` . aid agency and the un say insufficient amount of aid are reaching people in gaza , which they say is facing famine.the un suspended food distribution in rafah on tuesday because of the perilous situation there . israel say it ha made `` extensive effort `` to ensure that humanitarian aid is `` flowing into gaza `` . judge salam also said that the court found it `` deeply troubling `` that israeli hostage were still being held by hamas and other armed group in gaza , and called for `` their immediate and unconditional release `` . israeli opposition leader yair lapid criticised the ruling , calling it an `` abject moral failure `` that the icj did not connect their bombardment of rafah to the release of the hostages.south africa 's foreign ministry chief zane dangor called the ruling `` groundbreaking `` , alluding to it being the first time the court ha made an explicit order to israel to halt action in a part of gaza.hamas said it welcomed the decision which it said `` demand that the brutal zionist entity [ israel ] stop it aggression `` in rafah `` . minute after the ruling wa delivered , israel warplane carried out a series of air strike on the shaboura camp in the centre of rafah.a local activist at nearby kuwait hospital told the bbc that rescue team in the hospital were unable to reach the site of the raid due to their intensity.israel began a long-anticipated offensive in rafah about three week ago , vowing to destroy the remaining hamas battalion there . it say it belief israeli hostage are also being held in the town.the un say more than 800,000 palestinian have fled from rafah since the offensive began . about 1.5 million had been sheltering there from the fighting elsewhere in gaza . the hearing is part of a case brought by south africa to the icj in december , claiming israel wa committing genocide in gaza . that case is ongoing . israel began it offensive in gaza after gunman from hamas , the organisation which ruled the territory , attacked israel on 7 october , killing about 1,200 people and taking 252 others back to gaza a hostages.at least 35,800 palestinian have been killed in the war since then , according to gaza 's hamas-run health ministry .

Body Text: the war in gaza is being fought on many fronts.one of them is aid.months after some israeli started to protest against aid lorry entering gaza at the main kerem shalom crossing , the battle ha moved to other key junction , where rival group of activist do their best to block or protect aid convoys.in recent week , social medium ha been flooded with image of aid lorry being blocked and ransacked.right-wing activist , including jewish settler living in the occupied west bank , have uploaded dozen of video of crowd , including some very young child , hurling food onto the ground and stamping on box of aid . “ it ’ s important to stop the aid , ” one activist say . “ it ’ s the only way we ’ ll win . the only way we ’ ll get our hostage back . ” many argue that gazans should receive nothing while israeli hostage remain in captivity , and that providing aid to gaza merely serf to prolong the war.in one video , a group of jubilant protester dance and celebrate on top of a looted lorry.in another , one of the stranded lorry is ablaze.other video show israeli vigilante stopping lorry in jerusalem and demanding that driver show paper proving they are not transporting aid to gaza . their face are uncovered and they appear to be acting with complete impunity.in the west bank , at least two driver who were not carrying good bound for gaza were dragged from their cab and beaten.palestinian lorry driver say they ’ re traumatised . “ i ’ m terrified to reach the crossing point , ” adel amro told the bbc . “ i fear for my life . ” mr amro wa carrying commercially purchased good from the west bank to gaza when he wa set upon . other targeted driver are involved in transporting aid from jordan , which ha to cross the west bank and israel before it reach gaza . “ we ’ re now taking side road , far from the main route , because we fear the aggressiveness of the settler , ” he said . but after a series of well-documented attack , some israeli are fighting back.peace activist have taken to tracking their opponent ’ movement on social medium and making sure they ’ re present at key crossing points.at tarqumiya checkpoint , where lorry enter israel from the southern west bank , member of the group standing together are now mounting regular vigils.tarqumiya wa the scene of one of the most dramatic recent attack . “ people in gaza are starving and aid should get to gaza , ” said suf patishi , one of standing together ’ s founding member . “ israeli society should say in a loud and clear voice that we are opposed to these act , ” he said of the recent attack on convoy . “ it ’ s not a lot to ask , not to die from hunger , you know . ” the group brings together jew and arab from all over israel.for nasser odat , an israeli arab from haifa , coming to tarqumiya provided a welcome opportunity to feel useful , after more than seven month of helplessly watching the war in gaza . “ i feel very empowered , ” he said . “ now , finally , i have something to do to help . to help these people that are starving . ” a the peace activist sheltered from the fierce sun under palm tree at the centre of a roundabout , passing lorry driver waved and sounded their horn in gratitude.a small group of right-wing demonstrator arrived but were heavily outnumbered by mr patishi ’ s volunteers.the two side debated their differing position in discussion that became increasingly heated.police officer stood nearby , ready to keep the opposing camp apart if it came to blows.the peace activist have accused the police , under the control of national security minister itamar ben-gvir , one of the most hardline member of benjamin netanyahu ’ s government , of doing little to stop the attacks.they say there ’ s evidence that settler are receiving help from the authority and point to text message in which group organising attack on aid lorry solicit and receive help from the police and army . “ a lot of time the police were in the area when attack occur , but they did n't have someone to push them to act , ” mr patishi said . “ and it 's very sad because the police should keep the law . ” a lorry drove by , two young woman waved an israeli flag but stopped short of trying to stop the traffic.the two , who asked to be identified a ariel and shira ( not their real name ) , explained why they felt it wa important to be there . “ we would prefer that we don ’ t have to do the blockage , honestly , ” ariel said . “ i don ’ t like ransacking thing . it ’ s not one of my favourite hobby . but we prefer that to the death of our friend and family , which is what happens the longer this war drag on . `` both woman recognised that there might be starvation in gaza , but were convinced that hamas wa stealing and stockpiling aid rather than distributing it to people in need.and they were not worried about what sort of image of israel wa being projected by the scene of aid lorry being stopped , ransacked and set on fire . “ it ’ s time to stop caring what everybody else think , ” shira said , “ and do what ’ s necessary to protect my life , to protect my family . ” a for the police , ariel wa dismissive . “ they aren ’ t going to interfere if they aren ’ t certain they ’ re able to shut it down , ” she said . “ they ’ re not going to start something they can ’ t finish . ”

Body Text: the day after might sound like the title of a film or a novel . but for diplomat and policymakers , the phrase ha only one meaning and that is what happens ' the day after ' the fighting stop in gaza . given the intensity of the conflict and the absence of hope , such thinking might seem surprising , even wishful . yet there is an increasing focus on what could and should happen if and when the gun fall silent in gaza . eu foreign minister will discus exactly this in brussels on monday when they hold talk with counterpart from jordan , egypt , qatar , saudi arabia and the uae , along with the secretary-general of the arab league . across the middle east and among western country , conversation are taking place and plan are being drawn up . many are aware the window of opportunity before the u election in november is closing . despite all this , however , there seems little agreement about what should happen and when . for the three european nation which will formally recognise the state of palestine this week - norway , spain and ireland - the focus is to revive discussion about a two-state solution , which for year ha been little more than a slogan to which politician pay lip service . they hope talk of a political `` day after `` will open a way towards a ceasefire and the release of hostage . `` the only pathway to peace is political , `` said ireland 's taoiseach simon harris . for british minister , the focus is how best to support the palestinian authority ( pa ) so it could potentially help govern post-war gaza . the foreign secretary , lord cameron , told the house of lord this week that he wa pushing israel to stop withholding money from the pa . not only is israel denying the pa tax revenue , far-right finance minister belazel smotrich is also threatening to cut palestinian bank off from their israeli counterpart . lord cameron said he had told the israeli government : `` you may not think the palestinian authority is ideal Body Text: a temporary pier built by the u military to deliver aid to gaza ha been damaged by heavy sea and will take at least a week to be repaired , according to u official . u force began building the floating pier - which is attached to gaza 's shoreline by a temporary causeway - several week ago.the causeway portion of the project ha now reportedly broken off and will have to be repaired before being returned to it position . humanitarian organisation have warned that the amount of aid reaching palestinian in gaza is only a fraction of what is required to meet the need of it population . the pier , which wa first announced by u official in march , is comprised of two main component : a large floating dock made up of steel segment and a two-lane , 1,800ft ( 548m ) causeway and pier . the causeway part of the project is composed of a series of interconnected , 40ft ( 12m ) steel piece linked together and attached to shore . on tuesday , the pentagon confirmed that a portion of the causeway broke away in heavy sea . while it is tethered to gaza 's shoreline , the piece will need to be removed and taken to the israeli port of ashod to be repaired before it can be re-attached to the causeway and back in action . according to pentagon spokeswoman sabrina singh , the pier will be removed over the next two day with the help of the israeli navy . the repair will take more than a week , she added . m singh said weather condition in the area had not created an `` optimal environment `` for the pier 's deployment , but that defence official remain confident it would be operational again soon . `` i ca n't predict the weather , `` she said . “ but we believe that given the time of year , we will be able to re-anchor this pier . `` mick mulroy , a former deputy assistant secretary of defence for the middle east and one of the founder of fogbow , a private firm involved in the gaza pier plan , told the bbc that weather-related delay were `` expected `` to `` pose challenge `` . `` but those challenge can be overcome , and the mission itself is worth the effort , `` he said . `` people are in desperate need of aid and this is one mean to deliver it . and evacuated to a hospital in israel.the reuters news agency quoted the un world food programme ( wfp ) spokesperson a saying that the un ha transported a total of 137 lorry of aid from the pier - approximately 900 metric tonne - since it began operating . at the white house on tuesday , national security council spokesman john kirby said the pier wa never expected to `` supplant `` aid reaching gaza via land crossing , but instead could be a `` force multiplier `` . the pentagon estimate that more than 1,000 tonne have been delivered to shore , with just over 900 tonne reaching un warehouse . despite mounting concern over the worsening humanitarian situation in gaza , israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu ha said he remains committed to `` total victory `` in rafah , hamas ' last remaining urban stronghold in the south of the strip . israel 's military campaign in gaza began after gunman from hamas attacked israel on 7 october , killing about 1,200 people and taking 252 others to gaza a hostages.more than 36,000 palestinian have been killed in the war since then , according to gaza 's hamas-run health ministry .

Body Text: the un 's top court , the international court of justice ( icj ) , issued a ruling last week on israel 's military offensive in rafah.it wa the latest pronouncement by the court in a case brought by south africa , which accuses israel of a genocide in the gaza strip . israel ha vehemently denied the allegation.since the case began , the court ha delivered a series of contested rulings.the two most important concern whether or not the court ha suggested there is a risk of genocide in gaza . the second ruling - delivered on 24 may - includes hotly disputed wording over the military operation in rafah.it is now being intensively scrutinised and argued over . in last week ’ s order , the court ruled by 13 vote to two that israel should : “ immediately halt it military offensive , and any other action in the rafah governorate , which may inflict on the palestinian group in gaza condition of life that could bring about it physical destruction in whole or in part . ” headline suggested this wa an order to stop all military operation in rafah - but some of the judge disagree with what it means.five of the 15 published their own view . three had supported the order and two had opposed it . judge bogdan aurescu from romania said he voted for the order , but revealed that he thought the court wa being “ unclear ” and underlined that it could not ban israel from taking legitimate action in self-defence.judge dire tladi , from south africa , disagreed with aurescu , even though they had voted for the same order . he said it told israel “ in explicit term ” to stop it offensive in rafah.the two judge who had opposed the order declared that whatever the others had voted in favour of , it wa surely not a demand for israel to begin a unilateral ceasefire in rafah.uganda ’ s julia sebutinde said the court could not “ micromanage ” a war and israel ’ s aharon barak , temporarily-appointed for the case , said the icj ’ s order wa “ qualified ” so long a the country adhered to the genocide convention.the summary from germany ’ s judge , georg nolte , is the most revealing to where the court find itself.the order , a he voted for it , banned military action “ a far a it could endanger the right of the palestinian people ” to be protected from a risk of genocide . but he stressed : “ the court can play only a limited role in resolving the situation . it must be careful not to overstep the limit of what it can and should do . ”

Body Text: the u doe not believe israel 's action in rafah amount to a `` major ground operation `` that could cross a red line for president joe biden and trigger a possible change in u policy , the white house ha said.spokesman john kirby addressed reporter hour after israeli force reached the centre of the city in southern gaza , and reportedly seized a strategically important hill.mr biden recently said he would limit weapon supply to israel if it entered rafah 's “ population centre ” , where hundred of thousand of civilian are still believed to be sheltering.mr kirby wa also questioned about an israeli strike and a resulting fire that killed at least 45 palestinian on sunday . many of them were woman , child , or elderly , who were sheltering at a camp for displaced people.israel ha said the strike targeted and killed two senior hamas official , and that it belief the fire could have been caused by an explosion at a hamas weapon store nearby.speaking to reporter , mr kirby described image from the aftermath of the strike a `` heartbreaking `` and `` horrific `` . “ there should be no innocent life lost here a a result of this conflict , `` he added.the u state department said it wa watching closely for the israeli military to conduct a quick and thorough investigation into the strike.pressed by bbc correspondent tom bateman on whether previous such investigation had led to accountability , state department spokesman matthew miller declined to name specific case . “ you can not reach a conclusion about the result of these investigation in the middle of a conflict , ” he said.when the white house spokesman wa asked whether the strike had violated the limit previously set by president biden , he said he had `` no policy change to speak to `` . “ we do n't support , we wo n't support a major ground operation in rafah , ” mr kirby said . “ the president said that , should that occur , then it might make him have to make different decision in term of support . “ we have n't seen that happen at this point . we have not seen them smash into rafah . `` we have not seen them go in with large unit , large number of troop , in column and formation in some sort of co-ordinated manoeuvre against multiple target on the ground . `` israel ha insisted it will not be able to achieve victory in it seven-month war against hamas in gaza without taking rafah and rejected warning of catastrophic humanitarian consequences.the israel defense force ( idf ) first began what it called “ targeted ” ground operation against hamas fighter and infrastructure in the east of rafah on 6 may.since then , tank and troop have gradually pushed into built-up eastern and central area while also moving northward along the 13km ( 8-mile ) border with egypt.speaking to cnn on 8 may , president biden said he had made it clear to israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu that “ if they go into rafah , i ’ m not supplying the weapon that have been used historically to deal with rafah , to deal with the city , to deal with that problem ” . he said he had not suspended the supply of weapon at that point because israel had not yet “ gone into the population centre ” in rafah and that it operation had been “ right on the border ” . the president is facing growing call at home to put greater pressure on the israeli government to ensure everything is done to minimise the humanitarian impact of the conflict.democratic senator chris van hollen , who visited gaza in january , told the washington post : “ the escalating civilian death toll and deepening humanitarian catastrophe make clear that the biden administration should pause additional offensive military assistance to the netanyahu government until we know that all the president ’ s request , including with respect to rafah and the urgent delivery of humanitarian assistance , will be respected . ” in an address to the israeli parliament on monday , mr netanyahu said sunday 's strike had been a `` tragic mishap `` but vowed to continue with the rafah operation.describing the aftermath of the strike , mohammad al-mughayyir , an official with gaza ’ s hamas-run civil defence agency , wa quoted a saying by afp news agency : `` we saw charred body and dismembered limb . we also saw case of amputation , wounded child woman , and the elderly . ” an eyewitness named muhannad , himself a displaced resident of gaza , described the air strike : `` when we heard the sound the sky suddenly lit up . `` hamad , another man at the scene , told afp : `` when these rocket fall on a tower block there are dozen of martyr , so what about when they are tent ? `` the attack ha drawn protest from regional government , including egypt and qatar who have acted a mediator in the conflict , a well a jordan , kuwait , saudi arabia and turkey.egypt said the strike wa part of a “ systematic policy ” intended to make gaza “ uninhabitable ” and qatar described it a a `` dangerous violation of international law `` that could “ complicate ongoing mediation effort `` . jordan accused israel of `` ongoing war crime `` , while saudi arabia condemned the “ continued massacre `` , and turkish president recep tayyip erdogan vowed `` to hold these barbarian and murderer accountable `` . the un ha said around a million people have now fled the fighting in rafah but that several hundred thousand more could still be sheltering there.residents of the city reported heavy bombardment of western district overnight on monday , and on tuesday the idf said it wa continuing operation against `` terror target `` . witness said israeli tank were stationed at al-awda roundabout , a key landmark and the location of several major bank and government institutions.an eyewitness told the bbc that israeli soldier had taken up position on top of a building overlooking the area and started shooting at any movement . the allegation could not be independently verified . speaking from rafah on tuesday , sam rose , a spokesman for unrwa , the un ’ s humanitarian agency for palestinian refugee , told bbc news : `` what we 've witnessed over the past 24 hour is an intensification of the bombardment in rafah , and military operation [ which are ] pushing further west into the tal al-sultan district of the city . `` that includes the tented camp that wa hit a couple of night ago . it also includes a large unrwa logistics base and the unrwa health centre which is essentially the beating heart of the humanitarian operation in rafah , and ha been for several month . `` these part of the city have largely emptied out over the past 24 hour . so real concern , real numbness , real fear amongst the population right now . `` the israeli military ha denied report on tuesday that it tank shell hit another tent camp in al-mawasi , on the coast west of rafah , which local official said had killed at least 21 people.videos of the incident posted to social medium and analysed by bbc verify showed multiple people with serious injuries.there wa no clear sign of a blast zone or crater , making it impossible to ascertain the cause of the incident . the location - verified through reference to surrounding building - lie south of the israeli military 's designated humanitarian zone.israel launched a military campaign in gaza to destroy hamas in response to the group 's cross-border attack on southern israel on 7 october , during which about 1,200 people were killed and 252 others were taken hostage.at least 36,090 people have been killed in gaza since then , according to the hamas-run health ministry .

Body Text: three police officer have been injured during a demonstration in westminster organised by the palestine solidarity campaign and other group . one officer suffered a serious facial injury after she wa hit with a bottle thrown from within the crowd , the metropolitan police said . the met said the suspect had not yet been identified but that police were investigating.40 arrest related to assault on emergency worker , obstruction of the highway and public order act breach were made , the force said . the protest began in whitehall at 18:00 bst and wa due to end two hour later . police said the `` vast majority `` of protester - between 8,000 and 10,000 people - left without incident at the scheduled time . a group of about 500 remained and continued to protest . the met said some resisted arrest , which required officer `` to use force `` to remove them from the crowd.a breakaway march then made it way to bridge street , outside westminster station , where police put cordon in place.officers went into the crowd shortly before 22:00 to arrest those suspected of leading the breakaway protest.the palestine solidarity campaign said it had organised the emergency march to reiterate call for a ceasefire in gaza , following an israeli air strike and resulting fire that killed at least 45 palestinian on sunday .

alongside serbia and slovakia - in march.having drawn in serbia and beaten the slovak at hampden in their first two game , the scot were always scheduled to host israel in back-to-back matches.in the aftermath of the 7 october attack by hamas and the israeli government 's military response , european football 's governing body , uefa , decided no match in it own competition could be held in israel for security reasons.as a result , hungary ha mostly been the home of both israel 's men 's and woman 's football team in the past seven months.club side maccabi tel aviv and maccabi haifa played europa league and europa conference league game in hungary a well.that 's why tuesday 's return tie with scotland is taking place in budapest.despite moving game out of israel , uefa ha always been clear that israeli side would continue to play match in continental competitions.that ha come despite some pressure to exclude israel and it team , a uefa and fifa did to russia after it invasion of ukraine in 2022 . `` there wa no such discussion or such intention from the uefa administration , `` general secretary theodore theodoridis said in february . `` these are two completely different situation of two country . `` an automatic forfeit applies if a team - such a scotland - refuse to play a match.uefa can also open disciplinary proceeding , which could result in disqualification from the competition altogether . fifa , which governs world football , is currently taking legal advice on a motion submitted by the palestinian football association to suspend israel from the sport.earlier this month , gianni infantino - president of world football 's governing body , fifa - consulted lawyer on whether israel ha breached it regulation and delayed a decision until 25 july , when it executive committee is expected to vote.the palestinian football authority have been backed by jordan and other middle east associations.the israeli fa labelled the move `` cynical `` . scotland head coach pedro martinez losa addressed the situation two week ago in a medium conference after naming his squad.the spaniard said his opinion on the subject `` doe n't matter `` a uefa ha sanctioned the match - and said his focus is on doing the job on the pitch.it wa a view echoed on tuesday by goalkeeper lee gibson , who wa clear that the player were guided by those making the decision . `` we just have to focus on the game itself , `` the 32-year-old said . `` we 're footballer and our priority is to make sure , when we go on the pitch , we perform . `` everything else is dealt with by the scottish fa and uefa . `` last week , the sfa took the decision to play friday 's game at hampden behind closed door without any fan after being `` alerted to the potential for planned disruption to the match `` . it added that it `` no option `` but to act `` following extensive security consultation with all key party `` . public demonstration against israel 's military operation in gaza have been happening regularly across the uk.one group - the gaza genocide emergency committee - ha arranged a protest before the game at hampden and called for the match to be cancelled.police scotland say : `` appropriate policing plan are in place to maintain public safety and minimise any disruption to the community . `` tuesday 's return game in budapest will also be played behind closed door .

star of david reminiscent of the israeli flag were stencilled on several wall in paris.a moldovan couple wa arrested , who french official believe were paid by russian intelligence.last month , red hand were painted on a holocaust memorial in paris , and police believe the perpetrator fled abroad.according to le monde newspaper , quoting a source in the investigation , one of the individual held on saturday had been in telephone contact with a bulgarian suspect wanted for the red-hands affair . le monde named this suspect a 34 year-old georgi f.moscow reacted angrily last month to president emmanuel macron ’ s repeated refusal to rule out sending soldier to ukraine.last week , ukrainian official confirmed that discussion had been held over the despatch of french military instructors.this could provide the context for the coffin affair , investigator think , with russian intelligence seeking to show that there is big opposition to deeper french involvement in the ukraine war.in both the star of david and red-hands affair , the team included a photographer whose picture subsequently appeared on internet site linked to russian propaganda .

whose journalist nir hasson wa among those assaulted - reported that hundred of young men rampaged through the muslim quarter before the event began , chanting “ death to arab ” and attacking palestinian and other people . the flag march is always tense , but fear of violence were higher this year because of the war in gaza.israel ’ s far-right national security minister , itamar ben-gvir , took part in the march and said at the start that it wa sending a message to hamas that “ jerusalem is ours ” . “ with the help of god , the full victory is ours , `` he added.meanwhile , prime minister benjamin netanyahu told a special meeting in honour of jerusalem day that israel wa `` surrounded by enemy `` a it had been 57 year ago . `` they thought to strangle u , to wipe u off the map . but we are an ancient people , a people of brave fighter . we stood up a one and we defended ourselves , `` he said . `` we are also doing so today against hamas in the south , hezbollah in the north and iran in the east . ” hamas ’ s political leader , ismail haniyeh , condemned what he called the “ rampage of settler ” in jerusalem . “ our people will not rest until the occupation end , ” he vowed.jerusalem , with it major muslim , jewish and christian holy site , is at the heart of the decades-old israeli-palestinian conflict.israel - which occupied the formerly jordanian-held east of the city in 1967 , and effectively annexed it in 1980 in a move not recognised by most country - regard the whole of jerusalem a it capital.palestinian leader want east jerusalem - which is home to about 350,000 palestinian and 230,000 israeli settler - to be the capital of a future independent palestinian state.on the day of the israeli flag march in 2021 , hamas fired rocket at jerusalem , triggering a war in gaza that lasted 11 days.the current war began when hamas attacked southern israel on 7 october , killing about 1,200 people and taking 251 others a hostages.at least 36,580 people have been killed in gaza since then , the territory 's hamas-run health ministry say .

Body Text: an israeli air strike on a un school packed with displaced palestinian in central gaza ha reportedly killed at least 35 people.local journalist told the bbc that a warplane fired two strike on a hamas compound ” in the school and killed many of the 20 to 30 fighter it believed were inside.gaza ’ s hamas-run government medium office denied the claim and accused israel of carrying week . the bbc is working to verify the report about the strike in nuseirat camp.local journalist and resident said it took place in the early hour of thursday at al-sardi school , which is in a south-eastern area of the densely-populated , decades-old camp , where unrwa provides services.unrwa said 6,000 displaced people were sheltering in the school complex at the time . many school and other un facility have been used a shelter by the 1.7 million people who have fled their home during the war , which ha lasted almost eight months.videos shared on social medium showed the destruction of several classroom in one of the school 's building , a well a body wrapped in white shroud and blanket . “ i wa asleep when the incident occurred . suddenly , we heard a loud explosion and shattered glass and debris from the building fell on u , ” udai abu elia , a man who wa living at the school , told bbc arabic 's gaza today programme . “ smoke filled the air , and i could n't see anything . i did n't expect to make it out alive . i heard someone calling for survivor to come out from under the rubble . i struggled to see a i stumbled over the body of the martyr . ” he added : “ the situation ha become extremely difficult , especially for child and the elderly . everyone is a target . the blood of the martyr ha not yet dried ; it stain the stair , wall , and bedding . `` another man , jabr , said he “ woke up to the sight of body and [ human ] remains everywhere ” , while a third who asked not to be named said the casualty included `` elderly people , young individual , and child `` . resident initially said that more than 20 people were killed in the attack.later , an official at al-aqsa hospital told a freelance journalist working for the bbc that it had received 40 body from the school.gaza ’ s hamas-run health ministry said 40 people were killed , including 14 child and nine woman , and 74 others were injured . the same death toll wa given by the director of the hamas-run government medium office , ismail al-thawabta.unwa 's commissioner general , philippe lazzarini , said in a statement on x , formerly twitter , that at least 35 people were killed and many more injured . the agency ’ s director of communication , juliette touma , told the bbc that `` the figure are coming from our own unrwa colleague on the ground `` . the bbc ha been reviewing video and ha not yet seen conclusive evidence of civilian casualty at the scene of the strike . however , there is footage showing child casualty at al-aqsa hospital.us state department spokesperson matt miller urged israel to be transparent over the strike . `` `` the government of israel ha said that they are going to release more information about this strike , including the name of those who died in it . we expect them to be fully transparent in making that information public , `` he said . in a statement , the israel defense force ( idf ) said jet had conducted a `` precise strike on a hamas compound embedded inside `` the school . an annotated aerial photograph highlighted classroom on two upper floor of the building , which the idf said were the “ location of the terrorist ” . the idf said member of hamas and palestinian islamic jihad who took part in the 7 october attack on southern israel , when around 1,200 people were killed and 251 others were taken hostage , had been operating in the building . “ before the strike , a number of step were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilian during the strike , including conducting aerial surveillance , and additional intelligence information , ” it added . later , idf spokesman lt col peter lerner told reporter that between 20 and 30 fighter had been using the school to plan and carry out attack , and that many of them were killed in the strike . `` i 'm not aware of any civilian casualty and i 'd be very , very cautious of accepting anything that hamas put out , `` he added.he also said the idf had called off the attack twice in order to limit civilian casualty and accused hamas and palestinian islamic jihad of deliberately using un facility a operational bases.mr thawabta rejected the idf ’ s claim , saying : “ the occupation us lying to the public opinion through false fabricated story to justify the brutal crime it conducted against dozen of displaced people . ” mr lazzarini said the school wa hit “ without prior warning ” to his agency or the people sheltering there . “ claim that armed group may have been inside the shelter are shocking . we are however unable to verify these claim , ” he added . “ attacking , targeting or using un building for military purpose are a blatant disregard of international humanitarian law . un staff , premise and operation must be protected at all time . ” mr lazzarini complained that more than 180 unrwa building had been hit since the war began despite their co-ordinate being shared with party to the conflict , and that more than 450 displaced people had been killed a a result.at least 36,650 people have been killed in gaza since israel launched a military campaign in response to the 7 october attack , according to the territory 's health ministry , whose figure do not differentiate between civilian and combatants.medics also told afp and palestinian news agency wafa that another pre-dawn strike on thursday killed six people at a house in nuseirat camp.the idf meanwhile said troop had located underground tunnel shaft and weapon in eastern area of bureij refugee camp - just west of nuseirat - and eastern deir al-balah , a day after it said they had taken `` operational control `` there.residents reported intense bombardment in the area on wednesday , while médecins sans frontières said at least 70 body - the majority woman and child - had been brought to al-aqsa hospital over the previous 24 hours.the idf also said on thursday that troop and aircraft had killed three suspect who had approached the gaza-israel border fence in the rafah area , and that an israeli soldier had been killed in battle in southern gaza . last month , there wa global outrage after an israeli air strike , which the idf said targeted two senior hamas official , and a resulting fire reportedly killed dozen of palestinian at a tented camp for displaced people near a unrwa logistics base in the southern city of rafah . the idf said the loss of life wa “ tragic ” and that it wa investigating the possibility that ammunition stored by hamas could have caused a secondary explosion.that incident prompted mediator to revive their effort to broker a ceasefire and hostage release deal between israel and hamas.us president joe biden outlined what he described a an israeli proposal that had been presented to hamas.the first phase of the plan would last six week and include a temporary truce that would see the release of some of the hostage still being held in gaza in return for palestinian from israeli jail . the second phase would include a permanent cessation of hostilities.on thursday , the u , uk and 16 other country with citizen among the hostage issued a joint statement calling on the leader of israel and hamas “ to make whatever final compromise are necessary to close this deal and bring relief to the family of our hostage ” . hamas political leader ismail haniyeh said on wednesday that the group would deal `` seriously and positively `` with a proposal based on an end to the war and a full israeli withdrawal from gaza.israel 's prime minister benjamin netanyahu ha insisted he will not agree to a permanent ceasefire before hamas is defeated and the hostage are released . on wednesday , he declared the country wa “ striving for total victory ” . additional reporting by george wright in london

abroad , it said.israel say it is facilitating the entry of aid through the other point of entry in southern gaza , kerem shalom . on monday cogat , the israeli defence ministry body that coordinate humanitarian aid to gaza , insisted that the gaza side of kerem shalon wa `` at full capacity `` , with `` the content of over 1,000 aid truck waiting to be picked up by un aid agency `` . however city to move south of the wadi gaza riverbed . it subsequent assault on other area including the city of khan younis displaced palestinian further south.the war wa triggered by hamas ’ s unprecedented Body Text: four hostage have been rescued by the israeli military from central gaza , in an operation that wa week in the planning.for israeli it brought celebration and relief . for palestinian it brought more suffering , with hospital saying dozen of people - including child - were killed in the raid on the densely populated nuseirat camp.dubbed “ seed of summer ” , the raid wa unusually carried out in the daytime – which the israel defense force say allowed it a better element of surprise.the mid-morning timing meant the street were busy with people shopping at a nearby market.it also meant greater risk to israel ’ s special force , not only getting in , but especially getting out.one special force officer wa wounded and died in hospital , israel police said . “ it wa on a scale like entebbe , ” according to the idf ’ s chief spokesperson rear admiral daniel hagari referencing israel 's rescue of 100 hostage in uganda in 1976.acting on intelligence , and after crossing into gaza from israel , he said specialist commando simultaneously raided two residential apartment in nuseirat where the hostage were being held.in one apartment wa 26-year-old hostage noa argamani . in the other were 41-year-old shlomi ziv , 27-year-old andrey kozlov and almog meir jan , 22.mr hagari said they were not in cage but in locked room surrounded by guards.he said israeli commando , having forced their way in , seized the hostage wrapping themselves around them to provide protective shield before bundling them into military vehicle outside.as they left he said they faced fierce resistance from palestinian fighters.mr hagari said israel ’ s military had planned the raid in great detail , even building mock-up of the two apartment to train in.the u also provided intelligence support to israel for the operation , according to the bbc 's partner cbs news which cited two u officials.mobile phone video from the scene show people diving for cover a missile whistled in and gunfire rang out.later footage showed body strewn in the street . the raid clearly involved massive force . doctor at the two hospital in central gaza said they had counted more than 70 body . mr hagari estimated less than a hundred , while the hamas medium office said more than 200 had been killed . the bbc ha been unable to verify the number of casualty . “ i have gathered the body part of my child , my dear child ” nora abu khamees , sheltering in nuseirat , told the bbc a she crumpled in tear . “ my other child is between life and death . even my husband and my mother in law , our whole family is destroyed . this is a genocide . ” ten-year-old areej al zahdneh , speaking at a nearby hospital , told u there were airstrikes , tank and shooting . “ we couldn ’ t breathe . my sister reemaz wa hit by shrapnel in her head and my five year old sister yara wa also hit my shrapnel . ”

israel 's force , backed by air strike , fought intense gun battle with hamas in and around the nuseirat refugee camp , freeing the captives.noa argamani , 26 , almog meir jan , 22 , andrei kozlov , 27 , and shlomi ziv , 41 , who were abducted from the nova music festival on 7 october have been returned to israel.the israeli military ha estimated that fewer than 100 people died in the operation.but the latest figure from the hamas-run health ministry in gaza would , if confirmed , make it one of the deadliest day of the conflict so far.people living in the densely-populated area celebration in israel and world leader , including u president joe biden , have welcomed the news of their release.but there ha been mounting criticism of the deadly cost of the operation inside gaza , with european union foreign affair chief josep borrell saying he condemned it `` in the strongest term `` . `` report from gaza of another massacre of civilian are appalling , `` he wrote on x.an israeli minister said that instead of condemning hamas for hiding behind civilian , the eu had condemned israel for saving it citizen . image from the nuseirat refugee camp area show intense bombardment and people mourning the dead.two hospital in gaza , al-aqsa hospital and al-awda hospital , said they had counted 70 body between them . the hamas-run health ministry released name of 86 people out of the 274 palestinian it say were killed during the two-hour operation.previously , israel 's military spokesman daniel hagari estimated there were fewer than 100 casualty in what wa a `` high-risk , complex mission `` based on `` precise intelligence `` . defence minister yoav gallant said special force operated `` under heavy fire `` when rescuing the hostage . one special force officer wa wounded and later died in hospital . video from gaza taken in the aftermath of the raid show scene of carnage.footage from the al-aqsa hospital show numerous people with severe injury laying on the ground , leaving barely any space on the blood-stained floor for doctor to move between patients.other video show a frequent stream of new case being driven in by car and ambulance and carried into the building.the director of the al-awda hospital in nuseirat told bbc arabic the number of dead coming to the hospital increased throughout saturday.dr marwan abu nasser also spoke about the lack of a morgue in the hospital to accommodate the body of those killed who had been taken to the hospital . one man , who said more than 40 member of his family have been killed since the conflict began in october , described to the bbc being in a house which wa hit by a strike . `` a soon a these child and woman entered the house , the bombing attack took place , claiming the life of all those inside it , `` he said , `` this home , which used to house approximately 30 people who then became 50 , wa bombed . . . only me , my father , my wife , and a young man survived . . . we are the only survivor out of 50 people . `` the bloodshed on the ground prompted a rare venting of criticism at hamas from people in gaza.hassan omar , 37 , said he lamented the unnecessary loss of life in israeli strike , telling the bbc : `` for each israeli hostage they could have freed 80 palestinian prisoner and without any bloodshed - [ that ] is a million time better than losing 100 dead . `` my message to hamas is stopping the loss is part of the gain , we should get rid of those who control u from qatar hotel . ” the rescue of hostage came amid effort for a ceasefire and hostage release deal between israel and hamas.israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu ha been urged to reach an agreement but face opposition from far-right ally who say military action is the only way to bring the jails.on saturday , the hamas-run health ministry said the death toll in gaza is now 37,084 people .

Body Text: labour and the conservative have been challenged over how they would fund their election pledge , ahead of their manifesto being launched next week . the independent institute for fiscal study ha warned the next government would have to cut the scope of what the state provides or increase tax to maintain level of departmental spending . both party have said they will not raise the rate of income tax , national insurance or vat . on the campaign trail on sunday , labour announced plan to build more prison , while the tory focused on welfare reform and the liberal democrat on support for carers . speaking on a visit to essex , labour leader sir keir starmer refused to rule out spending cut to public service but said his party would `` not be raising tax on working people `` . `` all of our plan are fully funded and fully costed and none of them require tax rise over and above the one that we 've already announced , `` he said . labour ha already said it would end tax break for private school which exempt them from vat and close the loophole allowing some people with non-dom status to avoid paying tax in the uk if it win power . it ha also promised a time-limited windfall tax on the excess profit of oil and gas company . asked if he could rule out spending cut , sir keir said : `` we are not returning to austerity . we will grow our economy . `` however , the scottish national party challenged sir keir to `` finally start being straight with the public and explain where the labour axe will fall on public service `` . the party said £ 18bn of public service cut were coming down the line `` because of the decision made by both the conservative and sir keir starmer 's labour party `` . live : follow the latest news about the uk general electionpoll tracker these include £ 1.3bn to allow higher earner to keep child benefit payment , £ 2.4bn to raise the tax-free pension allowance and £ 2.5bn to introduce mandatory national service for 18 year olds.mr stride said his party would pay for these policy by raising £ 6bn from cracking down on tax avoidance . asked why this had not already been done already by past conservative government , mr stride said : `` we have been doing it and there ’ s more we can do . `` meanwhile , reform uk ha said it would save £ 50bn a year by cutting `` wasteful spending `` and bureaucracy . asked which public service his party would get rid of , leader nigel farage told the bbc : `` it ’ s not about getting rid of public service , it ’ s about making them more efficient . `` it ’ s about the national health service not swallowing up huge amount of money in diversity training , and thing like this . `` he called for an `` open debate `` about the future of the health service , arguing `` the nh is not working the way it wa 20 year ago `` , despite taking up a higher percentage of government spending . he added that a `` mass simplification of the tax system `` would `` bring u enormous saving `` . reform ha said it would increase the threshold when people start paying tax to £ 20,000 a year , a well a abolishing inheritance tax for all estate worth less than £ 2m . on sunday , labour set out plan to build more prison in england by allowing minister to bypass the traditional planning process . however , shadow justice secretary shabana mahmood declined to rule out continuing a scheme that allows some prisoner to be freed early to deal with overcrowding , despite sir keir criticising it . m mahmood said it would be `` irresponsible `` to make a decision on the future of the scheme without seeing figure on how many offender had been released.elsewhere , the tory pledged almost £ 730m to expand nh mental health treatment in england a part of move to cut rising welfare cost . it come a the party prepare to launch their manifesto next week , setting out what they plan to do if they form the next government . the tory manifesto is expected to include a promise to permanently get rid of stamp duty tax for first-time buyer of property costing up to £ 425,000 . it is also expected to reiterate a previous commitment to scrap national insurance when it is affordable to do so but it is not thought to include any pledge on inheritance tax . sir keir ha said labour will have `` no tax surprise `` in it manifesto , suggesting it will stick to previous pledge not to increase income tax , national insurance or vat , a well a the tax change it ha already announced . he ha also confirmed the manifesto will include a commitment to recognise a palestinian state a `` part of the process `` to a two-state solution , alongside `` a safe and secure israel `` . it will also include plan to recruit more teacher and police officer , and to cut net migration - the difference between the number of people coming to live in the uk and those leaving.the liberal democrat have said their manifesto `` will prioritise fixing the health and social care crisis `` . on sunday , the party announced it would include a pledge to increase the carer 's allowance , available to people who look after someone with an illness or disability for at least 35 hour a week , by £ 20 a week . the lib dems said they would also raise the eligibility threshold for the allowance to those earning less than £ 183 a week , with the change costing a total of £ 1.4bn a year . the green party say it manifesto will include practical solution to the cost-of-living crisis , building new affordable home , protecting the nh from `` creeping privatisation and cleaning up river and sea . it ha called for the next government to invest an extra £ 50bn a year in the nh in england , funded through a new wealth tax on the top 1 % of earners.the snp manifesto , which will be launched the following week Body Text: the dramatic rescue of four israeli hostage in gaza amid effort to try to get israel and hamas to agree to a ceasefire ha raised question over the impact it could have on reaching a deal , a mediated talk show no sign of a breakthrough.as image of the freed and smiling three men and one woman dominated tv bulletin and news website , ten of thousand of people joined protest across israel on saturday , urging the government to strike an agreement with hamas for the release of those who are still being held . “ all of them , now ! ” the crowd chanted in tel aviv.hamas meanwhile ha called the operation , which it health ministry said killed more than 270 palestinian , a “ massacre ” . being discussed is a three-stage plan announced by u president joe biden earlier this month , which he described a an israeli proposal . it would secure the release of the hostage and , crucially , pave the way for a permanent ceasefire in gaza.notably , the israeli prime minister , benjamin netanyahu , ha not openly endorsed the plan . it is not surprising , a he is facing pressure from multiple front and seems to be caught between two option : ceasefire or coalition.the family of the hostage , whose ordeal ha gripped the nation , and israel ’ s international ally are calling for a deal . from the people captured in october , 116 remain in captivity ; more than a third of them have already been officially declared dead , a number that is probably higher.among those against the proposal , full detail of which have not been made public , are two of mr netanyahu ’ s far-right minister , itamar ben-gvir and bezalel smotrich . they have threatened to quit the government if the deal go ahead , which could lead to the collapse of the netanyahu coalition . “ temporarily in israel there will be more pressure from certain quarter on netanyahu to not do any deal , that we should continue to do rescue operation , ” gershon baskin , who helped negotiated a deal with hamas for the release of captured israeli soldier gilad shalit in 2011 , said . “ anyone who think logically and rationally know that the only way to get [ the ] hostage home is through a negotiated deal . ” the resignation of benny gantz from the emergency government on sunday is likely to result in more power to both mr ben-gvir and mr smotrich – and , possibly , in more pressure from them on mr netanyahu . described a a moderate , mr gantz is considered a possible candidate to be the next prime minister.in israel , much of the dispute over the current proposal is around the commitment to a permanent cessation of hostility – in other word , the end of the war . mr netanyahu ha insisted israel will not accept any plan before the destruction of hamas ’ s military and governing capability , a choice of word that is vague enough to leave his option open . “ i believe that netanyahu prefers his coalition over bringing our boy and girl home , ” said michael hauser tov , chief political correspondent at the haaretz newspaper , which is critical of the prime minister . this is a common suspicion in israel and elsewhere : that mr netanyahu is interested in prolonging the war for his own political survival . “ i think netanyahu will try to continue with the negotiation only for his international need and the relationship with president biden . and , on the other hand , he ’ ll try to sabotage the negotiation because he want to keep his coalition stable . ” hamas ha not yet given a formal response to the plan outlined by president biden . one of it key demand is a guarantee that the israeli military will not resume it offensive against the group once the hostage are released . “ hamas , from my experience with them , put up a position and they stay firm to it . how long can they last ? i don ’ t know , ” mr baskin said . “ my perception is that the longer israel continues this war , the easier for [ hamas ] to recruit new recruit from bereaved family and people who ’ ve lost their home , and an armed insurgency against the israeli will continue a long a israel is in gaza . ” the israeli rescue in gaza , which resulted in the death of one israeli special force officer , wa considered a successful operation by israel ’ s top authority , despite the carnage in nuseirat that ha been largely ignored in israel . “ if anyone belief that [ saturday ’ s ] operation absolves the government to strike a deal , they are living a fantasy , ” nahum barnea , an israeli political commentator , wrote in the yedioth ahronoth newspaper . “ the opposite is true . the joy over the successful rescue of the four only evinced the need for a deal . ” hour after the four freed hostage arrived in a hospital near tel aviv , mr netanyahu visited them and their family . it did not go unnoticed that this happened before the end of the jewish sabbath , when official activity are often muted , and wa accompanied by a torrent of video and photo released by his team . “ when the ending is bad , the prime minister doesn ’ t show up . he doesn ’ t call , either , ” avi marciano , whose daughter noa wa killed in captivity , wrote on facebook.us secretary of state antony blinken is back in the middle east , his eighth trip to the region since the hamas attack , in another effort to push for a deal . there are also growing concern that , without a ceasefire in gaza , violence might escalate along israel ’ s border with lebanon , where the iranian-backed hezbollah movement ha carried out near-daily attacks.with a wide gap remaining between israel and hamas , u pressure is not a guarantee of progress . “ there ’ s no quick end to this war … this could theoretically go on for year , ” mr baskin said . “ i really want to be optimistic , but it ’ s very difficult to be . ”

collides with israeli politics . president joe biden belief that the time ha come to end the war in gaza . mr blinken ’ s job is to try to make that happen . but messrs ben-gvir and smotrich have threatened to bring down the netanyahu government if he agrees to any ceasefire until they are satisfied that hamas ha been eliminated.they are extreme jewish nationalist , who want the war to continue until no trace of hamas remains . they believe that gaza , like all the territory between the mediterranean sea and the river jordan , is jewish land that should be settled by jew . not weakened the resilience of hamas . for them , survival of their group and it leader equal victory . they will focus on the fact that the killing of more than 37,000 palestinian , mostly civilian – according to the health ministry in gaza – have brought israel into deep disrepute . it face a case alleging genocide at the international court of justice , and application at the international criminal court for arrest warrant for benjamin netanyahu and israel ’ s defence minister yoav gallant.on the israeli side , prime minister netanyahu ha lost two member of the war cabinet , messrs gantz and eisenkot , who wanted a pause in the war to allow negotiation to free hostage . he is more exposed , without the political insulation they provided , to the hardliner , messrs ben-gvir and smotrich . perhaps antony blinken will urge him to call their bluff , to make the deal and satisfy million of israeli who want the hostage back before more of them are killed . mr netanyahu might then have no choice other than to risk his government by gambling on an election . defeat will bring forward commission of enquiry that will examine whether he bear responsibility for the political , intelligence and military failure that allowed hamas to break into israel eight month ago.or benjamin netanyahu might default to the technique of procrastination and propaganda that he ha perfected over all his year a israel ’ s longest-serving prime minister . if in doubt , play for time , and push argument harder than ever . on 24 july , he will return to one of his favourite pulpit , when he the release of hostage held by hamas , the return of dead hostage ' remains and the exchange of palestinian prisoner . fourteen of the 15 security council member voted in favour of the us-drafted resolution . russia abstained . the resolution state that israel ha accepted the ceasefire proposal , and urge hamas to agree to it too.it mean the security council join a number of government , a well a the g7 group of the world 's richest nation , in backing the three-part plan that wa unveiled by president joe biden in a televised statement on 31 may . mr biden described it then a an israeli ceasefire proposal.the proposal submitted by israel to the u and fellow mediator qatar and egypt – reportedly lengthier than the summary presented by mr biden - ha not been made public and it is unclear whether it varies from what the president presented . the proposal wa agreed to by israel ’ s three-man war cabinet and ha not been divulged to the wider government . some far-right minister have already made clear they oppose it . israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu ha not said directly whether he support the plan a laid out by president biden . the resolution wa approved shortly after u secretary of state antony blinken met with foreign leader , including mr netanyahu , in an attempt to build support for the ceasefire deal.just hour before the un vote , mr blinken said his message to leader in the region wa : `` if you want a ceasefire , press hamas to say yes . `` the group ha previously said it support part of the plan , and it released a statement on monday “ welcoming ” the security council resolution . hamas emphasised it demand for a permanent ceasefire in gaza , full israeli withdrawal from the gaza strip , a well a the exchange for palestinian prisoner . the group said it is ready to cooperate with mediator and enter `` indirect negotiation `` . it political leadership in doha ha yet to formally respond to the proposal , according to u and israeli officials.the proposal would end with a major reconstruction plan for gaza , which ha been largely destroyed in the conflict . the first phase concern a hostage-prisoner swap a well a a short-term ceasefire.the second phase includes a `` permanent end to hostility `` , a well a a full withdrawal of israeli force from gaza , according to a text of the u draft resolution . the third phase focus on the enclave 's long-term outlook , and it would start a multi-year reconstruction plan for gaza . monday 's resolution come 10 day after president biden said the israeli had agreed to the plan.while mr biden presented the peace initiative a an israeli one , the u is also aware israel ’ s own fractious ruling coalition is approaching the plan with reluctance . this extends to outright opposition by some far-right minister who are threatening to trigger a collapse of the government if the deal progresses.the resignation of former general and centrist benny gantz from the war cabinet on sunday ha deepened that sense of instability.jeremy bowen : netanyahu walk tightrope a u urge dealpresident biden 's account on x , formerly twitter , noted the passage of the resolution . `` hamas say it want a ceasefire , `` the post said . `` this deal is an opportunity to prove they mean it . `` linda thomas-greenfield , the u ambassador to the un , said : `` today we voted for peace `` . uk ambassador barbara woodward described the situation in gaza a `` catastrophic `` , adding that the `` suffering ha gone on for far too long `` . `` we call upon the party to ? `` mr nebenzia asked.despite voting in favour , china also expressed concern over the text . it un ambassador questioned whether this time would be any different to the three previous security Body Text: hamas ha pushed back after being criticised by u secretary of state antony blinken for not yet accepting a ceasefire proposal , saying it had shown `` positivity `` towards the negotiations.the group said it had `` dealt positively . . . with the latest proposal and all proposal to reach a ceasefire agreement `` . it said , in contrast , `` while blinken continues to talk about ' israel ’ s ' approval of the latest proposal , we have not heard any israeli official voicing approval `` . mr blinken ha repeatedly said that israel ha accepted a ceasefire proposal outlined by president biden on 31 may . israel 's government ha not officially said so , though an israeli plan formed the basis for mr biden 's declaration . speaking in qatar on wednesday , mr blinken expressed frustration with hamas 's response to the israeli ceasefire proposal , which the group delivered on tuesday.the detail of the response have not been made public , though mr blinken said hamas had proposed change , some of which , he said , were unworkable . `` at some point in a negotiation – and this ha gone back and forth for a long time – you get to a point where if one side continues to change it demand , including making demand and insisting on change for thing that it already accepted , you have to question whether they ’ re proceeding in good faith or not . `` but in a series of statement on wednesday night , hamas questioned whether israel had actually accepted either the plan or a un security council resolution endorsing it . `` the world did not hear any welcome or approval from [ israeli prime minister benjamin ] netanyahu `` and his government to the resolution , it said . `` rather they continued to emphasise the rejection of any permanent ceasefire , in clear contradiction with the security council resolution and president biden ’ s initiative . `` hamas said that on the other hand , it had `` clearly expressed it positive position on what wa included in u president joe biden ’ s speech `` and on `` what wa included `` in the resolution . it also said it had confirmed it `` readiness to co-operate `` with the mediator involved in the ceasefire negotiations.after a meeting with mr netanyahu in jerusalem on monday , mr blinken said the prime minister had `` reaffirmed his commitment `` to the ceasefire proposal.mr netanyahu ha not publicly endorsed the plan , although the war cabinet which he lead authorised the proposal which wa delivered to hamas on 27 may . that proposal - reportedly lengthier than the summary presented by mr biden - ha not been made public and it is unclear whether it varies from what the president conveyed in his televised statement at the end of last month.one of the main sticking point between the two side appears to be their vision for ending the war . report say hamas is insisting first on written guarantee that israel will end the war before it will sign up to the plan . mr netanyahu ha said the war will not end until hamas 's `` governing and military capability `` have been destroyed and the hostage returned . the war began after hamas attacked israel on 7 october , killing about 1,200 people and taking 251 others back to gaza a hostage . the hamas-run health ministry say more than 37,000 people have been killed in israel 's offensive since then .

Body Text: a group of student from the london school of economics ( lse ) have lost the first stage of a legal battle over a pro-palestine encampment set up inside a university building.the group set up the encampment within the atrium of the ground floor of the marshall building in central london on 14 may.the university began legal action to remove the group earlier this month , seeking a court order forcing the student to disband it.following a hearing at the central london county court , district judge kevin moses issued an interim possession order , requiring the group to leave the premise within 24 hour once the order is served . he said the group `` are aware of the difficulty they are causing the claimant . they are aware of the difficulty they are causing to other user of the premise `` . judge moses added that , while the student had the right to protest , `` what it doe not do is give party an unfettered right to occupy other party ' premise with a view to protesting , particularly when they are required to leave `` . the group set up the encampment after the release of the asset in apartheid report by the lse student ' union 's palestine society.the report claim that lse ha invested £ 89m in 137 company involved in the conflict in gaza , fossil fuel , the arm industry , or nuclear weapon production.dozens of student have since been staying at the encampment for more than a month and had vowed to remain there until lse met a series of demand , including divestment and democratisation of the financial decision-making process.lse previously said it would carefully consider the report and hoped for `` peaceful dialogue `` . riccardo calzavara , representing the university in court , said the student had `` stormed the building `` and `` barricaded `` themselves in the atrium last month.he said : `` they may have had permission to enter the building , a they appear to be student , but they did not have permission to enter the building in order to encamp on part of it , nor have they ever had permission to remain there . `` mr calzavara said in written submission that the encampment posed an `` intolerable fire risk `` and caused `` considerable cost , and disruption , to the claimant and other user of the marshall building `` . he added that lse did not seek to evict the student because of their protest , but `` because they have taken over a building of ours unlawfully `` . he also acknowledged that while there wa `` nothing to prevent `` the student from returning to the building once the court order expired , they could not `` occupy it to the exclusion of others `` . daniel grutters , representing three of the student , said member of the encampment were willing to make any necessary adjustment to the camp in response to safety concern `` but for leaving `` , and were not blocking other people from accessing the building.he said : `` this , in it essence , is an attempt by all of the defendant to educate the lse about it implicity in what it call crime against humanity , genocide and apartheid . `` he continued : `` to the extent that the claimant is relying on health and safety risk , the defendant are willing to comply with any and all health and safety adjustment and recommendation made . `` he added : `` seeking to remove them , only to allow them to re-enter but for spending the night , is not a decision that is maintainable . `` a further hearing in the case will be held at a later date . listen to the best of bbc radio london on sound and follow bbc london on facebook , x and withdrew from planned slot this summer.a spokesperson for live nation said : `` following discussion with artist , we have agreed with barclays that they will step back from sponsorship of our festival . `` the bank signed a five-year sponsorship deal with live nation in 2023 . it is understood that the suspension doe not apply to the full term of the contract.mercury-nominated band lankum , who are on the line-up for suffolk 's latitude festival in july , were among the first to respond to the announcement . `` we welcome the news , `` they said on instagram . `` since the beginning of the campaign there ha been great collective effort from a number of band , artist and fan to get to this point . `` standing together is the best foot forward . `` the development come after more than amid the ongoing war in gaza.a spokesperson for barclays told the bbc : `` barclays wa asked and ha agreed to suspend participation in the remaining live nation festival in 2024 . `` barclays customer who hold ticket to these festival are not affected and their ticket remain valid . the protester ’ agenda is to have barclays debank defence company which is a sector we remain committed to a an essential part of keeping this country and our ally safe . `` they added that the protest had led to intimidation of staff and vandalism of their branch . `` the only thing that this small group of activist will achieve is to weaken essential support for cultural event enjoyed by million , `` they added . `` it is time that leader across politics , business , academia and the art stand united against this . `` a number of band pulled out of this weekend 's download festival at donington park in leicestershire . `` we can not sacrifice the principle held by this band and by the scene we were made aware of barclays ’ involvement in download we knew we could no longer participate . this moment of solidarity is an opportunity for festival organiser to reflect carefully on who they take take the fee . `` barclays ha previously said it recognises `` the profound human suffering `` caused by the `` complex and long-running conflict `` in gaza.however , it insisted it doe not make it own investment , but provides financial service to business `` including those in the defence sector `` . that includes company `` that supply defence product to nato and other ally including ukraine `` . it added that `` barclays doe not directly invest in these company `` and that `` decision on the implementation of arm embargo to other nation `` should be taken by governments.protest group
